keyFeatures: Branched to base, those on upper half of tree tend to point upward, lower ones are horizontal or deflected downward; needles blue-green, soft, curve out and up on branches, new growth bluish; buds and young bark have resin blisters.
Leaves compound, leaflets deeply dissected, 2-3 pinnate; flowers in small heads arranged in corymbs.
New stems pubescent; leaves green, white, pink. Winter ID: rough brown bark; buds tiny, circular, raised.

Habit is low branching; leaves large (30 cm), mid-green, palmate with 5 lobes (3 major lobes); florets in pendulous racemes. Winter ID: buds large (10 mm), green, opposite; samaras large, covered with hairs.
Leaves rounded, serrated with shallow lobes and nine major veins palmately arranged. Winter ID: fringe of fine white hairs on base of buds, green bark.
Leaves simple, palmately 5-7 lobed, simple, red-purple, serrated margin; stems new growth purple. Winter ID: buds, ovoid, have light brown hairs on a papery sheath that extends halfway up.

Leaves with 3 major lobes with soft serrations, fall colour vibrant red; terminal buds multiple; samaras red, narrower angle compared to A. platanoides. Winter ID: buds small (3 mm) red opposite; flower buds in large clusters circle twigs, give branches a bumpy look.

Leaf large, palmately compound with 5 obovate leaflets to 30 cm long; florets with 4 or 5 petals, white with pink markings, in 20 cm long panicles; fruit large spiny capsule, splits to release large, glossy brown seed. Winter ID: buds brown, opposite, large (2 cm) and sticky; leaf scar large, with 7 distinct bundle scars.

Leaves palmate with 5 lobes deeply incised, looks like Canadian flag leaf; petiole is long, broken leaf veins or petiole ooze milky sap. Winter ID: buds opposite, large, plump green/burgundy; samara wings held at wide angle (widely divergent wings - unlike sycamore maple)
Leaves evergreen, in basal rosette, succulent, lanceolate to linear, greyish-green leaves, margins and tips spiny.
Leaves basal, spiraled with age, thick, sword-like, fleshy with a toothed edge; florets tubular with 6 tepals on long racemes.
Leaves green with purple underside, fall colour plum-purple; flowers long-lasting, white daisy-like ray florets with hot-pink disc florets.
Horizontal habit; leaves dark green, alternate and obovate, leathery; flowers small, pinkish, urn-shaped; berries over winter.
Large prickly evergreen shrub to 4 m tall. Leaves are lanceolate with spiney edge and are grouped in threes at nodes. Tripartite spines to 4 cm long at nodes.

Leaves dark green, obovate with small serrations; yellow catkins in spring. Winter ID: bark has dark spots; compared to B. utilis var. jacquemontii, B. papyrifera bark is not as white and on older trees, has black checks.
Low growing, often weedy in lawns; leaves toothed, spatulate; flower heads white (pink or red cultivars exist).
Leaves green or bronze, succulent; flowers white, red, or pink.
Leaves alternate, ovate, serrate, blades about 10 cm long. Winter ID: Very white exfoliating bark with orange underneath.
Leaves elliptic, alternate with prominent venation, margins toothed and serrated. Winter ID: buds numerous, adpressed, scaly, reddish brown.
Leaves mostly basal, pinnately compound with rounded stalked leaflets; flowers small with 4 white petals; fruit a narrow exploding silique.

Leaves large (30-40 cm), entire with tomentose undersides; florets in white, large, and showy panicles. Winter ID: fruit to 30 cm long, bean-like capsule containing a fringed seed; leaf scars concave, circular, three per node with large bundle scars.
Clinging vine with aerial roots; leaves pinnately compound with bronze new growth; flowers red-orange, trumpet shaped. Winter ID: leaf scars large, circular.

Leaves very small and somewhat scale like, two per node but next pair rotated 90 degrees so that the stems look like an X if viewing a short stem section from the end; flower parts in 4's, blooms late summer to fall.

Low, horizontal tree with heart-shaped leaves that point downward; flowers clustered, bright pink, pea-like, on trunk and older branches as well as on new wood. Winter ID: Small (2 mm) dark buds, no terminal bud, zig zag stems, flower buds on trunk and large branches.
Branching horizontal, whorled with pendulous branchlets; needles sharp, mid green in whorls, typically on upper side of branchlets; cones green-yellow, sit in upright clusters.

Leaves blue-green, opposite or alternate, orbicular, cordate, margins crenate/serrate, point downward, coppey in spring and then pinkish-yellow in autumn; flowers on female tree, bloom reddish in spring, follicles pod-like, green, most < 15 mm long. Winter ID: buds small red opposite, adpressed, 'lobster claws'; fruit small, green or brown, banana shaped may be present on female plants.
Stem swollen at leaf node (ID feature of family); leaves obovate, decussate; flowers white with five notched petals resembling two petals each; much fuzzier than Stellaria media.
Small multi-trunked palm tree; leaves large, pinnately compound with long, narrow leaflets (typical palm leaf); stems clustered.
Long cord-like golden branchlets; leaves scale-like, in opposing pairs.
Leaves simple and pinnate with spines on margins; stems are spineless; flowers pink to violet, tubular composed of many small, narrow, upright petals.

Leaves trifoliate with deep serrations, green with purple tinge near petiole; flowers solitary, four petal-like sepals, (white-) pink (-purple), prominent styles and stamens; fruit is an aggregate of swirled achenes. Winter ID: Stems purple; buds opposite, pointed, hooked.
Very aggressive weedy vine that twines; leaves heart-shaped; flowers large, white, funnel shaped.

Small tree; leaves opposite, ovate; flowers solitary, bloom before or as leaves emerge, bract tips rounded with a cleft (compared to more pointed bract tips of C. kousa). Winter ID: bark texture resembles 'Alligator skin'; twigs glaucous, red/purple; terminal vegetative buds look like purple 'chicken feet' or garlic-shaped flowers buds and red leaf buds.
petalColour: (bracts white or red for f. rubra)

keyFeatures: Flowers bracts white and often turning pink with age (bract tips are pointed compared to those of C. florida which are rounded with a cleft). Winter ID: Flower buds are onion shaped and are not as flattened as C florida; bark mottled and exfoliating.

Inflorescence bract tips are pointed compared to bract tips of C. florida which is rounded with a cleft. Winter ID: flower buds onion shaped and are not as flattened as C florida; bark mottled, exfoliating.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: (certain cvs have pink bracts (e.g. C. Satomi))

keyFeatures: Creeping succulent; leaves smallish, almost round, thick, fleshy; stem thick, creeping and woody.

Leaves narrow elliptic, irregularly toothed, to 10 cm long, dark green then bronze red in fall; florets white, in 3-inch corymbs, in May with unpleasant fragrance; pomes to 1 cm wide, ripen to orange-red in September-October and typically persist until spring. Winter ID: persistent red-orange fruits, dense branching with long thorns.
origin: Garden origin (France: C. stipulacea x C. crus-galli)

keyFeatures: Invasive weed; stems evergreen, angular; leaves small, trifoliate; flowers bright yellow, laterally symmetical, very abundant in May-June; fruit is legume, long white hairs when immature. Winter ID: stems evergreen; trunk solitary, woody.
Flowers very large, zinnia-like, round with many petals, solitary on tall stems; leaves are opposite, pinnately compound with toothed ovate leaflets.

Tree vase-shape; leaves lightly serrated, ovate/cordate, oblique base, cirrhose tip, pinkish petiole; flowers ellipsoid head with many red-purple anthers and a single green ovary, two drooping creamy-white bracts 'wings', late spring; fruit green-brown nut-like drupe containing a single seed. Winter ID: buds plump, terminal, red bud/scales, green tip, shiny; bark orange-brown, scaly.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves grey-green, long, narrow, sheathing at swollen nodes and in a basal tuft; flowers cymose, ruffled.
Leaves lanceolate, narrow; flowers with fringed petals and a purple eye, in clusters of 10-15 in summer.
Leaves large, variegated with cream mottling in center, green margins and midrib; trunk sometimes single with spaced horizontal woody rings up the entire length.
Leaves long, linear with red margin, densely whorled.

Leaf vernation rolled, blades flat, thick midrib, flat, and narrow at base, +/- hairs along margins… auricles absent...ligule absent… sheath and culm compressed, flattened, purplish near base…rhizomes absent…circular mat habit when mowed and dies with first hard frost (annual).

Herbaceous perennial; leaves lanceolate, serrate with a strongly acute tip; inflorescence head with purple-pink ray florets angled downwards, surrounding cone of disk florets. Winter ID: head of seeds (achenes).
petalColour: but ray florets of cultivars may be white

keyFeatures: Trailing vine; leaves alternate, obovate with green and white variegation, usually cream mottling rather than an organized variegation.
Aggressive weed; stems straight up, hollow with horizontal separations; leaves whorled, soft needle-like; spores borne from cone-like structures at stem tip; abrasive to touch.

Small evergreen usually less than 30 cm tall; leaves needle-like, glabrous, in whorls of three, mostly about 10 mm long x 1 mm wide; florets urn-shaped in raceme with leaf like bracts, most cvs bloom for 6-8 weeks between December and April.

Groups of thick basal stems, when broken, plant exudes white sap that may irritates skin; leaves whorled, linear, grey-green, smell like coffee; inflorescence large yellow-green rises above on tall stalks.
Plant often used indoors at Christmas; stem exudes white sap when broken; flowers yellow, not showy, encircled with coloured bracts commonly red (white or pink cvs.).
Stems erect, dark purple; leaves bright green, whorled at nodes; inflorescence is large pinkish panicle; achenes feathery for wind dispersal.

Leaves alternate, deltoid to ovate, glossy with margins entire, undulate, and often ciliate; fruit capsule-like, brown, bristly. Winter ID: elliptical buds >2 cm long x 4 mm wide, pointed, spear-like, divergent, brown; bark smooth, silver-grey, with a horizontal pattern (like an elephant's leg).

scientificName: Festuca glauca ( syn. F. ovina glauca  )
keyFeatures: Small, tufted mounds; leaves blue-green, smooth, tightly in-rolled (almost needle-like) and erect or slightly arching, evergreen, about 1 mm wide; flowers dense, shortly branched panicles of spikelets early to midsummer.

Leaves elliptic to ovate with long pointed tip, glossy, leathery with undulating margin, stipules narrow, shedding; branchlets thin and weak; bark smooth, pale; trunks are often braided in indoor potted varieties.
Branches weeping, arching; leaves opposite, decussate, dark green; flowers droop, resemble lanterns especially when closed, 4-8 white petals with a brilliant dark pink corolla.

Shrub dense; leaves opposite, ovate to lance-shape, serrate; flowers deep bright yellow, March; fruit small brown capsules. Winter ID: buds greenish divergent; lenticels bumpy on older stems/trunks; young stems yellow-green before maturing to orange/brown.
origin: Garden origin (F. suspensa x F. viridissima)

keyFeatures: Leaves on stem usually in whorls of 8, linear to narrowly oblanceolate, bristly hairs, margins entire, 1-4(-7) cm long; flowers small, in terminal clusters of 3-5.
Leaves are light gray-green, lanceolate, sessile and pubescent; flower head with rolled ray florets; usually yellow with some orange disk florets; fruit is a fuzzy ball.

Native evergreen shrub; leaves broadly ovate, thick, dark green with minute serrations; stems pubescent; raceme of fuzzy, urn-shaped pinkish white florets; fruit is purple-red, fuzzy accessory tissue.
Leaves large, basal, oblanceolate with shallow lobes; petioles floppy, pubescent; head with varying colours of ray florets.
origin: Garden origin (G. jamesonii x G. viridifolia)

keyFeatures: Leaves few, basal and then opposite, kidney-shaped, long-stalked, 1.5-5 cm long, 5-7 coarsely toothed lobes; flower petals pink, shallowly notched, 3-5 mm long. (E-Flora BC).
Upright with some horizontal branching; leaves flat, leathery, fan-shaped, bi-lobed, densely clustered, dichotomous venation. Winter ID: buds large, stubby spurs, and orange-brown.

Leaves pinnately or bipinnately compound, many small leaflets 1-4 cm long. Winter ID: buds very small; legumes long, twisted, dark brown; branches zigzag with swollen nodes and gnarled leaf scars; crown open; bark is mottled gray.

Leaves linear, in basal rosette, up to 45 cm long x 6 cm wide; inflorescence is a corymb with many tiny white florets among dark red (or less commonly pink, orange, or yellow) leaf-like bracts spiraled up peduncle.
Leaves opposite, linear, similar to carnation, with swollen nodes; inflorescence panicle of tiny white to pink flowers, often used in floral arrangements with roses.

Invasive evergreen ground cover or climber that freely roots at leaf nodes; leaves mostly ovate (some almost triangular), glossy; juvenile leaves 3-5 lobed; mature leaves unlobed, dark green or variegated mid-green/silver-gray variegation/white margins; flowers tiny, 5-lobed in yellow-green umbel clusters.
fruitColour: (black for common subspecies but others may be orange to yellow when ripe)

keyFeatures: Leaves purple, palmate, lobed, shiny, deep veined, maple leaf-like in appearance, present all year; inflorescence panicle of tiny, ball-like white flowers borne on a long peduncle rising high above leaves.
Leaves obovate, serrated, very dark green, glossy; flower solitary with bright petals of any colour (white, red, yellow, pink etc).
Leaves blue-green, basal, ovate with cordate base.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Twiggy, deciduous shrub; leaves large, opposite, broadly ovate, coarse toothed; inflorescence flattened corymb-like cymes (mop-head or lace-cap), some florets with large blue to pink bracts (depends on soil acidity). Winter ID: buds opposite, large triangular leaf scars with 3 bundle scars; persistent round dried inflorescences (if not pruned).
petalColour: (acidic soil -> blue flowers; alkaline soil -> pink flowers )

keyFeatures: Twiggy; leaves elliptical, medium-sized in whorls of 3; some florets large white to pink 4 lobes; inflorescences large, cone-shaped, panicle-like (thryse). Winter ID: buds tiny and in whorls of 3; large, persistent conical inflorescences (if not pruned).

Climbing vine hydrangea; corymb-like cymes, outer ring of florets have 4 lobes, centre florets have no petals. Winter ID: bark shaggy, exfoliating cinnamon-tan; buds 1 cm, yellow; stem has root-like hold-fasts; fruit and flowers persist.
Leaves opposite on tall upright stems, when held up to light small clear dots or perforations can be seen.
Low growing spreading evergreen; leaves narrow and spiralled; flowers bright white in late spring.

Perennial weed similar to dandelion but has green penduncles with no latex; leaves are fleshy and less severely lobed than dandelion with rounded tips and short hairs; stems are very narrow, forked; flowers 5-15 mm in diameter; achene with long white hairs.
inflorescence: Small heads arranged in a cyme

keyFeatures: Small, dense, evergreen shrub; leaves mostly less than 10(-13) mm long, closely spaced, alternate-spirally arranged, almost round, glossy, and 2-4 small teeth with tiny glands on points.

Low growing, dense evergreen mat, sprawling, with trailing branch tips; leaves scale-like, 2 mm long, tightly pressed to stem except when shaded when awl-shaped juvenile leaves 5-10 mm long may occur; seed cones fleshy, berrylike, maturing to bluish-purple, glaucous, up to 8 mm long; pollen cones on separate plants and seed cones on separate plants.
Leaves ovate, margins dentate to crenate and/ or ciliate, to 7 cm long; flowers showy, 2-6 cm wide, flattened petals, slender-spur.

Large tree; leaves oddly pinnate, commonly with (11-)15(-23) leaflets; fruit is a large brown to yellow and drupe-like. Winter ID: leaf scar large (8 mm), resembles a monkey face; buds small, dark brown; new growth and buds pubescent.
Leaves thick, fleshy, crenate; corymb of numerous, small, star shaped flowers in varying colours.
Deciduous conifer; needles short, soft, occur in tufts; cones occur between nodes. Winter ID: buds small, spherical, fused with the branch; branches bare.
Floating aquatic weed; fronds 2-6 mm long, succulent, flat and circular, similar in appearance to squashed peas, un-stalked but with thin adventitious roots arising from the blade.

Basal leaves are dark green, fleshy, lanceolate with serrated margins, up to 30 cm; stem leaves are shorter, lanceolate and sessile; flowers solitary with white ray florets surrounding yellow disc florets.

Leaves usually 5 lobed and similar to some maples but are alternate, brilliant fall colours from purple to yellow. Winter ID: branches may have corky outgrowths; leaf scar with three large bundle scars; fruit is a multiple fruit capsule and persists through winter.
Trailing perennial; stem leaves 1.5 cm long, narrow, linear, serrate,mid-dark green; flowers 5 cm, raceme, tubular, blue/violet, Apr-June.
Leaves mostly oblanceolate; flowers white, panicles resemble small balls of flowers; panicles elongate to over 30 cm as fruit form up from bottom; florets to 8 mm wide with four petals.

Native evergreen shrub; leaves sessile, pinnately compound with holly-like leaflets (Ilex aquifolium has simple leaves); inflorescence showy yellow clustered racemes; fruit are true berries, blue-violet, in clusters.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Smaller, horizontal-oval tree with a gray, mottled trunk, disorganized branching, new growth red with white lenticels; leaves simple, glossy, ovate, green leaves; flowers 2-3 cm wide, commonly with pink buds, petals pink to white; pomes about 9-13 mm round, yellow to red.
petalColour: (deep pink in bud then flowers pale pink but some cv. more pink or all white)

keyFeatures: Trailing tropical plant; leaves alternate, elliptic with squarish dark green patches with triangular notches arranged along the midrib.
Leaves dark green with strong red veining.

Ground covering weed in moist shade or on media surface of overwatered potted plants; thallus thick, flattened, lobed to almost ruffled; gemmae like eggs in cup-like nest; female gametophyte 'palm tree' like; male gametophyte also stalked but with a flat top.
Deciduous conifer; leaves yew-like (soft flat needles), 1-3 cm long. Winter ID: buds small, yellowish, opposite; bark is shaggy; trunk has depressions or an 'armpit' below branch attachments.
Large, arching ornamental grass; leaves have white midrib; spike inflorescence has very furry spikelets, formation not as feathery as most grasses but more linear.
petalColour: (Inflorescence usually emerges whitish then reddish as flowers ripen and then silverish to light brown once they're spent.)

keyFeatures: Leaves very large, split as they age resulting in elliptical holes (swiss cheese appearance); roots can be aerial.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Taller, multistemmed, evergreen shrub with erratic growth pattern; leaves large, compound, tripinnate with dark, serrate leaflets, rachis rough to the touch, new growth red.
Leaves long, very narrow, linear but curve back on themselves near tips; stem single, swollen at base.
Flattened, upright modified stem looks like oblong pads; modified leaves are yellow clusters of many very small soft spines.

Leaves alternate, mostly elliptic to oblanceolate, margins entire (rarely toothed), about 4 cm wide x 10 cm long. Winter ID: Light green, chubby buds, rough lenticels, irregular growth habit often with drooping lower branches.
Weed; leaves trifolate, leaflets heart-shaped, mid-green with purple tinged magins or entirely purple; flowers yellow with five petals; fruit pod like.

Smaller deciduous tree; leaves simple, irregularly shaped, alternate with undulating margin; fruit and flowers insignificant. Winter ID: flower buds 4 mm, pubescent brown; buds stalked, fuzzy, dark brown to black; bark mildly exfoliating, smooth.
petalColour: (Make flowers with numerous red stamens; yellowish female flowers on same tree)

keyFeatures: Leaves large, heart-shaped, peach fuzz on underside; bark has stretch marks; inflorescence panicle with large showy, violet yellow florets. Winter ID: flower buds large, fuzzy, in clusters; persistent brown, oval, pointed capsules.

Leaves alternate, palmately compound with 5 serrated leaflets 4-14 cm long; tendrils arising opposite the petioles at nodes. Winter ID: dark blue berries; stems reddish; stem tendrils with adhesive pads at tips of 5-8 branches; leaf scars concave.
Leaves upright, jointed with other leaves at nodes; inflorescence bottle brush of fluffy spikelets; fruit green grain with long purple hair.
Annual bedding plant; stem mildly fuzzy; leaves round, lily pad-like, dark to bright green; inflorescence of various colours in umbels with 5 petals per floret.

Leaf blades >1.2 mm wide and up to 20 cm long, flat and sharp-pointed with rough margins; sheath margins transparent; auricles absent; ligule tall rounded, toothed or torn, hairy on surface facing blade.

Creeping annual; stems long and somewhat limp; leaves pale, light green, ovoid and alternate; flowers radially symmetrical, large (>4 cm wide), petals white to purple (or bicolour), trumpet-like, limp; sepals with prominent green finger-like sepals.
Trailing or climbing tropical plant; leaves cordate, glossy bright green; roots can be aerial.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite, rough with small white hairs, wavy margins, twisted petioles. Winter ID: fruit small brown capsules split in 4, persist in winter; leaf scar heart-shaped, non-descript bundle scars.
Needles radial, 4 sided; cones long and narrow; branchlets are long, pendulous. General ID features for spruce: needles are short, prickly and leave pegs when removed; cones are pendulous.
Leaves are narrow elliptic, alternate and appear whorled at end of branches, new growth is red; flowers white, urn shaped, many suspended from each peduncle.

Whorled, organized branching, evenly spaced branching; needles 2 per fascicle, 14 cm long, flexible, not snapping when sharply bent; buds whitish and bullet shaped; cone stems are centered; cones large and tan coloured; bark of upper trunk gray to dark brown.
Branching random, contorted; needles twisted, occur in 2 per fascicle; cones small, brown, cone stem is off centre.
Dense, pyramidal shape with horizontal lower branches; needles very sharp, prickly greyish-blue to 3 cm long; new growth is pale blue.

Bark orangish, peeling, branching open; needles 2 per fascicle, flat, 2.5-5(-7 cm) long, blue-green; female cones lumpy, green when immature, woody and open when mature, drop at maturity (unlike shore pine where they are persistent).

scientificName: Platanus x acerifolia ( syn. x hispanica )
keyFeatures: Leaves maple-like with 3 major lobes but alternate (like on the Canadian penny!); petiole has hollow end that hides bud. Winter ID: fruit like a 4 cm pom pom; buds red, smooth, 5 mm long; bark exfoliating, looks like camouflage; branches zig-zag.
origin: Garden origin (P. orientalis × P. occidentalis - many autorites have dropped the 'x' in scientific name)

keyFeatures: Leaves bright, deep parallel veins, lanceolate with smooth margins; inflorescence is a spike of green spikelets flush to the spike; fruit are insignificant pale brown papery capsules.
Common weed; leaves ovate, broad with prominemt parallel veins; inflorescence is a spike of green spikelets; fruit is a small light brown capsule.
Leaf tips boat-shaped, blade with puckering and wrinkling; seed head can be seen even when grass is very low growing. Field ID terms: boat tip, seed heads, brighter, apple-green, dull under.

Leaves oval to nearly triangular leaves, up to 10 cm long; florets white to pale pink, 1 cm wide, in drooping panicles; fruit a shiny black achene about 2 mm wide. Winter ID: Light brown, silvery stems; fruit may persist.

Stems hollow, bamboo-like, arising from rhizomes; leaves have a straight base (truncate), apex with an abruptly pointed tip, undersides have small ridges or bumps on veins or margins, up to 17 cm long; florets creamy-white, 2-3 mm wide, in panicles arising from leaf axils that are about 15 cm long. (Giant knotweed, F. sachalinensis, is very similar but larger).

Leaves alternate, broadly ovate, wavy margins, underside silvery with brown spots (resin blotches). Winter ID: buds about 1.5 cm long lanceolate, green and brown, sweetly aromatic when crushed; leaf scar oval.

Small, round deciduous shrub; leaves compound-palmate, with 5(-7) alternating, mostly elliptical leaflets 1-2 cm long. Winter ID: very twiggy; bark shaggy, cinnamon coloured; fruit 5-lobed that sometimes persist in winter.
petalColour: (Species has yellow flowers. Many cultivars with white

keyFeatures: Fronds once pinnate, most between 10-20 cm wide x 80-120 cm long; pinnae delicately serrated with a larger tooth near pinna base, lower surface has obvious yellow to orange sori.
Leaves succulent, clustered at nodes; grows in dry areas; flowers about 2 cm wide with with 5 overlapping yellow petals.

Compact, evergreen shrub; leaves alternate, mostly elliptic, glossy, rubbery, dark green, point upwards on upward branches (vs. 'Zabeliana' variety which has horizontal orientation); inflorescence is bottle brush-like raceme of small, white florets.

Deciduous tree with a wide spreading crown; very prominent creamy-orange, horizontal lenticels; branches come off stem at 45 degree angle; alternate, ovate, serrate leaves with reddish petioles. Winter ID: Brown pointed buds; fruit spurs; where petiole joins leaf blade, there are kidney shaped glands.

Leaves soft, needle-like, much shorter and flatter than pine trees; cones pendulous with 3-pointed bracts tucked under cone scales, look like tail and back legs of a mouse hiding under scale; bark very thick, deeply fissured. Seedling ID: 5-9 cotyledons, 1.2-2 cm long, no teeth.

Irregular shaped shrub, often trained to climb; leaves lanceolate, dark green and shiny; stem covered in thorns 3-4 cm long; inflorescence is corymb with white florets typical of Rosaceae; fruit orange-red, berry-like in clusters.

Leaves alternate, obovate-elliptic, serrulate, about 5 cm long x 1.5 cm wide; florets white, about 1 cm wide, 5 petals, in corymb-like cymes, pomes about 7 mm round or slightly flattened, red or orange.
Thorns about 1.5 cm long; leaves alternate, spatulate, concave, margins usually entire, apex usually emarginate, up to 6 cm long; florets 5-petaled, white; pomes orange, about 0.5 mm wide.

Leaves glossy, medium green, deep lobes with 'pins' on the tips. Winter ID: buds light brown; branching pattern is distinct - upper branches point up, middle branches are strongly horizontal, bottom branches point down.

Leaves mid-green, most obovate, lobes shallow and rounded (never more than half-way to midrib or pointed pointed), leaf blade narrows toward the petiole (sinus more open and not as deep as in Garry oak), most 12-15 cm long when mature with very short pedicels; catkins with peduncles up to 12 cm long; acorns oval, 2-3 cm long. Winter ID: buds rounded, chubby, brown, terminal buds clustered; branching upright (45 degree angle); twigs greenish.
Leaves have pointed lobes (sinus not as deep as Q. palustris). Winter ID: buds dark reddish at terminals, small and brown with obvious small scales otherwise; branching upright (45 degree angle).
Leaves basal, alternate on runners, with three lobed and toothed leaflets; flowers bright yellow, about 16 mm wide, 5 petals, many stamens.

Leaves basal and then alternate up stem, ovate to lanceolate, bases commonly with lobes pointing outwards (hastate), blades 1-5 cm long, petioles often longer than the blades; florets male or female (dioecious), in relatively large, narrow panicle; perianths 1-1.5 mm long, reddish to yellowish; achenes golden brown, smooth, about 1.5 mm long. (modified from E-Flora BC).
Leaves covered in slight hairs, dark green, crenate, basal or on the floral stalk; flower has long yellow ray florets with a flattish cone of black disk florets; stems slightly hairy.

Invasive, weedy, stems laying on ground can root at nodes; leaves compound (3-5 leaflets) with prickles on the midrib; stems have large prickles; cyme of fragrant white florets each with multiple simple pistils; fruit an aggregate of drupelets, red then black.
Leaves shiny, narrow (species), with rounded toothed margin; flowers in blue "spikes".

Leaves fuzzy, fleshy, basal and range in colour from mid-green to purple (especially the lower surfaces); florets up to 3 cm wide, bilaterally symmetrical, on several separate cymes, most cvs. blue, purple, or pink.
Leaves opposite, serrated, pinnately compound with 7 leaflets, med-green to yellow fall colour. Winter ID: vertical lenticels; chubby red buds.
Tree pendent to the ground; stems golden yellow; leaves <13 cm.long, glossy green/glaucous underneath, alternate, serrulate, lanceolate. Winter ID: weeping golden yellow branches; buds smooth.
Leaves oval, serrate, dark green, up to 8 cm long; flowers tubular, most cvs. bright red, up to 5 cm long in dense, erect, terminal racemes.
Leaves palmately compound, almost whorled, with 7-11 leaflets, glossy medium green; leaflets are elliptical in varying sizes with a smooth margin; flowers insignificant.
fruitType: Drupe, Aborted (hybrids) or absent, Aggregate fruit

keyFeatures: Coral-like appearance, evergreen, often used in annual flowerbeds; leaves are simple, pinnate, deeply lobed and covered in white to gray velvety hairs; flowers occur in loose corymbs of yellow disc and ray florets.
inflorescence: Small heads arranged in a corymb

keyFeatures: Bark thick, cinnamon red, spongy; leaves are overlapping awl-like, sharp pointed, voluminous; branchlets cord-like.
Leaves large, thick fleshy lime green, oblong, crenate from middle to tip; inflorescence a corymb bearing many tiny pink florets; stems fleshy and upright.
origin: Garden origin (S. spectabile X S. telephium subsp. maximum)

keyFeatures: Small deciduous tree 5-15 m tall; bark with horizontal pattern; leaves pinnately compound, up to 20 cm long, (9-)13-17(-19) leaflets oblong-lanceolate, sharp pointed, serrated almost to base, red rachis, mid- to dark green with grey-green undersides, 2-6 cm long; florets >75 per flat-topped corymb each about 13 cm wide. Winter ID: buds large, densely covered with gray soft hairy (resemble pussy willows); fruit persistent, bright red-scarlet to orange pomes 9-11 mm wide. [mainly from E-Flora BC]

Climbing weed; leaves ternate and bright green; inflorescence purple cyme of small drooping flowers, prominent yellow centres (stamens); petals curl back at tips; leaves smell like peanut butter when crushed.
Leaves red-brown, mature to blue-green; florets in deep pink corymb. Winter ID: branches fine, upright with many dry terminal fruit clusters; bark is reddish-brow, smooth.
Leaves basal, elliptic to lanceolate, dark glossy green with prominent venation; inflorescence spadix surrounded by singular bract on an upright, narrow stem.
origin: Mexico (S. cochlearispathum or S. wallisii x ???)
fruitType: Berry (true), Multiple fruit, Aborted (hybrids) or absent

keyFeatures: Leaves bright yellow to golden yellow; flowers candy pink corymb. Winter ID: Branches fine, upright with many dry terminal fruit clusters; bark is reddish-brow, smooth.
Leaves deep, dark green; florets in pale pink, almost white corymb. Winter ID: Branches fine, upright with many dry terminal fruit clusters; bark is reddish-brown, smooth.
Leaves obovate, most 3-5 cm long with a few teeth near tip; flowers white in mass along branches, May-June.
Winter ID: Fine arching branches with fruit clusters. Small (1mm) alternate buds.

Leaves dark green, shiny; flowers pale pink, pendulous with pink pedicel; fruit like hanging balls to 1 cm wide. Winter ID: fruit may persist as shrivelled white shell with light brown centre or on ground; buds appressed and superposed, tan (4mm).
petalColour: (Only Styrax japonicus ‘Pink Chimes’ has pink flowers.)

keyFeatures: Stems succulent with a single line of hairs and swollen at leaf node (ID feature of family); flowers white with five deeply notched petals; similar to Cerastium vulgatum but Stellaria's leaves are not hairy.
Twiggy shrub; leaves opposite, entire, irregularly shaped, new growth tends to be oval. Winter ID: branches fine, twiggy; fruit persistent, 1cm round, white; buds opposite.

Leave similar to common lilac; florets small, white, in large panicles (thryse). Winter ID: buds small, sessile, with four pairs of scales, orange/brown opposite; bark smooth coppery-gray, horizontal lenticels (cherry tree-like).
Leaves opposite, cordate up to 12 cm long; panicles (thyrse) of highly fragrant purple florets with 4 lobes in spring. Winter ID: buds large green opposite; terminal buds in pairs; opened capsules.

Medium sized tree 10-20 m tall (unless a cultivar); leaves needle-like glossy, flat, emerge light green then changing to dark green, 2-3(-4) cm long x 2-3 mm wide; male cones or fruit-like female cones each with a fleshy red aril nearly fully surrounding a single green seed, oval 8-15 mm long, bright red; male cones on separate plants, 3-6 mm round, yellow-brown. (Conifers.org)

Dense, columnar form with upright branches; needles dark green; male cones may appear on some branches; fruit-like female cones each with a fleshy red aril and a single green seed occur on most specimens (plants with male cones only are also common).
Stems hairless, angular; leaves pinnately compound; heads large, rounded, usually double and yellow to orange, 5-10 cm wide, aromatic when crushed.

Weed; leaves narrow with pointed lobes, tips of lobes arching towards plant; stem is pale green, thick, fleshy and hollow; flower large yellow head of ray and disc florets; fruit white, furry ball of seeds (achenes/ cypselas).
Leaves pinnately compound to 10cm long; leaflets are narrow, lance-shaped and toothed; stems are hairless; flower heads solitary, comprised of ruffled ray florets surrounding several disc florets.
Leaves alternate, leaflets pinnate; stems narrow, reddish brown; inflorescence corymb of yellow, flat head, disk florets only, lack ray florets.

Leaves scale-like in flattened opposite pairs with white marking on underside; bark cinnamon red that pulls of in strips; cones are woody with a floral appearance. (Form is shaggier than x Cupressocyparis leylandii.)

Compact, columnar from; leaves dark green, thread-like arranged in vertically oriented fan-shaped 'bunches'; different from T. occidentalis 'Fastigiata': 'Fastigiata' fans are more horizontally oriented, leaves are thick.

Branches zig-zag, leaves dark green/blue-green underneath; flowers pale yellow, up to 1.5 cm wide, June; fruit dry, nut-like; mature bark ridged; buds plump, reddish-light brown. Winter ID: yellow leaves.

Low-growing, roots at nodes; leaves trifoliate with light v-shaped marking on each leaflet; inflorescence oval-round, compact, head-like, umbellate, white or slightly purplish, florets tubular, 5-10 mm long; legume about 5 mm long with 1 to 4 seeds.
Tree-top 'nods' and droops to one side; needles flat most <15 mm long; with 2 white stomatal lines on underside; cones <2 cm, abundant; seedlings w. 3-6 cotyledons.
Creeping weed that roots at nodes; leaves broad ovate to round with crenate edge; fruit capsule heart shaped.

Leaves opposite, simple, ovate, and deeply serrated with petioles and stipules and covered with fine stinging hairs on the margins and underside of leaves; florets 1-2 mm long with 4 green sepals and no petals; fruit an achene 1-1.5 mm long.
Aggressive choking weed; leaves compound, pinnate with linear leaflets, tendrils at leaf ends; inflorescence a raceme, florets violet to purple, narrow; fruit a small brown legume.
Upright arching form; Leaves opposite, prominent venation; petioles vibrant red. Winter ID: flowers axillary and in terminal cyme inflorescence, red to white-pink, fragrant in winter.
origin: Garden origin (V. farreri x V. grandiflorum)

keyFeatures: Fast growing evergreen ground cover; leaves are glossy dark green, opposite, decussate; stems thin, flexible, will root at nodes, exudes milky sap when broken; flowers violet blue, trumpet shaped.

Spreading bushy deciduous shrub; leaves opposite, deeply veined, dark green; lower surface pubescent; florets in saucer shaped or snow-ball shaped terminal cymes. Winter ID: horizontal branching in tiers (especially for V. 'Mariesii'); vegetative buds opposite, tow scales, hairy; flowers buds large, valvate, hairy, and appressed to stem; leaf scar with three prominent bundle scars.

Leaves alternate, leaflets lanceolate; inflorescence raceme of blue-violet or pink-white pea-like florets; long pods. Winter ID: liana, twines clockwise; buds acute with 2 glands at base; leaf node has spine-like projection.
Evergreen, grass-like clumping habit; leaves thick, sword-like with threads on margins; inflorescence a panicle with large (5-7 cm) florets each with 6 white tepals.
Semi-evergreen shrub with arching reddish branches; leaves to 6 cm long, opposite, glossy dark green with long acuminate tips; some bronzing in winter.
origin: S.E. Asia / Japan / China (cross between A. x grandiflora and A. shumannii in1911 )

keyFeatures: Bark cinnamon (orange-red), papery, exfoliating; leaves lobed, bright red fall colour. Winter ID: exfoliating bark, buds sharply pointed, dark purplish-brown.

Large red stalked buds; new stems angular; persistant woody cone; leaves have doubly serrate margins and are rolled under at the edges; male catkins are long and thin, hanging in clusters; female catkins are short and thick, held upright at the ends of branchlets.
Leaves alternate, palmately compound, five leaflets are rounded/notched at the tips; new leaves emerge purple-tinged,mature to bluish-green; flowers small, purple-brown, fragrant.

Leaves unique, awl-shaped, sharply pointed, closely overlapping, symmetrically whorled; female cones globular, up to 20 cm round; male cones cylindrical, up to 15 cm long (usually on separate plants).
Shrub large evergreen; leaves dark green, leathery, serrated, short red petioles ; flowers whitish-pink, urn-shape; fruit round, orange to red to scarlet, spiky; bark shaggy orange-red.
Large, round, evergreen shrub; leaves large, opposite, glossy, and common cultivars green with 'splatter-paint' yellow specks: lenticels prominent.
Shrub dense, mounding, evergreen; three pointed spine at nodes; leaves about 2 cm long, dark green, obovate, single spine at tip; flowers yellow, April-May.
Arching evergreen shrub; leaf narrow lanceolate-linear (canoe-like), spiny tip, edge revolute (turned under), glossy dk-green top/whitish underside; 3 small spines at leaf axil.
Small alternate leaves that are glossy green on top, grey/silver on bottom, and sharply toothed; branches are stiffly arching and have spines.

Leaves mostly <2 cm and with a notched tip, waxy, strong 'burnt hair' odour when crushed, new growth stems felty; flowers pale yellow in axillary clusters, April-May. Winter ID: leaves turn bronze in cold weather.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Tall perennial with pubescent and angular (4-8 sided) new growth; leaves opposite, lanceolate, green/grey-green on top, white below and pubescent; raceme large, dense, purple, persistant.

Tall/twiggy vase shaped; stems tan, slightly pubescent; leaves opposite, serrate, bronze when young then dark green, elliptic-obovate, flowers small, pale pink, cymes from leaf axils; fruit dark-violet, metallic lustre. Winter ID: buds opposite; leaf scars semi-round; red berries or brown dried berries.
fruitColour: (pink then dark violet when mature and then red by winter)

keyFeatures: Scent of leaves, narrow 'duck's bill' cone, and grayish-green to reddish-brown exfoliating bark
Leaves thick, crenulate, broadly elliptic,dark glossy green; stems glabrous (C. sasanqua has pubescent stems); flowers large, pink, red or white cvs.

Pyramidal growth with a flat top; needles blue-green, 4-sided, sharp tipped, stiff, clustered on short, stout lateral spurs or alternately on longer stems; female cones green then brown, barrel-shaped, 6-10 cm, ripen over 2 years; male cones autumn, < 8 cm, light brown, cylindrical (barrel shaped).

Habit bushy, upright, arching, green, ribbed stems; leaves <4 cm, dark-green, alternate, ovate, entire to slighly crenate, prominent veins; flowers pale-dark blue, terminal/lateral panicles <8 cm long.

Spiraling, open, glowing tree, nodding leader, branch sprays flat and upright; leaves (scale-like) soft, dark green to gold, white X on underside; male cones bright pink at tips of branchlets; female cones like soccer ball and about 1 cm round.
Long, awl-shaped foilage, silvery blue-green in summer and grayish-blue in winter (as plant ages, interior dead brown needles often visible).
Shrub dense, twiggy, spiny, new growth red-purple to glossy dark green; leaves ovate-oblong,finely serrulate, stipules, <3.5 cm; flowers red/pink, April, before leaves.

Round evergreen shrub. Compound-palmate, opposite leaves with 3-5 glossy, oblanceolate leaflets. Leaves have a distinctive pungent, spicy, 'basil' scent when crushed. When held up to light, you can see oil glands in the leaves.
Evergreen vine; leaves leathery, trifoliate; flowers early spring, 4-5 white petal-like sepals.
Upright arching evergreen shrub. Leaves are alternate, elliptic-ovate, gray/green above and silver and pubescent below. Oblong, orange-red fruit persist in winter.

Shrub to 3 m tall; leaves opposite, acuminate tip, ovate; flowers tiny, white, flat corymb-like cymes, late spring; fruit ellipsoid, white/bluish tinge. Winter ID: stems turn bright red (very similar to C. sericea).
Small tree/shrub, curled/twisted branches; leaves obovate, matte surface, wrinkled, doubly toothed; catkins yellow, male, pendulous, April; fruit nut with leafy involucre.

Low growing evergreen ground cover; branches reddish, fast-growing; leaves small, elliptic/obovate, glossy dark green; long slender, flowers white, small, 2-4 flowered cymes, early summer; fruit almost spherical red, persistent.

Large, upright, arching, evergreen shrub; new wood is red; large (for a cotoneaster), alternate, obovate to elliptic stipulate leaves with prominent veins; dark green above, white and tomentose below.

Tree small, round, deciduous tree, multi-stemmed; leaves opposite, ovate, glossy, dark green,typical dogwood look with heavy parallel main veins; flowers small (< 8 mm), yellow, in clusters of 10 to 25 in early spring. Winter ID: fruit dark red, ellipsoid; bark dark brown, exfoliating; buds round, numerous.
Spreading evergreen with very small dark green leaves on thick branches.

Shrub open vase, arching, deciduous;branches delicate zigzag pattern; leaves ovate, emerge bronze and then turn bright green, <6 cm; florets 2 to 4, racemes on leafless shoots, fragrant, pale yellow; fruit 2-beaked capsule.
Large arching, evergreen shrub; leaves long, narrow, willow-like, upper surface dark green with prominent veins which give leaf wrinkled look, lower surface pubescent.

Shrub multi-stem, shoots green in summer; leaves opposite, dark blue-green, heavily veined, major veins off midrib +/- parallel and curved towards apex, margins slightly rippled; leaves turn red in autumn; flowers tiny, white cymes. Winter ID: shoots smooth, shiny, bright yellow-green; buds tiny, 'chicken-feet' claw-look.
Leaves mostly <2 mm wide; flowers open about 2 weeks before those of Dutch corocus.

Leaves alternate, ovate-elliptic, shining green/minute, silvery-brown scales underneath; new growth with brown scales; flowers silvery-white, sweet scent, late fall; fruit silver spotted oval drupe, that may ripen red-orange by April. (E. 'Gilt Edge' is variegated.)
origin: S.E. Asia / Japan / China (likely E. macrophylla of Korea x E. pungens of Japan)

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, glossy above/paler beneath, obovate, serrulate, glittering specks reflect sunlight on lower surface; flowers pink in panicles in the fall.
Shrub 4-angled, corky 'winged' shoots, (alatus means winged); leaves oblanceolate, toothed, dark green, mostly opposite (rarely alternate); fruit capsule, reddish-purple, orange arils.
Large evergreen shrub; leaves alternate, very large, leathery, lustrous dark green, serrate, and palmate with 7-9 very deep lobes.

Grafted with pendulous branches (form is umbrella or mushroom-like); leaves emerge purple in spring, fading to green-purple in summer. Leaves alternate, ovate-elliptic with undulating margin and prominent veins. Winter ID: elliptical buds >1 cm long x 3 mm wide, pointed, spear-like, divergent, brown; bark smooth, silver-grey, with a horizontal pattern (like an elephant's leg).

Tall, narrow, deciduous tree with pendulous branches; leaves emerge dark purple and fade to purple-green in summer. Winter ID: buds >2 cm long x 5 mm wide, pointed, spear-like, divergent, brown; bark smooth, silver-grey, with a horizontal pattern (like an elephant's leg).
Early blooming 'spring bulb' (often when there is still snow); flowers white, nodding, 3 petaled.
Tree stout; branches grey; leaves pinnately compound, 7-11 leaflets, opposite; flowers tiny, purple, April-May; fruit 1 seeded winged samara. Winter ID: large black 'chocolate chip' buds.

Dense, small, evergreen shrub with small, alternate leaves that are dark green, ovate, and glossy, with a mucronate tip but no marginal spines; when looking head on, leaves appear very geometrically arranged; new stems are reddish.
Groundcover deciduous; stems gray-green, prickle-tipped; leaves angular, bright-green in spring,-turning gray-green; flowers yellow, 'pea' shaped in short racemes, May-June;

Shrub multi-stem, branches 45 degrees; leaves obovate, alternate, serrate edge towards apex, oblique/cordate base. Winter ID: flowers fragrant yellow/red, spider-like, Dec.-Mar.; fuzzy reddish stems and buds; clusters of small round flower buds prior to flowering; fruit capsules may be present.

Small, evergreen shrub; leaves smooth, lanceolate, powdery, opposite (each leaf pair is at a right angle to the leaves above and below - very geometric in arrangement - this uniformity of size and arrangment gives it an almost artifical look).

Prostrate evergreen with dense, wiry shoots; small, linear leaves on ridged green stem; bright yellow 'pea-like' flowers in May-June (much flatter growing and more likely to keeps leaves over winter unlike G.lydia).
Leaves cordate, variegated, mid-green with gold/chartreuse centres, white main veins.
Leaves thick, leathery, palmately compound; flowers nodding, white/green/pink/purple flowers, appear in winter.
Leaves scale-like, golden, forming threadlike foliage; lenticels prominent.

Semi-evergreen, spreading ground cover; leaves leathery, opposite, ovate and almost geometric on the stem; flowers to 3-5 cm wide, bright yellow solitary in summer (not as tall as H. 'Hidcote' and H. calycinum has a conspicuous calyx).
Shrub twiggy, red new growth, 1.2 m; leaves ovate-lanceolate, <6 cm, opposite, dark green; flower to 7.5 cm wide, golden yellow petals and orange anthers, June-July.

Large evergreen shrub/tree with dense pyramidal form; leaves are alternate, thick, lustrous dark green, with undulating margins (may be entire or highly spiney), light underside; fruit bright red persists into winter.
Large evergreen shrub/tree with dense pyramidal form; leaves are alternate, thick, lustrous dark green with undulating, spiny silver margins; fruit bright red persists into winter.

Upright arching deciduous vine/shrub; stems square, green; leaves glossy green, leaflets 3 oblong-ovate, flowers bright yellow, salverform, <2 cm, (4-)6 petals. Winter ID: whip-like green ribbed stems, glossy red buds then flowers.
Upright, vase to irregular-shaped juniper; branches have twisted, wind swept look; leaves scale-like (mature) or and awl-like (juvenile and in lower light conditions).

Most are small conical trees; leaves mostly opposite, scale-like, and not prickly, juvenile leaves needle-like, 5-7 mm long, in whorls of three; seed cones berry-like, up to 6 mm long, bluish-purple; male cones on separate plants; bark reddish-brown, scaly or fibrous and stringy.
Leaves elliptic, glossy dark green, alternate (may appear opposite or whorled near shoot tips), smooth margins; flowers cup-shaped, 5-sided with 10 anthers neatly arranged in corolla pockets.

Twiggy, arching, deciduous shrub; leaves are alternate, double serrate, with deep veins; flowers bright yellow in early spring. Winter ID: stems slender, green (yellow-green in winter) and contrast with dark buds.

Branches upright, arching branches; leaves opposite, dark green, broadly ovate/acuminate tip, sparsely toothed, prominent veins, pubescent, <7 cm long; flowers dense, terminal corymbs, pink, bell-shaped, May - June, flower stalks highly pubescent; fruit bristly reddish capsules. Winter ID: exfoliating bark all over (like ninebark; opposite buds (unlike ninebark); capsules persistent, gray-brown .

Shrub arching, thicket forming; leaves alternate, rubbery, lanceolate, dark-green/mottled cream and pink, short red petiole; flowers white, urn-shaped, terminal and auxilliary racemes; leaf buds red, scale-covered, in leaf axils.

Leaf alternate, long petiole, squarish, lobed at tips, truncate apex; flowers with pale-green petals, late May-mid-June, terminal, cup-shaped, solitary; fruit long yellow carpels; valvate, clam-shaped, duck-bill buds.
Flowers are yellow and have a sweet scent; leaves are purplish - dark green. semi-evergreen
petalColour: (Maroon outside and yellowish to white inside.)

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite, about 1 cm long, heart-shaped or ovate (may resemble the Ace of Spades), new growth is burgundy, fading to a red blush on glossy green leaves.

Semi-evergreen; twigs/leaves at 45 degrees off branch; twigs purple; leaves elliptic, glossy dark-green, waxy, sessile, opposite, simple; flowers funnel-shaped, light yellow to creamy-white, 5 lobed, at leaf axils, late spring; fruit berries, violet-purple.

One of the few large, local evergreen flowering trees; leaves thick, glossy, dark green, lower surface with dense, brown pubescence, up to 30 cm long; flowers large (about 15 cm wide), solitary flowers in late spring, most with 9(-12) creamy white, fragrant tepals, Winter ID: woolly, brown pubescence on terminal buds.
Native evergreen shrub; leaves pinnately-compound, lanceolate, 11-21 leaflets with 8-15 spiny teeth each; no undulating margin.

Leaves <20 cm, dark green, obovate; flowers fragrant, 8-20(-35) cm, rose-pale purple outer and pink-white inner tepals (commonly 9), goblet-shaped; fruit a brown aggregate with orange-red seeds. Winter ID: short dense hairs on flower buds.
origin: Garden origin (M. denudata x M. liliiflora)
fruitType: Follicle, Aborted (hybrids) or absent, Aggregate fruit

keyFeatures: Tree multi-stem, compact, bushy; smaller in habit/size/leaves, branches lower than other magnolias; leaves <10 cm, buds densely silver pubescent; flowers star-like, <13 cm across, most with 25-30 strap-like, white tepals, first magnolia to flower (cv. Royal Star has slightly pinkish flower buds which open up to 2 weeks later than species).
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
fruitColour: (Fruit aggregate pink-red before turning brown as the follicles open to reveal their single orange-red seed)

keyFeatures: Low, spreading conifer similar to some junipers, but without distinctive juniper scent; leaves small scale-like, bronze colour in winter.
Spring bulb; flowers mostly bright yellow/cream; leaves green, strap-like.

Upright, deciduous shrub; leaves oblong to oblanceolate, glossy, dark green/softly hairy, gray-green beneath, held upright, cucumber-like smell; male and female flowers on separate plants, female flowers yellowish to greenish-white, petals white, bell-shaped, scented, hanging from leaf axils, 5-10 per raceme; drupe black, edibile; bark bitter.
fruitColour: (Turning from yellow to pink to very dark blue)

keyFeatures: Leaves 4-8 cm long, glossy dark-green, leathery, slightly serrated, ovate; flowers fragrant, white, tubular with 4 spreading petal lobes, mid-spring; fruit rare.
origin: Garden origin (Osmanthus delavayi X O. decorus)

keyFeatures: Evergreen, upright groundcover, prostrate stems; leaves obovate,leathery, glossy dark green, alternate, coarsely uniform teeth toward the tips; flowers small, white, tubular, spikes.
Large, evergreen shrub with smooth, glossy, thick, mostly obovate leaves with finely toothed margins; new growth is red, maturing to dark glossy green; it will almost always get leaf spots.
origin: Garden origin (P. serratifolia x P. glabra)

keyFeatures: 'Bird's Nest' form: spreading, flat topped with branches that are layered with a depression in the center; needles prickly, short pegs remain when pulled off.
Spreading pine, locally most are just 1-3 m tall; needles 2 per fascicle, 2.5-7 cm long, rough protuberances after abscission.

Tree very narrow pyramidal form, slender trunk; needles <2cm, dark green/2 stomatal bands underneath, flattened on sides, short pegs, sharply pointed, flowers 3-6cm, purple, female cones <5cm, blue black when young, cinnamon brown with age.

Form prostrate or weeping (trained to shape), orange bark on new growth; needles sharp, short pegs when pulled off; female cones cylindrical, scales persistent, terminal shoots, erect when in flower/pendent later; male cones ovoid, spring, yellow to red/purple (2-3 cm).

Needles flattened, sharply pointed, bluish-green, 2 thin white bands underneath, whorled singly around shoots; male cones ovoid, yellow-red-purple, <3 cm; female cones cylindrical, green to pale brown, <10 cm; bark purple-brown when young.
Irregular habit, bark dark purple-gray, yellow-brown shoots; needles 2 per fascicle, 7-13 cm long; buds grey-brown, covered in silky white hairs.
Tree tall, narrowly columnar; bark fissured, braided to diamond pattern; leaves deltoid, glossy, dark green, <10 cm long, serrated margins; male catkins only, red.
Columnar; leaves ovate, margins crenate, green/whitish underneath. Winter ID: new bark chocolate brown, old bark light brown, rough collars of dark nubs around trunk, very prominant bark ridge scar.
Leaves about 8 cm long, alternate, glossy dark green with undulating serrated margin (red petiole and red stems distinguish it from P. laurocerasus).
Leaves obovate, wrinkled, forming a rosette, elongate after flowering, up to 20 cm long; flowers up to 4 cm wide, arising in central clusters on 5-15 cm long peduncles.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: (Often bicolor or tricolored; species in pale yellow)

keyFeatures: Low, evergreen shrub, up to 1.3 m tall, horizontal branching; leaves alternate, most elliptic and about 10 cm long x 4 cm wide, held flat and perpendicular to the stem (compared to Otto Luyken' where the leaves point upwards).
Dwarf cultivar (most <1 m tall and wide after 10 years); leaves elliptic, bronze-green in winter, 2-3 cm long x 1-1.5 cm wide; flowers lavender-blue, about 4 cm wide.

New stems reddish; leaves alternate, bluish-green, turning rich red in autumn, pinnately compound (with 11-31 opposite leaflets); flowers yellow-green, conical panicles; fruit red, spherical panicles, persistent. Winter ID: stems smooth, stout; scars encircle leaf buds.
Compact, evergreen azalea covered in clusters of scarlet red flowers in spring; leaves small, dark green, alternate (but appear whorled at the terminal ends), obovate with flat sparse hairs.
Leaves small, elliptic, leathery, dark green/rough rusty-scaly underside, aromatic when crushed; flower lavender-pink in spring. Winter ID: leaves purple-bronze.
origin: Garden origin (R. carolinianum x R. dauricum var. sempervirens)

keyFeatures: Dense, compact form. Small (<1 cm) leaves are dark, oblong, convex and have white, crystal-like dots (scales).
Leaves are medium sized, green, very hairy (coarse white fur) and recurved. White flowers have black stamens.

Stems reddish, velvety; leaves alternate, pinnately compound (with 13 to 27 leaflets), hairy rachis; flowers yellow-green panicles; fruit hairy, crimson, aggregate drupes, thick terminal clusters, persistent. Winter ID: leaf scar encircles fuzzy bud; twigs pubescent; persistent fruit.
Leaves are oblong, smooth, and glossy with an obvious mucrinate tip; flowers creamy white.

Large deciduous shrub; alternate leaves with 3-5 lobes, dark green wrinkled above, and whitish tomentose below; leaf has a spicy scent when crushed; pendulous raceme of pink-red flowers in spring (R. 'Alba' with white flowers is also popular).

Leaves pinnately compound, spiney stipules; golden-yellow (cv. Frisia) or bronze-green (cv. Purple Robe); florets in racemes, wisteria-like, white or violet-purple, fragrant; legumes smooth, flat, purple-brown.
Very rugose (wrinkled) dark green leaves with 3-5 lobes.
Usually grafted into small tree with stiffly pendulous branches; leaves alternate, elliptic, toothed, dark green above, grey-green below.

Shrub dwarf, spreading evergreen; leaves dark green, waxy, alternate (rarely opposite); unpleasant leaf odor when crushed; flowers pink-tinged white, in auxiliary clusters with imbricate bracts; fruit blue-black drupe.
petalColour: (Female flowers white or slightly pink; male flowers with pink anthers.)

keyFeatures: Leaves of 2 types - small, scale-like, spirally arranged on twigs/crowded at tips, and long, linear, flattened, in whorls of 20-30 (like umbrella spokes), dark green above with 2 white stomatal bands below; cones female, single, ovoid (5-8 cm); cones male, clusters (3-8 mm).
Habit irregular ('Dr. Seuss-like'), narrow, pendent side branches; leaves awl-shaped, gray-green, point forward on shoots.
Bark fibrous, red-brown; leaves flat, needle-like, 2 ranked, dark green with 2 broad white stomatal bands below.
Small to medium evergreen shrub; leaves obovate, spicy scent; flowers reddish in bud then creamy white in mid-spring. Winter ID: persistent red fruit on female plants.
Leaves scale-like, overlapping, form flattened, rope-like shoots, green/thick white stomatal bands underneath, similar to western red cedar, only thicker and much slower glowing.
Tall, narrow, upright, evergreen, vertical sprays, similar to T. occidentalis 'Smaragd'; leaves scale-like, gray-green.
origin: U.S. - northeast (Species in Eastern North America)

keyFeatures: Identical to T. plicata except foliage has yellow or white stripes (zebra-like).

Needles flat, linear, dark green, on slender stocks, shortest of the hemlocks (<15 mm long); female cones on short stalk and also small (<2 cm long). Seedling ID: short flat needles with two parallel stomatal bands on lower surface; needles on stem about 5 mm longer than on older plants (up to 2 cm long).
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves <3 cm, alternate, ovate-lanceolate serrate, glossy dark green, dense on reddish stems, leathery; flowers urn-shaped, pinkish-white, late spring, nodding racemes; fruit edible, spherical, glossy black berries.

Leaves to 15 cm long with 3 main veins, slightly toothed towards apex; flowers <3mm, white, late spring, tubular, flattened, terminal umbel-like cymes; fruit ovoid, metallic blue (appears if a male plant is near by).

Large evergreen shrub; leaves oblong-lanceolate, wavy margin, opposite, dark green/grey-brown underneath, rugose top/ tomentose underneath; flowers <20 cm., tubular, creamy-white, dense, domed, terminal umbel-like cymes; fruit ovoid, red, ripening to glossy black.
fruitColour: (Maturing to glossy black at varying rates if mild enough fall.)

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, ovate to elliptic, up to 4 cm long; flowers 5-10 cm wide, flattened, face-like, available in many colours and most petals have more than one colour or shading.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves light green scales in loose open sprays; cones about 1 cm round.
origin: Garden origin (Cupressus nootkatensis x C. macrocarpa)

keyFeatures: Locally evergreen in mild winters; layered habit with fishbone branching pattern; leaves purple-red in fall. Winter ID: fruit bright red berries, 1 cm, above foliage, persistent.
Fronds are fan-shaped, lobed, and triangular; stalks are wiry and reddish-brown; sori marginal with a false indusium formed from the reflexed leaf margin.
Vase-shaped; leaves in a basal rosette, appearing spiraled on older plants but with no discernible stem, grey-green with silverish-grey bands; flowers in a rosette of pink bracts.
Leaves are thick and glossy; stems trail downward; both leaves and stems are covered in fine hairs; flowers long, tubular, red, in terminal clusters.
Leaves mostly elliptic, dark green, glossy, 14-32 cm long, and variously variegated (cvs.); florets tiny, on spadix that may mostly remained covered by the spadix.
Leaves basal, lance-shaped, up to 25 cm long with white threads and a terminal spine.
Leaves are succulent, glossy, and dark green with prominent white-green veins; leaf margin is slightly serrated, and the shape is arrow-like.
Leaves with cordate bases (unlike peace lily); spathe is waxy and heart-shaped; spadix is fleshy and smooth (flower not smooth - protrudes from the spadix).
Foliage is dark green, waxy, and has very striking white veins. Leaves are ovate and opposite.
Conical evergreen conifer with regular whorls of branches; leaves dark green, awl-like on fan-like branchlets.
Foliage is needle-like and resembles a fern; tiny thorns present.
Leaves are needle-like, scaly, and resemble the appearance of a fern; thorns ridge along the side of the stems.
Multi-stemmed with bamboo-like joints (ringed nodes); leaves asymmetrical; flowers pendulous.
Grown for its interesting leaf patterns which can vary in appearance from spotted, streaked, bordered and splotched depending on the cultivar.
Annual to 30 cm; leaves thick, pubescent, undulating, doubly-serrate, deltoid; petiole thick, pinkish, comes off one side; flowers male or female flowers in fiery colours.

scientificName: Capsicum annuum var. annuum Grossum Group
keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, simple, ovate, entire, with blades up to 20 cm long; fruit a large hollow berry that's green, red, yellow, or orange (brown, white, and purple cvs. also exist).
Attractive indoor foliage plant (large evergreen tree in nature); leaves pinnately compound with 11-15 elliptic leaflets that are mostly 10-15 x 3-5 cm.
Trailing plant; flowers are small (<4 cm wide), petals completely fused, trumpet-like, and slightly bilaterally symmetrical (unlike most petunias).
Foliage is grass-like, tapered and recurved; produces small young plants from nodes that hang from the parent plant.
Frond-like foliage, dark green and pinnate with leaflets in clusters of 22 to 40; leaf scars visible along the trunk of stem (usually many stem arising from soil).
Indoor vine; leaves trifoliate.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves glossy, elliptic, dark green leaves; flowers fragrant, white, 5-lobes; fruit red drupe.
Vine rough, hairy, trailing with tendrils; flowers yellow, rotate, solitary; male flowers clusters, on spurs; fruit clustered, oblong, prickly, edible.
Leaves arching, pinnately compound, palm-like, leaflets dark, evergreen, linear.
Fronds twice or thrice compound and arising from a thick, fuzzy runner-like rhizome.
Leaves of indoor plants are mostly glossy green, commonly striped, 20-90 cm x 3-9 cm depending on the cultivar.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves spirally arranged in whorls, sheathing stem, narrowly elliptic, most 10-15 cm long x 4 cm wide.
Stems green and fleshy (unlike true bamboos), nodes protruding; leaves alternate, sheathing, lance-shaped 15-25 cm long and 1.5-4 cm wide at the base.
Leaves dark green with cream spots, opposite or in whorls of three, apex pointed, elliptic, 8 cm long x 4 cm wide, emerge from tightly rolled cones.
Stems succulent; leaves reduced to gray spines.
Leaves obovate, <6 cm long; cyathia with small greenish florets and petal-like red or yellow bracts.

Leaves leathery, usually glaucous, margins entire, tend to hang in many speciesor may be sessile; flower receptacle cup-shaped with numerous stamens around the rim; fruit with many tiny seeds and surrounded by a woody, cup-shaped accessory tissue from the receptacle.
Leaves thick, triangular, inside margins with upright teeth in opposite pairs that looks like an animal mouth.
Succulent, ribbed barrel-shaped stems.
Leaves alternate, linear, entire, mostly up to 20 cm long x 3 cm wide.
Leaves very large, thick, elliptic; new leaf growth green, darkens to purple-green as it matures; inflorescence is a spadix surrounded by a single large bract.
Leaves alternate, sessile and clasping stem, obovate, prominent yellowish veins, entire wavy margins, over 15 cm long when mature.
A fast-growing, climbing vine with adhesive aerial rootlets; leaves ovate, bases cordate or uneven, up to 2.5 cm long.
Stems fuzzy; leaves lush green leaves with white to deep pink veins.
petalColour: may have yellow throat and pink streaks; less commonly all yellow)

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite, ovate-elliptic, thick, glossy, dark green, up to 10 cm long; flowers white, highly fragrant, most 4-6 cm wide.
Leaves toothed, ovate-elliptic, are metallic silvery gray-green above and purple beneath, up to 5 cm wide x 11 cm long (incl. 4 cm long petiole), blades commonly puckered.
Leaves opposite, mostly elliptic, glossy, dark green (variegated cvs.), up to 10 cm long; florets wax-like with a star-shaped crown in its center, fragrant, 10-30 per umbels (infrequently formed).
Red stems and oval purple-red leaves, up to 8 cm long, with notched tips and light red veins (requires full sun exposure for best foliage colour); florets very small, in panicles up to 50 cm long.
Foliage is green or red with heavily spotted white, pink or red dots between leaf veins. Leaves opposite, ovate, and up to 7cm long.
Leaves sessile and densely covered in fuzzy felt.

Compared to Oriental lilies, Asiatic lilies (Division I) tend to have narrower leaves (more lanceolate), more numerous but smaller flowers that are upright or outward facing, and more mildly scented or unscented.
Leaves pinnately compound, leaflets fuzzy, irregularly lobed and sized; florets yellow, in raceme-like cymes; berries usually red.
Leaves palmately compound, hairy, dark green but undersides or stems purplish.
inflorescence: Small heads arranged in a corymb

keyFeatures: The largest herbaceous perennial plant; leaves elliptic, often over 1 m long x 30 cm wide (even larger in tropics), major veins running parallel off the midrib.
Fronds sword-shaped fronds, pinnae deltoid, and shallow toothed. Arching habit with weeping form.

Leaves basal, linear, leathery, shiny, margins entire, apex tip with spine, up to 30 cm long x 6 cm wide; florets clustered, violet, forming in the centre area formed between the pink-red "blushing leaves".
Leaves deeply veined and puckered, heart-shaped, green to red or bronze.
Leaves rounded, heart- to kidney-shaped, irregularly toothed and crinkled margins; florets in simple umbels.
Leaves puckered, grey-green with sunken dark green veins.
Leaf blades spatulate to broadly ovate or broadly elliptic, commonly variegated yellow and green (e.g. P. 'Variegata' or P. 'Green & Gold') or also with red margins (P. 'Tricolor').
Trailing plant; leaves 5-lobed leaf (“Peltatum”); florets in a 4 cm wide umbel.
Leaves alternate, often pinnately lobed or deeply cut, mostly oval, spear-shaped, usually heart-shaped when young and becoming large.
Leaves elliptic to obovate, toothed, dark green with four rows of upraised silver patches on either side of the main veins, up to 7 cm long.
Leaves opposite, rounded, thick, scalloped towards the apex, bright green, mostly <1 cm long.

Leaves mostly ovate and 3-6 cm long when mature, margins with rounded teeth, venation palmate with three main veins running the length of the leaf; petioles short, stout, yellow-green, sometimes with a reddish flush, and flattened to slightly con-cave above; stipules light green.
An evergreen epiphytic fern; fertile fronds leathery and resemble the forked antlers of a stag.
Leaves, linear, leathery, dark green, shiny, with nice fragrance when broken, about 0.6 cm x 10 cm long.
Fronds arching, pale green fronds, each with up to five simple or fork-tipped pinnae; spores may form along a downward rolled margin.

Stolons long and thin; leaves basal, rounded, to 10 cm wide and rising about 20 cm tall, dark green with silver veining on top and pink-red undersides; florets bilaterally symmetrical - two large lower petals and 3 smaller upper petals, on panicles well above foliage.
Leaves leathery, linear, stiffly vertical, appearing to directly arise from the soil. Snake-skin like pattern, sometimes with yellow margins.
Leaflets toothed, up to 8 cm long and 1.5 cm wide (potted plants only have juvenile leaves and are unlikely to flower).
Low growing, highly branched, moss-like evergreen; tiny "leaves" in four rows.
Specialized leaves are like a string of dull-green pearls that resemble peas in size and shape. Habit is trailing or weeping.
petalColour: (White with red stamens and yellow anthers.)

keyFeatures: Plant erect, shrubby, annual in zone 7; leaves gray-green, simple, <20 cm.long; flowers violet, drooping, late spring; fruit white-purple, 8-37 cm. long, summer.
Stem short; leaves oblong, wrinkled, wavy and scalloped margins, up to 8 cm wide x 25 cm long; flowers with petals fused at bases, up to 6 cm wide.
origin: Garden origin (South Africa; parentage involving S. rexii)

keyFeatures: Leaves basal, large, arrow-head shaped, veins white .
Flowers bilabiate and trumpet shaped with 2 fused pistils.
Stems trailing with jointed appearance; leaves ovate, appearing sessile due to sheathing petioles; flowers about 5 mm wide with white petals and hairy anther filaments.
Leaves with parallel venation, ovate to 6 cm long, narrowing toward base and then expanding to a broad sheath around the stem.
Leaves spirally arranged, linear-lanceolate, dark green with purple undersides, up to 30 cm long; florets white in comes with purplish, boat-shaped bracts ("Moses-in-a-basket").
Leaves basal (arising from bulb that is usually 10-20 cm below ground), linear to braodly oval; flowers usually solitary and cup-shaped with 6 tepals available in every colour except blue.
Florets with five petals each with 2 lobes, arranged in a dome-shaped cyme.
Leaves to 8 cm long, white (glaucous), feels powdery, and are toothed only at the tip; heads small with yellow disk florets only.

Thistle-like in appearance; stems bluish; leaves bluish tinge with lower leaves being heart-shaped and spiny-toothed and upper leaves being palmately-divided; flower heads egg-shaped, bluish, to 5 cm long, surrounded by a by 12-18 attractive, finely-divided, blue-gray bracts that extend from the base of each flower head.
Leaves mostly oblanceolate with variable lobbing or teeth, up to 25 cm long; spikes are head-like, violet to blue to pinkish-purple.
Leaves heart-shaped; florets with 6 white tepals, on raceme with leaf-like bract on peduncle; fruit red, berries.
Leaves thin white midrib, with variegated medium-green and dark-green stripes.
Spreading shrub to 1 m; leaves are opposite, ovate to lanceolate, serrated; inflorescence to 15 cm long raceme of creamy-yellow tubular, red or white, pendulous florets.
Stiff upright stems; Leaves are dark green and a 20cm; Inflorescence is a yellow raceme that looks like a shooting star.
Upright, thicket forming bush with blue green bamboo-like shoots; leaves up to 18 cm long, ovate; florets white in pendulous racemes with showy dark red bracts.
Shrub spreading/trailing over wall, (upright growth in tiny location); leaves mostly awl-like/pointy (boat-shaped needle part), in whorles of 3 with very short internodes.
Mounded; leaves dark green/lighter bluish-green beneath; male cones absent; fruit-like female cones each with a fleshy red aril and a single green seed.
Leaves are variegated with creamy-yellow horizontal bands, thin white midrib.
Leaves silver, powdery with very powerful unpleasant smell when crushed.
origin: Garden origin (A. absinthium x A. arborescens)

keyFeatures: Leaves lobed, bases triangular; flowers pink to purple, in terminal clusters forming a flat-topped inflorescence.

Leaves lance-shaped, hairy, entire to lobed, 5-15 cm long; heads yellow, daisy-like with eight mostly yellow rays which are toothed at the tips, disk florets yellow, up to 5 cm wide; achenes resemble ticks.
petalColour: (Not all cultivars have ray florets that are part red-brown.near center of inflorescence.)

keyFeatures: Very dense ground cover; leaves basal and then opposite on runners, spatulate, dark green to purple.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves very narrow (<1 mm wide), upright, bright green; spikelets with very long white hairs.
Leaves alternate, elliptic to lanceolate, sparsely toothed, up to 10 cm long, flower heads about 3 cm wide with about 25 white to pale violet ray florets and yellow disc florets.
Floppy herbaceous perennial; basal leaves ovate and resemble spinach; opposite leaves on floral stalk sessile and dentate; florets white, panicle tall.
Leaves like Canadian flag, fine white hairs on base of underside. Winter ID: buds brown, 3 mm, pointed, adpressed, terminal bud.
Leaves are 3-lobed mid green, almost compound with irregularly serrate margins; flower pendulous with four petal-like sepals, cupped, yellow, June-July; fruit is a white, wispy ball.
Leaves to 15 cm long with 5 lobes, lower surface silvery.
Form very narrow; leaf three major lobes, mid-green, lighter underside, 10 cm petiole. Winter ID: buds opposite, red on brownish twigs; bark grayish.
Leaves alternate, dark, very rugose (similar to viburnum), with a strong scent when crushed; florets in a large, dense, purple/white/blue corymb.
petalColour: (Heliotropium arborescens 'Marine' is the cultivar shown in the images. 'Fragrant Delight' is deep lavender.)

keyFeatures: Leaves linear, entire or more commonly deeply divided (pinnatisect), pubescent (softly downy), and gray-green.
Trailing plant with very soft, lime or gray-green leaves that are covered in very fine silvery fur.
inflorescence: Small heads arranged in a corymb

keyFeatures: Trailing, annual vine often used in containers; leaves 12 cm, cordate or palmate with 3-5 lobes and in a huge range of colours (gold, lime-green, purple, etc).

Perennial to 1.5 m; leaves 30 cm x 1.5 cm, venation parallel, purple-black, with a green midrib below and a catching edge; spikelets arranged in a dense, purple spike (green leafed, white flowered cultivars also available).
Succulent, tubular leaves have a round tip and hairs at the base.
Leaves opposite, tomentose, margins entire to sparsely toothed, lower ones spatulate and others more lanceolate; flower 1-sided with 5 petals arranged like a fan from a tubular base.
Leaves lanceolate to obovate, irregular and entire margins; flower heads about 10 cm wide, variety of colours, concave or curling petals, darker ray florets.

scientificName: Plectranthus scutellarioides hybrids & cvs. ( syn. Solenostemon )
keyFeatures: Opposite leaves are crenate, puckered, and come in a large range of colours and shapes; stem squarish in c.s. (Lamiaceae)
Leaves light green, obovate/dentate, opposite, pubescent stems, trailing; flowers salver-shaped, white petals, yellow throat.
Sagittate leaves, wings on petiole; flowers in light, warm colours, 5 flat petals with black center.
petalColour: (Thunbergia alata ‘Lemon Star’ is shown in the flower images
Thunbergia alata ‘Orange Eye’ has an orange flower. Thunbergia 'Alba' (not shown) has white flowers.)

keyFeatures: Coarse-textured tree; leaves up to 15 cm long, with 4 lobes and look like cartoon ghosts or whale fins. Winter ID: bark is highly netted with vertical stripes.
Leaves deep purple (crimsons-oranges in fall), cupped like ladle on long (20 cm) petiole, petiole with milky sap. Winter ID: buds dark red to almost black; upward curled branches (fastigiate).
Round-form oak tree with upward, ascending branches; leaves 15-20 cm long, sinuses deep, rounded.
Leaves ovate to lanceolate, apex narrow, margins strongly serrated with fine points.
Twiggy, horizontal oak tree; leaves alternate, about 8 cm long, lanceolate, undulating that have a pin on the tip and whorled at the terminal ends.
Stems 2 cm reddish thorns, alternate, deciduous, bi-serrate; flowers white, saucer-shape, May-June; berry-like pomes, black when ripe. Winter ID: thorns, persistent fruit.
Leaves shiny, leathery, finely serrated, fall colour orange-red-purple; flower tiny white, June. Winter ID: fruit purple-black pome, persistent into December.
Clump-forming; leaves basal, up to 1.2 m wide and 2 m long to almost round, very rough and heavily veined with thick, spiny petioles around a thick flower 'spike'.
Aquatic plant; leaves to 3 m long, linear to sword-like, thick, fibrous, and spongy; fruit dense, to 20 cm, brown (bullrush).
Leaves with 3-5 silvery-veined leaflets turning red in fall; berries dark blue.
Dense, flat-topped, fastigiate branching; needles 2 per fascicle, <12 cm long; bark orange, exfoliating.

Needles contorted, irregular shape; leaves 5 per fascicle, <4 cm long, dark blue-green, glaucous underneath; cones with each scale with a bristle-like spine 4-8 mm long. Winter ID: persistent (10-17 years) green needles; buds terminal, loose outer scales, adpressed inner scales, reddish-brown, sticky.
Clump forming bamboo; stems olive coloured; leaves point down on twiggy whorls at nodes.
Stems clump forming, green/turning golden yellow, round with a flat groove on one side, tortoise-shell internodes at base of cane; leaves upright, <8 cm long.
Clump forming; stems green/turn black/purple, round with flat groove on one side; leaves upright, <8cm long, lance-shaped, dark green, feathery.
Leaves round (5 cm), 11-13 fan-like lobes golden yellow, double serrated.

Flat-topped tree with horizontal branching; lenticels prominent on newer growth; leaves to 15 cm, sharp-pointed (accuminate), margins double-serrate, 2(-4) glands on each petiole; flowers white and emerging before leaves expand.
origin: Garden origin (Sato-zakura hybrid derived likely from P. serrulata)

keyFeatures: Leaves ovate, opposite, dark green/glaucous underside, reddish stem. Winter ID: fruit white/pink round berry, persistent.
fruitColour: (most commonly purplish-red with minute pale dots; some cvs. white)

keyFeatures: Long, leggy, arching bush; leaves are compound with 3 leaflets arranged in a 'T'; flowers pea-like, purple-pink.
Low, spreading groundcover; leaves very small, pubescent, elliptic with rounded tips; flowers small with 5 deep blue, petals.
Leaves to 30 cm long, variegation along just one margin, thickness greater on one side.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Frond tips tilt sideways; sori pink-red and then orange-black and in a double row.
Spreading groundcover; leaves are med-green, narrowly-lanceolate, whorled (often 8) at light green stem nodes; flowers tiny, white, scented, late May-June.
Spreading groundcover; leaves are large, orbicular, med-green, lobed (often 7), dentate margins.
