Leaves are felty, silvery/gray/green and are basal and are on the floral stalk; flowers rise above, bright magenta; fruit crown-like, brown.

Leaves basal, fern-like, deeply lobed; disk florets tiny, about 10 per head, ray floret with relatively large corollas, many small heads make a much larger corymb-like inflorescence which overall is cymose. (A. 'Moonshine' has hairy leaves, lightly scented bright yellow flower heads; A 'Apple Blossom' has unscented deep pink to white flower heads, inflorescence nearly flat-topped).
Leaf petiole is black and leaflets have a smooth margin on one side; sori marginal with a false indusium formed from the reflexed leaf margin.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves fuzzy, round, palmate with 'v' shaped lobes and a heavily serrated margin.
Leaf is pinnately compound with 3-5 very serrated leaflets; flower panicle is pinkish-purple.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves mid-green, alternate, sessile; flower heads with linear purple ray florets and compact yellow disc florets.
Clump-forming herbaceous perennial; leaves basal, palmately lobed leaves; florets small and in compact umbels surrounded by a rosette of showy bracts on branched, erect, wiry peduncles.

Fronds deciduous, thrice pinnate, elliptical, grooved rachis, up to 90 cm long, stipe may have long, brown papery scales near the base, arising from a clump (not along a rhizome); sori dot-like on undersides of pinnae, up to 6 per pinnule, indusium light brown, kidney-shaped.

Leaves heart-shaped with interveinal white variegation (B. 'Jack Frost'), or veins and margin are dark green with a wide band of white variegation on the margin (B. 'Dawson’s White'), or leaves of species uniform light green.
evergreen; leaves leathery, dark green/broad creamy-yellow stripe down the center; flower spikes, brown, mid-late spring;
Leaves variegated with a wedge, to 90 cm high; fruit typical of sedges (2 mm by 1.2 cm, brown, like tight wheat-like).
Stems trailing, reddish brown; leaves opposite, margins spinose, dark green, glossy.

Vase-shaped fern with short creeping rhizomes 45-70(-90) cm tall and as wide; fronds stiff, leathery, upright, once pinnate, with 20-30 pairs of narrow lance-shaped pinnae; stipe and rachis with black hair-like scales.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Fronds green, lacy to 60 (-90) cm long, bipinnate at the base, pinnate toward the apex; sori alonge cental vain on the underside of the pinnae.
Wavy, lime-green frond has pinnae that twist skyward and curl at the tips (reminiscent of curled parsely); sori only toward the tip of the frond, light brown.
Leaves highly wrinkled, compound, stipulate.
Leaves very puckered, blue/green with creamy-yellow margins, about 40 cm long; flower white, July.
Leaves 40-50 cm long, lime-green with strong veins (fan-like).
Leaves opposite, obovate, to 2 cm long, trailing along ground.
Fern with 50 cm pale soft fronds with pinnae that resemble an ostrich feather.
Fronds erect, pinnately-compound, yellowish-green, up to 1.2 m long with cinnamon colored fibers found near the bases; spore-bearing fronds emerge early spring and soon turn brown.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Large shade-loving fern; fronds about 1 m tall, mid green, openly odd-pinnate.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Varied leaves/flowers; leaves opposite or whorled; flowers tubular, funnel-shaped, racemes/panicles, linear to lanceolate, small/large.
Leaves are dusty green, deeply-lobed in opposite clusters; Inflorescence is a loose panicle of purple spikes that rise up like building spires.

Low-growing prostrate perennial plant forming a thick, dense mat, stems < 10 cm long; leaves opposite, slender subulate (awl-shaped), to 1 cm long; flowers solitary in Irish moss or florets in cymes as in Scotch moss, 4–5 mm wide, five white petals as long as the green sepals; capsules 2.5–3 mm long, seeds triangular shaped, 0.4–0.5 mm, brown and smooth.

Leaves are opposite clusters of 8cm puckered leaves, creamy variegation on the margins with a medium-green inside; florets 0.5cm wide with two larger petal lobes on the top and looking a bit like an open mouth.
Leaves small, narrow; flowers bisexual; fruit on all plants, oval-shaped (compared to S. japonica).
Blue-green pinnately compound leaves. Florets in white corymb that becomes a flush of bright pink berries (< 1cm round) that eventually fade but stay on most of winter.
Bark is papery, peeling, has beige horizontal lenticels, and is tints of cream/tan/pink/red/silver.
Leaves narrow, toothed and opposite on a reddish stem; flower open, spikey and blue.
Leaves ovate 3-8 cm long, rounded toothed, very strong odour when crushed; florets to 1 cm wide, blue-violet (some white cvs.).
origin: Garden origin ( N. racemosa x N. nepetella)

keyFeatures: Leaves linear, entire, silverish; flowers in a tight spike-like verticillaster with a flush of purple petals out of the top.

Fronds not divided into pinnae, up to 60 cm long x 6 cm wide, margins mostly entire and undulate (except for cultivars with lobed or lacerate margins which may be wider); sori in (centipede-like rows that radiate from the "midrib".

Tufted plant; leaves opposite, ovate with dentate to ciliate margins, glandular hairs, to 1-2(-4) cm long, strongly scented; flowers densely arranged in verticillasters, white to pink and up to 3 mm wide.
Tall stalks; leaves are opposite, ovate; florets with 5 petals; inflorescence panicle-like (thyrse).
Fronds shiny, bipinnate, dark green, up to 60 cm long; pinnae finely divided and overlapping; crosiers flip over backwards as the newly emerging fronds expand to form "tassels".
Tall aster (3m); Flowers heads are 10cm with yellow ray florets and a cone of darker disk florets.
Stems yellow-green; leaves opposite, grey-green; flower sepals and petals creamy-pink.
petalColour: (both sepals and petals are pale shell pink)

keyFeatures: Leaves ovate, opposite, clusters, purple-red stems; flower sepals scarlet tube, deep purple corolla.
Leaves opposite, sessile, oval to lanceolate, up to 10 cm long, gray-green; florets cymose, in dense terminal clusters above foliage. fruit dandelion-like.
Leaves iris-like; flowers orange or yellow, floppy, paired on raised green stem.
Leaves basal, cordate, copper on top, purple on the bottom, blades up to 25 cm long and petioles even longer; heads yellow, up to 6 cm wide.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Stems square in c.s.; leaves opposite, serrated, petioles red, scented like bergamot orange; inflorescence a dense globular, terminal verticillaster (head-like with some cvs. superficially like coneflower), outer florets 3-4 cm long.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: pink and dark red cvs. exist)

keyFeatures: Leaves dark green, ovate to lanceolate, heavily veined.
Leaves ovate (almost triangular), purple or have green margins with dark purple center with a lighter halo around it; stems purple with sheathed swollen nodes.
Leaves resemble horse chestnut with seven crinkled, coarsely-toothed, dark green leaflets; panicles resemble astilbe, florets creamy white (sometimes light pink), June to August.
Leaves are erect, basal, narrow, sword-shaped, about 40 cm long; flowers lily-like with 6 tepals but only 3 stamens, most cvs. red or pink, about 6 cm wide.
Leaves compound, pinnate, to 50 cm long; leaflets ovate and have 2 small asymmetrical lobes at the base. Winter ID: leaf scar is larger than bud, bud is small and round.

Branches arching, mound forming habit; leaves whorled, sometimes of differing sizes, margins spiny; nodes with long, three-pointed, spiny stipule with each point to 2.5 cm long (B. julianae has even longer spines).
Dense groundcover to 2 cm high; leaves tiny, elliptic, margins ciliate, gray-green; stems reddish-purple.
Leaves are alternate and fuzzy on top and the petiole is red at the base; florets in a drooping white raceme (curves like a goose's neck).

Shrub or small tree up to 9 m tall; Messy, multi-stemmed, deciduous tree; leaves, obovate to oblanceolate, 4-12 cm long, thick, hairless green on the top and hairy silver on the bottom, petioles 5-10 mm long; flower catkins 2-6 mm long, pussy willow-like; capsules 7-9 mm long. Winter ID: grey bark with greenish to reddish-brown twigs. (Modified from E-Flora BC and Trees and Shrubs of BC.)
Leaves shiny, dark green, blades up to 40 cm long and 25 cm wide with a long petiole; florets up to 5 cm long with purple "helmet", on a cylindrical spike 30-40 cm long.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Basal clump; leaves with long petioles and 3 irregularly ovate leaflets with serrated margins and acute tips; flowers white or pink,slightly cupped, to 8 cm wide, multiple stamens and pistils, most with many tepals, Aug-Oct, scented.
origin: Garden origin (Anemone hupehensis var. japonica x Anemone vitifolia )
fruitType: Aborted (hybrids) or absent, Achene, Aggregate fruit

keyFeatures: Leaves deeply incised with many rounded lobes, pale-green with grayish downy hairs on both surfaces, up to 8 cm long; flower heads yellow, <1 cm wide, many per flowering stalk, July-August.
Dark green frond is more dissected (pinnae are like mini fronds) and has a double row of tan sori that look like tiny spiders.

Leaves alternate and spirally arranged, most lanceolate, sessile, and less than 2 cm wide x 12 cm long; florets in racemes to 60 cm long; fruit capsules to 5 cm long, developing at the bottom of the raceme as florets continue to form near tip.
Leaves irregularly compounded, palmate, fragrant; flowers double mauve-pink. Winter ID: remnant achene + calyx.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Claridge Druce has 3 cm flower has dark purple veins on the throat, leaves are larger, darker, and more round than 'Phoebe Noble' which has 3 cm bubblegum pink flowers, and very pubescent leaves.
Plant is 2m high but very floppy; flower has a fan-like arrangement of ray florets around a red and/or yellow disk florets.
Leaves linear, bluish green, 15-30 cm long x 1-2 mm wide; spikelets in panicles 35–55 cm high, June-July.
Stems square in c.s., woody at base; leaves opposite, elliptic to ovate, up to 4 cm long, aromatic; flowers rose-violet with reddish-purple bracts.
Fronds bi-pinnate, 30-120 cm long, pinnae ovate, margins serrate to spiny, rachis covered in hairy, brown scales.
Leaves dark green, very rugose, margin scalloped, petiole reddish; florets bright yellow on a tall raceme.
Erect perennial, leaves whorled, lance-shaped, pointed, toothed, dark green, about 15 cm long; florets in racemes, white to pink or bluish.
Spruce tree with sharp, dark green needles, cinnamon coloured branches, and obvious terminal cones that are 8cm with orange, papery scales (new cones are pink).

Vase shape shrub; leaves 20 cm, odd pinnate, sessile, 17-21 ovate-lanceolate leaflets, toothed; fruit blue-black lozenge, May-June. Winter ID: flowers yellow, Dec-Feb, densely-clustered raceme, 25 cm long; bark bright yellow inner colour.
Clump forming bamboo, <1.5 m height; stems red tinged; leaves elliptic, light green/white tips, up to 10 cm long.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Twining vine; leaves are opposite, 3-lobed, with serrate margins and cordate base; flowers cream coloured and spiky; fruit has papery cone-like scales and is pendulous.

Leaves deeply-dissected, 1-2 pinnatifid, hairy, fern-like, aromatic (spicy), up to 25 cm long, divided into as many as 15 pairs of linear-lanceolate toothed segments; florets tiny, long-lasting, bright golden, in small heads that appear in dense, flattened plate-like compound corymbs, 4-10 cm wide.

Fronds are deeply-lobed, rachis dark brown: vegetative fronds are vase-shaped then becoming horizontal and evergreen; reproductive fronds are upright with much narrower pinnae, lower surface with two thick rows of sori.
Leaves large, twice ternate with lobed leaflets; Flowers large (>15 cm wide) in summer; Fruit an aggregate of four or more follicles.

Leaves are solid dark-green, lanceolate with acuminate to acute tips and distinct hair glands that extend along serrate margins; flowers single, <8 cm long and spurred in colors of red, crimson, pink, purple, or white. Hybrids: Leaves tricolor with red midrib, yellow arrow-like centre, and the rest dark-green.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Trailing plant; leaves semi-succulent, opposite and exstipulate with ovate blades "dotted with cinnamon" (glands), blades mature to about 3(-4) cm long, with 3-6 pairs of rounded teeth, on petioles about 2 cm long.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: (white to pale mauve with purple spots)

keyFeatures: Leaves long, linear, flat, about 4 mm wide, turning orange to bronze in fall; spikelets in rows on branched stems above the foliage in August, purplish-bronze.
Leaves dark green, deeply divided into 5-7 toothed lobes; florets "monk-hooded", deep purplish-blue to violet, in dense, terminal racemes up to 20 cm long.
Leaves basal and then opposite on runners, rounded, wrinkled, dark green-reddish; flower petals bluish, fused at bases with two lower lobes much larger than the others.
Basal; leaves narrow, dark green (folded like an accordion), spiky hairs on edges; inflorescence panicle, whorled spikelets (like sparklers).
origin: B.C. west of Cascades (Ranges from Arctic to high altitudes in tropics)

keyFeatures: Leaves dark, appearing in tight spirals on 60 cm tall brown stems; flower with 2 cup-like bracts, lime-green.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves basal, lobed, 10-15(-20 cm) wide when mature; flowers deep maroon-purple flowers, about 2 cm wide.
Leaves to 25 cm, alternate, variegated gold and green.
Grass to 4 m tall; leaves with silver midrib.
origin: Garden origin (Japan: M. sacchariflorus x M. sinensis)

keyFeatures: Leaves 11-14 mm wide, blue-green turning red-orange in fall, white silky hairs at 'collar'; flowers purple tinged, turning white in fall.
origin: S.E. Asia / Japan / China (possible a hybrid involving M. sacchariflorus)

keyFeatures: Small evergreen grass-like; leaves (15 cm), fibrous, thick, linear, purple/black; flower tiny with 6 pinkish-white tepals; berries black, 5 mm wide, Oct-Nov.
Spreading ground cover; leaves are 6 cm compound, clover-like with three heart-shaped leaflets that are green on top and purple on the bottom and are on pinkish-white stems.
Fountain grass with bottle-brush like inflorescence that appears whitish and fluffy.
Grass tall, 60 cm; leaves 2 mm wide, mid-green, ridged, raised midrib underside; inflorescence fluffy, fuzzy,arching, tan panicle, July; fruit seeds, Aug-Sept.
Leaves succulent, rounded, whorled (three per node), up to 2 cm long; florets with just four petals (most sedums have 5), up to 12 mm wide.
Tall tufted evergreen grass; leaves arching to 2.4 m high, spikelets oat-like, in large panicles
Tall, stiffly-upright grass to 2 m; leaves to 4 cm wide and 60 cm long, linear, ribbed and have a white midrib.
Cactus-like plant has larger spirals of succulent leaves with smaller spirals clinging to the sides (like 'chicks').
Leaves arrow-head shaped, dark green with cream coloured venation.
Leaves 5 cm by 20 cm long, bright green; fruit oat-like but more flattened, 3 cm long, pendulous, and flutters with the slightest breeze.
Vigorous, clump-forming; flower heads with creamy-white disk florets only.
Leaves are very light green or cream, 20 cm high, wedged, and curled at the tips.
Leaves whorled, linear; flower heads daisy-like, up to 2.5 cm wide, ray florets pink, margins entire, disk florets yellow.

Grows up to 40 cm high x 60 cm wide; leaves narrow, arching, green near base to mostly coppery brown (on the same plant); fruit is a brown braid on 1 mm floppy stalk (arching and trailing to the ground).
Leaves iris-like (1 m); flowers are striking red, rising paired off on a purplish stem.
origin: Garden origin (C. masoniorum x C. paniculata)

keyFeatures: Tall grass (2 m); leaves about 1 m long x 2 cm wide, medium green that are folded and have a thick midrib; inflorescence to 3 m high, panicle of spikelets that look braided.
Leaves are succulent with pink variegated margins.
Low succulent groundcover; leaves 0.5cm long, silvery-blue that are spoon-shaped and whorled on pinkish stems.
Fountain-like mid-sized grass; leaves mid-green; inflorescence large long-lasting bottle-brush, purple/black, July; fruit dark brown.
Clump forming grass with compressed imbricate spikelets dangling in open panicles as the grains mature.
Stiffly upright, green leaves with blood-red tips.
Leaves are large and green that look silvery-white from the dense, furry hair that covers them. Very soft to touch.
Leaves rounded, lobed, grayish-green, 15-80 cm long.

Small herbaceous perennial up to 50 cm tall; stipules about cm long, leaves are medium-green, usually compound with three lobed leaflets, pubescent, crenate margins; florets on delicate on white panicle up to 15 cm long; fruit looks like tiny sugar scoops.

Medium to tall shrub (0.5-) 1.5-3 m tall, spreading by rhizomes and often thicket-forming; stems stout to spindly, erect to arching, with a pair of large prickles at each node (usually lacking internodal prickles); mature stems blackish; leaflets 1-7 cm long, coarsely double-toothed (common on coast) or single (east of the Cascade Mountains); flowers 4-8 cm wide, usually solitary (or 2 or 3 in a cluster); petals (2) 2.5-4 cm long; sepals 1.5-4 cm long, persistent; hips globe- to pear-shaped, 1-2 cm long, ripens into a purplish-red, with numerous achenes. (Modified from E-Flora BC.)

Multi-stemmed shrub; leaves 6 cm, 3-lobed, serrate, similar to currant leaves but with small stipules; inflorescence a corymb of usually white florets to 1 cm from pinkish buds. Winter ID: buds alternate; bark severely exfoliating.
Dense, clump-forming grass-like ground cover; leaves arching, blue-green; spikes cylindrical, most 2-7 cm long
Tall plant (70 cm) reddish stems with white sap (typical of euphorbia); leaves green then turn all shades of fire in the fall; flowers are fiery orange/yellow.

Large, dense tuft; leaves are flat to tightly rolled, mostly 20-30 cm long and 3-5 mm wide, evergreen; stems erect, grow up above tuft of grass bearing spikelets arranged in panicles up to 18 cm long with nodding tips.
Evergreen climber; leaves mostly lanceolate, dark green; flowers tubular, yellow and red, in summer; berries black.
Leaves linear, 10-30 cm x 1-2 cm, margins with scattered white hair-like filaments; florets brownish, very small, in open panicles.

Tree diamond-shaped, dark lenticels on gray-white bark; leaves 6 cm, dark-green above/ silvery white & hairy underside (cashmere-like), irregular shapes, leaves turn yellow in autumn; male catkins red, <8 cm.long, pendent, early spring; female catkins green, <5 cm long.

Leaves about 1 cm x 40 cm long, margins pale yellow before fading to pinkish white, sticky (hairs that catch); inflorescence purplish brown and loose; florets very tight in upright spike of spikelets.
origin: Garden origin (C. arundinacea x C. epigejos)

keyFeatures: Bark shaggy, peeling, red-brown; leaves diamond-shape, rhombic-ovate, biserrate, <8cm; catkins separate female (become conelike, 3-lobe scales) and male (<8cm, yellow-brown), early spring. Winter ID: exfoliating bark,yellow leaves.
Flowers to 10 cm wide, white to pink, many petals, buds round; leaves mostly with three deeply entire or incised leaflets.

Leaf compound, serrated, 5 leaflets/1 terminal, orbicular, 2 stipules, fall-purple/red; flower semi-double, true red, June to September, no scent. Winter ID: strong prickles; fruit huge rose hips, persistent, .
Leaves mostly with 3 or 5 main lobes and lobes are toothed; flowers 'hooded', blue-violet, and appear in the fall in racemes; stems sturdy and stay upright .
Dense evergreen ground cover; leaves basal and then opposite on runners, ovate, bronze-green, irregular margins; florets crowded in verticillasters, blue to purple, May-June.
Leaves alternate, linear-elliptic, up to 6 cm long and 1 cm wide; flower stiff so that seems dried already (crispy, straw-like).
Leaves are linear and very fine, 40 cm high, completely bronze/tan; fruit brown, 2 cm braid on a 1.5 cm trailing stalk.
Basal; leaves alternate, pinnate venation, sheathed base, elliptic, acute, undulating, green/reddish tints; flowers salverform, racemes, red, pink, orange, yellow; June-September.
leaves alternate, leathery, usually 3-lobed, up to 10 cm long; flowers bright yellow, saucer-shaped, 5 showy petal-like sepals.
Low carpets of leathery, glossy, dark green leaves each have three coarsely toothed leaflets that are red tinted in winter.
Stems hairy; leaves broad, coarsely toothed; flower heads are often used to depict the sun.
Stoloniferous perennial; flowers relatively large, pink (most cvs.) and 'hooded'; leaves triangular to ovate, pubescent, central silver stripe or mottling and rounded-toothed.
Leaves thick, fleshy, spoon-shaped, to 9 cm long, in a basal rosette; florets with 7-13 showy petals clustered on short stalks.
Peppermint taste; leaves ovate, to 9 cm long, opposite, sharply serrated, major veins turning red; stems turning reddish, square in c.s.
Upright, 1 m annual with leaves that are 20 cm x 3 cm, parallel, and bronze-purple; spikelets in a spike about 15 cm long, bottle-brush or rush-like.
Leaves basal, linear, erect, V-shaped at midrib, mostly over 1 m long.
petalColour: (does not flower reliably if at in the Greater Vancouver area)

keyFeatures: Small clumping perennial; leaves narrow, linear, hairy; flowers star-shaped, pink or white.
Flowers with 5 large white petals and many yellow stamens; fruit capsule, 5 sections. Winter ID: buds long, slender, 45 degrees angle.
Trailing annual; leaves peltate, prominent veined, irregular, up to 8 cm long; flowers trumpet-shaped, warm, firey colours. Almost always have aphids.
Low, evergreen perennial; leaves compound, rounded, slightly lobed (lily-pad like), medium green leaflets and red petioles; flower with reversed petals resembles a shooting star.

Tall shrub; leaves irregularly dentate, 3 lobes toward the apex half of blade, several club shaped glands where the petiole meets the blade; flowers white in a hydrangea-like inflorescence; fruit 8-10 mm long, red, and edible. Winter ID: buds opposite, smooth, 8mm long.

Stems hairy, branching, mostly <1 m tall; leaves opposite, simple (unlike dahlia), ovate to lance-shaped, up to 12 cm long, usually lacking petioles with blade clasping the stem; flowers petal number and colour highly variable.
Leaves long, ovate lobes, acuminate, doubly serrate, highly dissected, palmately cut. Winter ID: buds look like a moose hoof with hair around the base.

Woody clinging vine, with aerial roots for climbing trees; leaves large, compound, pinnate, dark green; leaflets serrated with bronze new growth; flowers reddish orange, trumpet shaped. Winter ID: large circular leaf scars.
Leaves deeply dissected, palmate with 3 to 5 narrow, jagged-edged lance-shaped leaflets (reminiscent of cannabis); samaras persistent, red and green.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Upright, basal, linear leaves with entire margins, parallel venation, and hollow centers. Up to 50 cm in length and 3 mm in diameter and scented. Showy purple umbel.
Leaves are heart-shaped (3-9 cm), brightly variegated pink, green, pale yellow and red on red stalks.
Leaves opposite, turning silverish-gray, lanceolate-linear that are tomentose and highly aromatic; flower is a verticillaster with husk-like, highly scented purple florets.
Needles about 1 cm long, square with blunt tip, dark green, cones 8-10 cm, persistent.
Low and shrubby perennial; leaves opposite, elliptic to ovate, finely crenulate, medium to grayish-green, very rugose, distinct scent.
Bark is whitish-tan to cinnamon colour, smooth, and exfoliating; large black capsule fruits in the summer.

Branches weeping, contorted; leaves bright green/gray-green beneath, twisted, lanceolate, toothed; catkins yellow-green, spring; male catkins yellow anthers. Winter ID: buds appressed, new growth buds almost black with red base.
Leaves are silver, pointed, geometrically-spiraled and they weigh down the stalk.
Leaves are finely dissected, up to 40 cm long, stiff, with a licorice taste.
Leaves basal, ovate, bases cordate, irregularly toothed and serrate, up to 12 cm long; flowers yellow bottle brush-like that rises above the leaves.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: (Ligularia stenocephala 'Little Rocket' has very bright yellow blooms.)

keyFeatures: Leaves are heavily-lobed, spiney, toothy; flower is a bluish/purple 'globe'-shape.

Leaves basal, pubescent, most with 7 rounded lobes that are toothed or scalloped, blades up to 5 cm wide, petioles up to 13 cm long; florets showy, bell-shaped, sweetly fragrant, petals shorter than the pink to dark red sepals, up to 12 mm wide; in open panicles 30-50 cm tall.

Leaves mostly oval to almost round, margins serrate from half-way up to tips, initially pubescent then glabrous, 2-5 cm long; raceme of open, white florets, 5 petals; pomes pulpy, blue to purplish-black, about 1 cm long. Winter ID: buds alternate, cobweb-like covered tips; twigs orange to red-brown, smooth with prominent lenticels.
Ground cover about 15 cm tall; leaves opposite, ovate, in terminal whorls of 4-6, veins parallel and curved; flower 4 whitish petals, May-June; berries red, Aug-Sept.
Leaves tri-pinnately compound, triangle-shaped, yellow-green/turns dark green; sub-leaflets oblong when young/lobed when mature; sporangia tiny clusters along margins, rust-brown.

Leaves opposite, leathery, mostly lanceolate, 0.8-4 cm long x 3-11 mm wide, margins entire and often rolled under, shiny, dark green, glabrous above, lower surface grayish and very finely and densely covered with short glandula hairsh, petioles 2-5 mm longl; flowers deep pinkish-rose, saucer-shaped, 1-2 cm wide; capsules 5-valved, about 4 mm wide x 5 mm long. (E-Flora BC)

Multi-stem shrub, upright with flattened, contorted branchlets, red-purple stems/buds in spring; leaves lanceolate, bright green with silvery green beneath, highly fluted (fasciated) stems; catkins in early spring, gray then yellow.
Grass-like herbaceous perennial; Leaves are dark green, linear to sword-like, basal; Flowers are radial and sky blue with dark blue veins.
Single stem to 30-50 cm tall; leaves lanceolate, sessile, and alternating; florets white, in terminal panicle.

Small tree 5–14 metres tall, with a dense thorny crown; leaves 2 - 5 cm long, obovate, deeply lobed and serrate; flowers with 5 white petals, numerous red anthers, in May, to 1.5 cm wide, moderately fragrant; fruit oval, dark red, about 1 cm long, berry-like pome containing a single seed, persistent to spring.

Deciduous tree; Leaves are dull, olive coloured, ovate leaves that have prominent veins (but indented on upper surface); Winter ID; 8mm buds look like rust-coloured praying hands. Bark looks like snake skin.
Thicket shrub; leaves are large (20 cm), palmate, dull green that are tomentose and serrate; fruit about 1 cm wide, bright red, and looks like half a thimble or a dense raspberry.
Tree to 6 m tall; flowers white, <2 cm wide; pomes oblong, <1 cm long. Winter ID: buds spur-like; bark coppery-brown, scaly and plated.
Rosette-forming perennial; leaves hairy, roundish and cordate with a toothed margin; inflorescence rises above foliage on terminal racemes, flowers are greenish white.
Spreading herbaceous perennial; leaves cordate in varying shades of green, baby leaves arise on the petiole where attached to the older leaf base.

Leaves needle-like, linear to acicular, opposite, glaucous, leathery, strongly scented when crushed, most 2-3 cm long x 2-3 mm wide; flowers whorls of 2-lipped, usually bluish (less commonly white, pink, or purple), tubular, at upper leaf axils.
petalColour: (most are pale blue to almost white)

keyFeatures: Leaves are basal, mostly oblong-obovate, 10-15 cm long; florets bell-shaped to 5 cm wide to 90 cm tall, mostly lilac-blue or white on raceme that blooms in summer; sap milky.
petalColour: (Species blue; other colours depends on cv.)

keyFeatures: Leaves cordate, shallow but constant, sharp serrations, green to purple; inflorescence panicle of pale purple 5-lobed florets, compound style spirals at tip, prominent ovary.
Flowers radially symmetical, petals 5, each with a broad lip (lamina) and hooked or straight spur directed along the petiole (often the same colour as the large petal-like sepals).
petalColour: lamina and sepals vary with cv.)

keyFeatures: Leaves sheathing, lanceolate, entire or rarely lobed, mostly less than 10 cm long; flower heads blue with red to blue centers and black-edged bracts below, to 7 cm wide, in late spring.
Leaves sessile, woolly due to greyish-white hairs, mostly lanceolate and 2 cm long; flowers white in summer 2 cm wide, petals 5, heart-shaped.

Prostrate spreading evergreen shrub to 20 cm; leaves alternate, simple, evergreen, up to 1.5 (-2.5) cm x 0.4 (-0.6), oblanceolate, margin entire, dark green; flowers pink, in dense clusters, highly fragrant, springtime.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves broadly elliptic to obovate, maroon to dark green, marginal teeth with serrations, up to 12 cm long; catkins of male florets up to 8 cm long in Feb.-Mar.; nuts form in July are encased by an involucre husk that extends beyond the nut (in contrast to C. avellana which is also more shrub-like).

Small plant with multiple upright stems; leaves produce shades of red, orange, and purple in autumn; flowers with electric yellow bracts bloom on a low cushion in April and persist, but gradually fade as stems elongate to form a 40 cm tall mound by midsummer.

Leaves alternate, three-lobed palmate compound leaves (biternate) on fleshy green or pink petioles. Flowers heart-shaped, usually magenta and white, 3 cm long and evenly spaced to hang on long arching stems.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: (Some images are of cv. Alba (white flowers))

keyFeatures: Low growing with long linear basal leaves; florets large, lily-like with 6 bright yellow tepals produced daily from June until first hard frost.
Leaves to 1.3 m, thick, medium-green and fleshy at the base; flower cluster to 15 cm wide; fruit a large showy capsule.

Leaves scale like in full sun to awl-like in shaded parts, dark green with no purplish color in winter, unpleasant aroma when crushed; usually dioecious: male plants produce catkin-like pollen cones and female plants form bluish-black seed cones that are berry-like.
Leaves arranged in a cob web-like covering of rosettes.

Tall, narrow, deciduous tree, upright branching with pendulous tips; leaves broadly elliptic, emerge gold changing to bright green over summer; buds are long, pointed, spear-like; smooth grey (elephant skin) bark with horizontal lines. Winter ID: habit, form, and 'elephant skin' bark; buds large, narrow pointy, alternating.
Leaves tips and bases rounded, margins entire with fine hairs, most 3-4 cm wide x 4-5 cm long.

Leaves alternate, deltoid to ovate, glossy with margins entire, undulate, and often ciliate, dark red; fruit capsule-like, brown, bristly. Winter ID: elliptical buds >2 cm long x 4 mm wide, pointed, spear-like, divergent, brown; bark smooth, silver-grey, with a horizontal pattern (like an elephant's leg).

Similar to D. formosa but has narrower, less rounded flowers with longer wings on the outer petals and can flower from spring to fall; leaves finely divided into leaflets and lobes, gray-green, mostly 20-35 x 10-15 cm.
Leaves basal forming a rosette, succulent, usually glaucous (some are green and tinged red),
Habit upright becoming mat-like; leaves dissected, fern-like; flowers 4-5 cm wide, most with 4 overlapping petals, commonly bright orange.
Leaves alternate, spoon-shaped to oblong-ovate; flowers funnel shaped green corolla tube opening at right angle to 5 colourful petals, about 5 cm wide.
origin: Garden origin ( N. alata x N. forgetiana)

keyFeatures: Leaves ovate, undulating cupped, papery and hang down; stems purple/glaucus when young; flower bracts large, wide, overlapping; fruit absent. Winter ID: terminal buds look like chicken feet; swooping branches.
origin: Garden origin (C. nuttallii x C. florida)

keyFeatures: Tall native tree with large white flower-like inflorescences (many small clustered florets surrounded by white bracts).
Leaves basal with 3 incised leaflets, rounded with mucronate tips; flowers daisy-like with many petal-like sepals, solitary, whorl of leafy bracts on scape; plants go dormant after flowering.

Large woody deciduous vine with lilac blue to white flowers, smaller than W. foribunda flowers; leaves alternate, leaflets (7-)11(-13) elliptic to ovoid. Winter ID: stems twine counter clockwise; fruit pods brown.
Florets on tall peduncle forming a rounded head full of violet to purple flowers.
Sort and tall cultivars; leaves alternate, lanceolate, and dark glossy green; flowers bi-laterally symmetrical with and open when squeezed on the sides.
Leaves opposite, obovate, apex rounded or notched, bright green, 10-25 mm long (generally more rounded than B. sempervirens).
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves heart shaped, large (to 25 cm long); flowers to 5 cm long with an unusual Dutch pipe-shape due to calyx. Winter ID: twining stems; leaf scar U-shaped; buds small, clustered, wooly.
Leaves opposite with 3 leaflets; flowers up to 20 cm wide, 8 white and pink-purple petal-like sepals.
Leaves mostly > 4 mm wide; flowers relatively large and begin to open about two weeks after those of C. chrysanthus.
Compact spring flowering bulb plant; leaves basal, linear, about 2 cm wide x 20 cm long; florets with six tepals and short pedicles, highly fragrant, in an erect raceme.

Up to 60 cm tall; leathery basal leaves on long petioles, palmately compound and heavy venation with 5-7 dark green, serrate or irregularly toothed leaflets; early flowering cyme, cup-shaped due to 5 petal-like sepals, usually pendulous.
origin: Garden origin (varies with cv.: H. lividus x H. niger x H. argutifolium x H. x sternii)
petalColour: (Helleborus x hybridus 'Royal Heritage Strain' produces a wide range of shades from white to pink
distinctive cup shaped bloom with strong overlapping petals. Some blooms are freckled or blotched.)

keyFeatures: Invasive ground cover that's often used in hanging baskets; leaves variegated with silver.
Stem to up to 2 m tall, nodes may have bulbils; leaves 6-10 cm x 1-2 cm wide; flowers orange with black spots, 6 tepals.
Twining climber; leaves joined on the new growth; flowers trumpet-shaped, scarlet, in showy clusters, not scented.
origin: North America (L. hirsute x L. sempervirens)

keyFeatures: Leaves silky, oblong to elliptic, hairy, gray-green leaves to 10 cm long. Flowers extremely fragrant, to 5 cm wide cultivars both singles and doubles (petals ruffled), bloom in dense racemes.

Leaves narrow, basal, to 30 cm long; florets deep violet blue, urn-shaped (grape-like), slightly fragrant (musky-sweet), 20-40 on conical racemes on scapes rising up to 20 cm in early spring, 1-3 per bulb.
Leaves oblong-elliptic, hairy, green up to 11 cm x 3 cm (if basal); flowers small, 5-lobed, up 1 cm wide, blue with yellow or white eyes bloom in dense cymes mostly in April - May.
A trumpet daffodil with one flower per stem 40-56 cm tall in spring; flowers up to 10 cm wide, bright yellow petals and a yellow trumpet.
Leaves floating on water surface, attached to the rhizomes by long petioles, margin entire or toothed edges, apex rounded or pointed; flowers rise out of the water or float on the surface.
Leaves mostly 10-20 cm wide with three pointed lobes; berries blue-black, persist after leaf drop.

Leaves mostly basal (some smaller ones alternate up the peduncle), ovobate to spoon-shaped, margins lobed to incised, very hairy, with 3-4 narrow, pointed lobes, blue-green, up to 15 cm long; flowers with four large overlapping petals.
Loose, mat forming mound; leaves mostly opposite, awl-shaped or linear, pointed, thick, and clustered at nodes; flowers about 2 cm wide with notched petals.
Stems arching; leaves alternate, parallel veined, smooth; flowers greenish yellow (usually in pairs), small, tubular to bell-shaped, 6 tepals; fruit blue-black berries.
Leaves arising from rhizome or alternate, margins entire, wavy; inflorescence cylindrical, about 3 cm x 4-10 cm long, petals pink; achenes brown, about 3 x 4 mm, shiny, smooth.

Leaves deeply-divided, silky, hairy, fern-like, light green, basal, to 12 cm long; flowers solitary, erect-to-nodding and open-bell-shaped (bloom as the foliage begins to form); fruit achenes in spherical clusters (similar to some clematis species).
Leaves dissected, parsley-like; flowers cup-shaped, poppy-like, up to 5 cm wide, common cultivars with many petals in red, pink, purple, yellow or white, purple-black anthers.
Leaves basal, pinnately compound, has 6-9 leaflets up to 20 cm long (may appear palmate like horse chestnut); florets creamy pink to red, astilbe-like.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves mostly 5-lobed (a bit like tiny hands), spirally arranged, tightly spaced on short stems forming moss-like clumps; florets cymose 1-2 cm wide, 5 separate identical petals, mostly white, pink or shades of red, May-June.
Leaves opposite, elliptic, about 5 mm long, dark green with a strong lemon scent lemon-scent especially when in flower; flowers tiny, tubular, pale lilac.
Leaves linear, alternating to top of stem; flowers with three petals clustered in stem tip.
Leaves bipinnately compound, large (about 90 cm long), odd-pinnate, pinnae broadly ovate to elliptic, up to 7 cm wide x 10 cm long; bark with 5 mm long randomly arranged thorn-like prickles.
Leaves with white tubercles occurring on top and bottom and both sides.
Clustered basal stems; foliage has ragged, fan-shape tips that resemble a fish tail; flowers emerge in clusters, as catkins.

Leaves 25–70 cm long and 10–30 cm broad, petioles up to 1 m long; flowers at the tips of long stalks, the spathe is perpendicular to the stem to appear like a bird's head and beak, florets emerge one at a time from the spathe, three orange sepals and three purplish-blue or white petals (two are joined together to form an arrow-like nectary).
petalColour: 2 fused together as a 'tongue'; orange sepals)

keyFeatures: Stem barrel shaped; leaves reduced to sharp spines 1-1.5 cm long.

Stems clustered, reed-like, course fibers; leaves eventually forming (3-) -8(-11) elliptic leaflets (initially palmately deeply lobed), margins finely toothed, tips acute becoming truncate with age, about 2-3 cm wide at centre x 30 cm long.

Leaves basal, in clumps, heart-shaped on long petioles, dark green leaves often variegated with silver blotching or veining. Flowers with downward sepals and reflexed petals that unfold in a curved and upward position at the tips.
Stem zig-zags; needle-like cladophylls in clusters of 20-30 per cluster forming a "pom pom".
Whole plant an iridescent; velvety sheen; stems hairy; leaves finely serrated, green, and densely covered with purple hairs.
Leaves pinnately compound, 1-5(-7); leaflets ovate to lanceolate, margins toothed with narrow points.
Large evergreen shrub; leaves opposite, variegated greyish-green and cream-like, with large spines (look like a variegated Ilex aquifolium except Ilex has alternate leaves).
Bulb about 10 cm long; plant up to about 60 cm tall; leaves narrow, linear; flowers largish blue to yellow to white flowers with no fragrance and mainly bloom in May–June.
origin: Garden origin (Iris xiphium var. praecox from Spain and var. lusitanica from France x Iris tingitana from North Africa)

keyFeatures: Leaves iris-like, narrow, sword-shaped, florets sweetly fragrant, funnel-shaped, 5-10 form on a arching, spike-like cyme, peduncle wiry, up to 45 cm tall.
Leaves very rugose, ovote to elliptic, margins scalloped; floret petals fused with lower ones pouch-like, very showy, commonly bight yellow (also orange - red cvs.), about 1 cm wide.
petalColour: (The flower is usually spotted.The C. 'Sunshine' has bright yellow flowers)

keyFeatures: Leaves are glossy and serrated; stems are reddish and fleshy; flowers arrange in clusters of 3 at the tips of stems.
Basal leaves orbicular and palmately lobed; flower ray florets with white band towards center of head plus various colours on the outer part of each ray corolla.
origin: Garden origin (P. cruenta x P. lanata - both Canary Islands.)

keyFeatures: Plastic-like 2-3 pinnate fronds to 1.5 m with round black sori.
Highly branched and extremely fine-textured 'fern'; leaves needle-like, about 1 cm long.
Leaves triangular-shaped (dark red and purple cvs. are common).
Leaves linear 12-20 cm long x 4-5 cm wide; flowers white, fragrant, trumpet-shaped, up to 17 cm long, 6 tepals, bloom in July-August or in time for Easter if forced indoors.
Leaf blades glossy, deeply-dissected, up to 40 cm long indoors (to 90 cm long outdoors in the tropics), margins wavy, petioles sturdy and usually longer than blade.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Foliage is dark green with white vein-like patterns, and is fuzzy.
Leaves bipinnately to tripinnately compound, some leaflets with a few teeth or small lobes, glossy, dark green & lacy.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Stems low growing, highly branched, a quick-spreading ground cover but limited by cold locally; leaves rounded, shiny, and only about 5 mm long.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Heart-shaped leaves that have a chocolate brown cross like pattern in the center and with a green outer surrounding.
Fronds, arching, up to 30 cm tall and wide; pinnae about 12 cm wide x 16 mm long with crinkled margin, alternating on brownish-red rachis that has fine scales.
Leaves small, succulent, greyish; stems pendulous.

Stems thin, trailing; leaves opposite, heart-shaped, entire margins, pointed tip, dark green, often with silvery variegation, about 2 cm long; flowers arise one per node, tubular with swollen base, pinkish with darker protruding anthers, about 2 cm long.
To 40 cm tall; glossy leaves to 20 cm long; flowers yellow to white with yellow bottom petal markings, about 5 cm wide, up to 7 per stem starting from the top downwards.
Leaves broad, cupped, leathery, many variegated cultivars mottled cream, gray, or gold; flower "spikes" up to 12 cm long.
Long stem roses and small sized potted roses; prickles; leaves alternate, pinnately compound; most with 7 serrated leaflets, leafy stipules extend up petiole.
Needles 5 per fascicle; slender, soft, blue green, finely serrated, 5-13 cm long.
Floppy, perennial mound with compound, deeply lobed, smooth papery leaves that are variable in shape; inflorescence had-like with many violet-blue florets.
Leaves basal, sessile, obovate-spatulate, margins usually with small teeth; florets yellow, 5-20 cm per umbel, peduncle about 10 cm long.

Leaves thistle-like, pinnately dissected, toothed, hairy, grayish-green up to 30 cm long, turning yellow soon after flowering; flowers with four large wavy pink, red, orange or white petals with a dark center; fruit an attractive brown capsule with pores about 2 cm long.
Leaves opposite, ovate-orbicular, margins toothed and/ or lobed, on long runners; flowers yellow, 5 petals (fused at base), up to 7 cm wide; fruit a muskmelon (e.g. cantaloupe, honeydew, etc.).
Leaves spirally arranged on a compact stem, linear-lanceolate, margins wavy and serrate, pink variegation, up to 15 cm long.
Palm-like; leaves sword-shaped, leathery.
Bark scaly/black when young, turning thick/orange-brown with maturity; broken twigs smell like 'oranges'; needles 3 per fascicle, 10-25 cm long. Seedlings w. 8-10 cotyledons, 3.5-5 cm long, no teeth.
Leaves ovate, 6-9 cm long, solid purple underneath, most cultivars with silvery longitudinal stripes above (or just green and purple).
Flattened stem segments 4-8 cm long with crenate margins and soft brown spines (leaf remnants); flower scarlet, 2-6 cm wide with many petals.
origin: South America (H. gaertneri x H. rosea)

keyFeatures: Leaves fleshy, scale-like; fruit (female cone) is a small, spiky ball.
Leaves hightly pennisect; florets loosely arranged in muliple racemes (compare the dense single raceme found in Delphinium).
Leaves furled at the tip, glossy, and dark green on the midrib.
Leaves glossy dark green, alternate, elliptic, 3-8 cm x 1-4 cm, apex and base mostly acute, aromatic when crushed, petiole about 1 cm long and flattened.
origin: S.E. Asia / Japan / China (Citrus reticulata x Fortunella japonica

keyFeatures: Basal crenately lobed foliage; very showy throughout spring and fall.
Seedlings with 6 cotyledons.

Leaves basal, long, broad, flat, smooth, light green to purplish red, may have variegation or banding; spikes are often tall, broad (flattened), and colored with shades of brilliant red, yellow, and orange.
Flowers large, sweet smelling, lily-like, on thick peduncle.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Foliage is variegated and heart-shaped with red tendrils.
Foliage is heart-shaped, toothed along the margin, and has red tendrils.
Stems thick and fibrous; leaves are strap-like with smooth margins.
Leaves basal, linear; florets sessile, mostly 5-8 cm wide, in spikes up to 1 m long.
Forms a thick crown; leaves upward-arching, divided into long, thin leaflets.
Leaves perfume scented like pine and citris, opposite, ovate-elliptic, medium gray-green, and pubescent; stems square in c.s.; flowers to 3 mm wide, white to pink.
Leaves grass-like, basal and then spirally arranged, linear, up to 30 cm long; heads arranged in a spike, purple, violet or white, opening from top to bottom.
Seedlings with 3-6 cotyledons, 1.2-3 cm long; needles 2 (rarely 3) per fascicle, mostly 4-8 cm long.
Most early flowering Iris on campus; leaves angular to almost squarish at bases in cross-section (do not roll well between fingers).
Rhizomes only; leaves basal, large, arrowhead-shaped, forming clumps to 60-90 cm tall, flowers minute and in a yellow finger-like spadix surrounded by a bright white or colorful bract (the spathe).
petalColour: Black calla lily has rich velvety purple black flowers)

keyFeatures: A bushy trailing plant; leaves ovate, toothed, heavily textured, dark green with dark bronze undertones and often light green edges, undersides are typically dark red, to 8 cm long.

Leaves basal, oval, 4-8 cm long leaves, margins scalloped (irregularly toothed/ incised); florets with 5 notched petals, mostly in shades of pink to purple mostly with some yellow on the throat (all white cv. available), 20-30 per panicle.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves basal (from a bulb), long linear to oblong-lanceolate, petiole slender, up to 30 cm long; florets star-shaped, in racemes, white species are most common but florists may use the orange coloured O. dubium.

Leaves needle-like, arranged spirally all around the shoot, 7-25 mm long x 1-1.5 mm wide, margins smooth, stomata on upper and lower surface and triangular to rounded in cross-section (unlike other species of hemlock); male cones tiny, yellow when ripe; female cones spruce-like 3-8 cm long x 1.5-2.5 cm wide, dark purple becoming to red-brown when mature, pubescent.

Leaf blades lanceolate to obovate with rounded bases, major veins run parallel off midrib,of most cultivars with bold variegation with V- shaped patterns, many with dark-red undersides, 20-30 cm long.
Leaves lobed, and arranged in a basal rosette of 3 leaflets; flowers 3-8 cm wide, most with 5-8 petal-like sepals, and dark stamens.

Thorny and twiggy with stems that erect from the ground; leaves alternate, simple ovate with acuminate tips, 4-13 cm long x 2-6 cm wide; florets small usually white, each group of three are surrounded by three or six colourful bracts that are commonly pink or purple, sepals white and petal-like, tubular at base.
Stems leggy, purple; leaves smooth and bright green or purple, opposite, ovate with serrate margins which tend to curve downwards, highly scented.
Stems reddish; leaves broad and oval with cream-like variations and dark green stripes;lower surface pinkish-purple.
Leaves ovate to oblong, 3-5 major veins, petiole stem-clasping, up to 8 cm long; flowers bell-shaped with flaring pale purple petal-like lobes, up to 5 cm wide.
Plant upright; stem is lined with fine hairs; leaves ovate, dark green, margin toothed; tiny florets in fuzzy red "catkins".
Foliage is lime green, and bushy like a fox's tail.
Leaves have deep lobes; flower heads have convex ray florets.
Leaves alternate and usually leathery, elliptic, and evergreen.
Leaves opposite on square stems, ovate, up to 8 cm long, and smell like pineapple when crushed; florets bright scarlet, two-lipped, in a spike-like verticillaster up to 20 cm long.
Fine white hairs covering sharp pointy spines.
Cactus-like houseplant; stems mostly 3 angled; leaves obovate, occur along ridges when present.
Basal leaves to 20 cm long, broad, lobed; florets tightly clustered, papery; “sinuatum” refers to 3-sided winged peduncles.
Scented annual; leaves alternate, compound, tri-pinnate, serrate margins, leaflets deltoid and +/- curling; stem with swollen nodes and vertical stripes.
Leaves narrow, linear to narrowly elliptical (rarely 3-lobed), up to 7(-10) cm long x about 1.5 cm wide; head of yellow disk florets in narrow, elongated panicles.

Low perennial; leaves opposite, very rugose (deep netted veins produces distinctive sage-leaf texture), variegated (cream margins, mid-green centers, and purple tint to bright purple variations and dark maroon petioles), distinct sage scent.

Low perennial; leaves opposite, very rugose (deep netted veins produces distinctive sage-leaf texture), glaucus, elliptic-oblong, highly aromatic, finely scalloped margins, dark green to purple with purple veins, distinct sage scent.

Leaves elliptic to obovate, margins serrate, up to to 10 cm long; florets white, about 1 cm wide, in pendulous racemes up to 15 cm long; cherries ripening to black by mid-summer, extremely bitter, < 8 mm round.
Leaves are very rough, sandpapery, have a strong grapefruit scent when crushed, short hairs; flowers about 7 cm wide, multi-coloured, umbel looks like a pile of Chiclets or very large cake sprinkles.
Clump forming; leaves thick, rounded, leathery with mostly crenate margins, winter colour often reddish or bronze; florets cymose on panicle-like scape.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves bluish with irregularly shaped creamy gold centers; flowers pale lavender in late summer on 50 cm tall racemes.

Stems branched mostly 3 times, leaves 25-80 cm long, linear with strong midrib and smooth margins; flowers blue (white or purple cvs.); fruit capsules about 1-1.3 x 3-4.5 long; rhizomes about 1 cm thick.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: (cv. Caesar's Brother is purplish; cv. Alba' is white)

keyFeatures: Leaves highly variable from uneven-ovate to palmately lobed; male flowers (2 petals) and female flowers (5 petals) on same plant that both droop.
origin: Garden origin (F1 hybrid between a wax begonia and an angel wing begonia)
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Stems unbranched, usually <3 m tall; leaves linear, up to 9 cm wide by 120 cm long; female inflorescences clustered in "ears" above a few of the leaves in the midsection of the plant, between the stem and leaf sheath, tightly covered by bracts called husks; male inflorescences or "tassels" form at apex of the stem ends; grains called "kernals" are arranged on a "cob".
Leaves are 1.5 - 3cm, dark, and lanceolate; Flower is a 1.5 - 2cm head with yellow ray florets and dark brown-black disk florets. “Procumbens” refers to the low (up to 15cm) height of the plant.
Low growing bushy shrub; leaves opposite, mostly elliptic, up to 2.5 cm long x 7 mm wide, petioles very short; flowers all summer into autumn.

Arching or sprawling shrub 2-3 m high or used locally as an annual in container plantings; leaves elliptic, blades up to 10 cm long x 5 cm wide, margin entire, base cuneate, apex acute or acuminate; petiole 0.5-1.5 cm long, winged in upper part by extension of lamina base; flowers in clusters of 2-5, pedicels 15-25 mm long, calyx 4-5 mm long; lobes 2 mm long, linear, 2-3 cm wide, bright blue, upper 3 lobes with yellow patch at base. (flora.sa.gov.au)
Leaves coarsely toothed, lobed, up to 20 cm wide, mostly palmately veined; flowers waxy yellow, drooping, bell-shaped; capsules three-horned, brownish-green.

Leaves sword-shaped, iris-like, fragrant when crushed, up to 2 cm wide, with wavy or crimped margins, tapering into a long, acute point, pink sheathing at bases; rhizome thick, spreading near soil surface; spadix 5-9 cm in long, greenish-yellow, emerge part way up the shoot.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: A free-floating perennial aquatic plant with spongy, bulbous stalks and feathery, free hanging roots; leaves broadly ovate, thick, glossy, 10-20 cm wide; spike of 8-15 orchid-like flowers with six tepals, mostly lavender to pink.
Leaves wide, ribbon-like with 'bar code' pattern variegation which varies from top to bottom of leaf.
A submerged aquatic perennial; leaves whorled, feathery (pinnatisect).
Stiff rush with narrow, spongy, round, dark green linear leaves that are curled like a corkscrew.
Leaves large, glossy, arrow-head shaped, to 25 cm long; flowers soft blue spike in summer (white cultivar available).
Leaves are basal, puckered and very veiny on the lower surface; Inflorescence rises above foliage.
Forms a dense silvery mound a foot (30 cm) high; leaves finely cut; flower heads of only yellow disk florets, many per stem, each about 5 mm wide.
Leaves rounded, deeply and irregularly lobed, bases cordate; flowers light purple, 5-petals, dark purple veins in centers.
Leaves shiny, dark green, may have reddish-purple edges; flowers irregularly, bluish-mauve.
Basal mound of dark, narrow leaves with floral stalks rising above that support hanging tubular flowers.
petalColour: and 'Prairie Dusk' has rose purple blooms)

keyFeatures: Leaves are 1mm, grayish-white blobs arranged geometrically (like a Hebe). Flower is a 1cm wide head of yellow disk florets.
Very dark purple, obovate, succulent leaves that can be toothed or entire.
Leaves delicate, odd pinnate, with rounded incised leaflets; inflorescence subtended by relatively large white bracts on outer margins.
Leaves with 3 toothed leaflets; white flowers and large red strawberries; prominent runners.
origin: Garden origin (F. virginiana x F. chiloensis)

keyFeatures: Shrub upright, <40 cm; leaves blue-green, clusters, no petiole; stems reddish tinge/topped by spikes of chartreuse flowers, which turn red in winter when in bloom.
origin: Garden origin (E. amygdaloides x E. martinii)

keyFeatures: Leaves rounded, heavily-lobed, palmate, thick and somewhat glossy (cv. Chocolate Ruffles has purple and metallic green leaves; cv. Creme Brulee has lime-green, bronze, and tan leaves).
Low-growing tufted clump; leaves evergreen, coppery-bronze.
Leaves upright, fine textured, curled tips, to 70 cm high, wedged, bronze, leathery, and very difficult to pull up.
Clump forming; leaves very narrow, 1-1.5 mm wide x 20-25 cm long, bluish-green; turquoise-green in winter.

Stems numerous, slender, 3-20 (35) cm tall; leaves 1-3 near the bases, variously developed (reduced to scales or with sheaths and very short blades further up on stems); spikes solitary, near stem tips, 2-5.5 mm long.

Leaves thin, elliptic, 1.5-4 cm x 0.5-1.8 cm, margins entire or with a few low, blunt teeth below the middle only; flowers urn-shaped, pinkish, to 6 mm long, bloom in early spring, before or as the leaves emerge.
Leaves rounded with heart-shaped bases.

Branches large, contorted; shoots orange-red, hairy; leaves oblong-obovate, dark green, lobes may be rounded or slightly pointed, sinus deeply cut into blade and narrow (U-shaped), less than 14 cm long when mature; petioles 1.5-2 cm long; acorns sparsely produced, sessile, 2.5-3 cm long. Winter ID: terminal bud <3 cm, furry; bark deeply fissured.
Leaves, leathery, mostly elliptic, 8-20 cm long x 3-7 cm wide, petioles 1-2 cm long; flowers 2.5-4 cm long x up to 5 cm wide; corolla deeply 5-lobed, stamens 10, anthers 2-3 mm long, red-brown.

Shrub to 6 m tall with dark grey bark and yellowish to reddish-brown twigs that are usually densely hairy; leaves mostly elliptic to obovate, 4-11 cm long, 2-6.3 cm wide, long soft-hairy or short-woolly to shaggy-hairy, sometimes nearly smooth, upper surface highly glossy, long soft-hairy to nearly smooth, margins entire to toothed, bases and tips pointed to rounded; stipules absent, rudimentary, or leaf-like on vigorous shoots; male catkins yellow, 4-8 cm x 2.5 cm; female catkins elongate, 6- 9 cm long as fruit develop. (Modified from E-Flora BC and Trees and Shrubs of BC.)
Similar to the Carolina silverbell (see separate entry) but grows much larger and with larger flowers.

Upright, deciduous tree; leaves are orbicular, floppy, dentate serration, dark green top/silver bottom, long petioles. Winter ID: buds very large, 2 scales, pubescent, fruit persistent, 0.5 cm 'football' nutlet; bark smooth, gray very subtle vertical striping.
Stipe grooved, brown-black with scales; fronds upright, dark green, bipinnate, finely divided, pinnae glossy with crenate margins, veins back, up to 30 cm tall.

Fronds narrow at apex and base, bipinnate, densely arranged, lustrous, leathery, dark green; pinnules bristle-tipped; stipe and rachis are covered with silvery scales that mature to brown; sori dark greenish-brown before turning black.
Smaller fern; fronds light green, pinnae are wider at the base and fused to the rachis (kind of like webbed feet); spores in single rows, tan colour.
Low round-topped ground cover with white five petaled flowers in summer.
Basal ground cover; leaves <10 cm long, fern-like, hairy leaves/stems, bronze fall colour.
Densely branched to base; needles 5 per fascicle, stiff, to (6-)8(-11) cm long, glaucous on inside; often with a slight twist.

Low-growing, roots at nodes; leaves dark purple. trifoliate with light v-shaped marking on each leaflet; inflorescence oval-round, compact, head-like, umbellate, white to purple, florets tubular, 5-10 mm long; legume about 5 mm long with 1 to 4 seeds.

Vigorous cultivar with strong wood; leaves with 3 major lobes with soft serrations, fall colour vibrant red; terminal buds multiple; samaras red, narrower angle compared to Norway maple. Winter ID: buds small (3 mm) red opposite; flower buds in large clusters circle twigs, give branches a bumpy look.
Leaves opposite, compound, odd-pinnate with 3(-5) toothed leaflets; florets in pendant clusters, dioecious, greenish-yellow, male florets with dark red anthers; samaras persistent.
Small, upright Japanese maple with 7-lobed serrated leaves turning from red (spring) to green (summer) to red (fall).
Small tree with red, 5 to 7 lobed serrated leaves about 6 cm wide.
Leaves red-tipped, palmate (most with 7 broad lobes).
Vigorous spreading herbaceous ground cover; leaves ternate or biternate, basal, A. ‘Variegatum’ has creamy-white variegation.
Leaves compound with 5 obovate, serrate leaflets up to 20 cm long, yellow in fall; panicles of red florets. Winter ID: buds large, red, smooth, not sticky.
origin: Garden origin (Hybrid between A. hippocastanum and A. pavia)

keyFeatures: Leaves bi-pinnately compound, light to mid-green, sickle-cell leaflets, fern-like; flower <4 cm long, in terminal clusters, stamens numerous, long, silky, pink filaments arising from a white tube enclosing ovary, Aug-Sept; fruit strap-like, flat brown pod, up to 20 cm long.
Leaves narrow, blue-green, margins rolled under; fruit brown capsule.

Leaves on stems divided into lobed leaflets that are usually three-lobed at the tips; flowers radially symmetical, petals 5, each with a broad lip (lamina) and hooked spur directed along the petiole (often coloured the same shade as the large petal-like sepals).
Small, mounding perennial with mid-green spatulate leaves that are loosely toothed.
Stems trailing; leaves basal, oblanceolate; flowers mildly fragrant, four-petals.
origin: Garden origin (A. caucasica x A. aubrietioides)

keyFeatures: Exfoliating reddish-brown outer bark with a greenish-brown inner bark; fruit reddish-orange and bumpy.
Leaves long, narrow, linear and tightly packed to forma small clump that's usually less than 30 cm wide; florets pink and in compact clusters on erect scapes (peduncles) about 15 cm long.
Basal; leaves lanceolate,mid-green, <20 cm.long; flowers white, pink, hot pink, red, lilac; upright, 2 cm. flowers on <50 cm. petiole, large clusters.
Plants up to 30 cm tall; flowers daisy-like to 5 cm wide, yellow disk florets and blue-violet ray florets (may also be pink, violet-lavender, dark purple-black, or white-near white depending on cv.).
Florets small and numerous, purple to white, on pyramidal panicle; leaves 2-3x compound, leaflets toothed, rachis/ petiole dark-red and swollen at 'nodes'.
origin: Garden origin (A. chinensis x A. japonica x A. thunbergii and/ or x A. astilboides)
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves to 2 cm long, sparsely toothed margin, downy; flowers with four brightly coloured petals.
Deciduous barberry with dark maroon simple ovate, entire leaves to 2 cm long. Winter ID: unbranched spiny stipules.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves with fishtail-like apices.
Leaves ovate-lanceolate on stem, nettle-like, hairy, deeply-toothed; florets in loose racemes, 3-4 cm long.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves mostly basal, deeply lobed, oblanceolate (also unlobed, lanceolate, leaf-like bracts on peduncles); flowers tiny, white, on ling racemes; fruit green then brown, heart-shaped, 4-8 x 3-5 mm.
Leaves broad-oval, finely-toothed, to 8 cm long; flowers scented, powder blue in panicles 10-13 cm long from June to Sept.
origin: Garden origin (C. americanus - native to eastern U.S. X C. coeruleus - native to Mexico)

keyFeatures: Leaves pinnately-lobed and irregularly to deeply divided (sometimes appearing as false leaflets but midrib blase tissue present at least near the apex), lower surface covered in silver hairs; flower heads appear shaggy, up to 7 cm wide.
Dense, round head-like inflorescences of white flowers in late summer.
Large conifer with shaggy growth habit; leaf scales narrow, dark-green; cones round, about 6 cm wide with a ruffled appearance.
Leaves palmately compound with 4 or 5 dark, narrow leaflets with entire margins; flowers showy, in clusters of white 5 petalled flowers with pale pink and green calyx; orange fragrance.
origin: Garden origin (C. ternata x C. dumosa var. arizonica)

keyFeatures: Leaves rough with red tinged, very ruffled margins and curled tips; flowers with 5 white petals and yellow stamens.

Suckering; leaves alternate, serrated with less than 40 teeth per side, to 10 cm long; flowers fragrant, white (or pink cv.), racemes, <15 cm, late summer. Winter ID: leaf scar almost circular, raised bundle scars; buds small, red, wart-like; capsules brown, oval, persistent.

Leaves alternate, serrated with over 60 teeth per side, dark green, to 13 cm long; florets small, fragrant, white, in racemes to 15 cm long in late summer and autumn. Winter ID: mature specimens have attractive peeling bark.
Tall, open scrub; leaves dark green with glaucous undersides; ovate to obovate, to 6 cm long; flowers yellow with purple antthers on pendant racemes to 15 cm long.

Popular hedge plant; leaves ovate to elliptic, dull green, pubescent on both sides early in season, to 5 cm long; flowers small, 5-petaled, white flowers with tinges of pink bloom in spring; fruit slowly changing from green to red to black by fall, persistent.
Foliage several shoots fused/flattened into 'cockscombs'; leaves awl-shaped; bark red-brown, scented, peels in strips; female cones globose.
Leaves of juvenile foliage only, needle-like, green in summer and dark red-purplish in winter.
Bark red-brown, exfoliating; leaves grey-green, point forward in 5-ranked spirals around shoots. Winter ID: leaves turn bronze.
Leaves silver-gray, trifoliate, pubescent; florets in cone-shaped, terminal racemes, pineapple-scented, deep yellow.
Branches green; leaves elliptic-obovate, pubescent, up to 1 cm long.
origin: Garden origin (C. multiflorus x C. purgans 'Allgold')

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, obovate to elliptic, leathery, glossy, dark green with yellow margins, up to 10 cm; flowers highly fragrant, reddish-purple with pale pink to white insides, February to March.
Leaves ovate, downy texture, margins entire and wavy, up to 20 cm long; flowers up to 19 cm long, each opening just once at night, highly fragrant; fruit downy and spiny,

Leaves simple, alternate to basal, most palmately veined with 5-7 toothed lobes; flowers bilaterally symmetrical, petals usually 4-5, sepals showy and petal-like with the posterior one forming a spur.
origin: Garden origin (mountainous areas world-wide except Australia)

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite, lanceolate, up to 7 cm long; florets white, bell-shaped, fragrant, in racemes up to 7 cm long.
Leaves opposite, ovate, with fine teeth and fuzzy on both sides; florets white, in panicles in late spring.
Slender herbaceous perennial; leaves blue-gray, lanceolate, opposite on swollen nodes; flowers radial, sessile, in dense cymose clusters, most vibrant purple-pink with clove-like scent.
Plant forming a mat-like evergreen ground cover; leaves linear.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Compact, spreading mat, up to 30 cm tall; leaves linear, gray-green, evergreen, up to 10 cm long..

Leaves 3-4 times divided, tip segments linear to oblong, pointed; inflorescence of 5-15 florets in a drooping panicle; pinkish-purple; capsules pod-like, 2-3.5 cm long, 3-4 mm wide with shiny black seeds about 2 mm long with elaiosomes for ant dispersal.
petalColour: ivory white flowers held above ferny

keyFeatures: Leaves basal with long petioles, blades cordate with scalloped margins; leaves on stem apetalate and sheathing; flower heads yellow with many long narrow ray corollas.

Leaves alternate, lanceolate, smooth margin, dense covering of silvery to rusty scales, 4–9 x 1-2.5 cm; flowers in clusters of 1-3, 1 cm long with a four-lobed creamy yellow calyx, early summer; fruit 1-1.7 cm long, orange-red when ripe, covered in silvery scales.

Leaves palmately compound (reminiscent of Virginia creeper), with a single spiny stipule at most nodes, umbels of small inconspicuous greenish-white florets in spring, berries on pollinated female plants dark-red ripening black.
Leaves mostly crowded near the branch ends, elliptic, serrate; flowers bell shaped, about 1 cm long.
Low growing deciduous perennial; leaves biternate, with heart-shaped toothed spiney leaflets; flower sepals pink to red, petals white.
Leaves compound with triangular to heart shaped leaflets; flowers white to pink.
origin: Garden origin (E. diphyllum x E. grandiflorum)
petalColour: (cv. Roseum has dusky pink to purple flowers)

keyFeatures: Ground cover with bright yellow flowers with short brown spurs in spring.
origin: Garden origin (E. perralderianum x E. pinnatum subsp. colchicum )

keyFeatures: Very similar to E. carnea but more vigorous, up to 1 m tall; leaves very similar to E. carnea, linear, in whorls of 4, about 8 mm x 1 mm wide; flowers pink to mauve, or white, many cultivars available that mostly bloom between November and May.
origin: Garden origin (E. carnea x E. erigena)

keyFeatures: An erect spore bearing vascular plant with whorls of narrow jointed branches at nodes; leaves reduced to crown-like whorl at nodes; strobili formed on tips or on separate fertile shoots connected by rhizomes.
Leaves usually glandular, in whorls of four; flowers small, pink bell-shaped, drooping, in compact clusters at the ends of its shoots, Aug-Oct.
Leaves mostly basal (also on branched stems), rounded, white veined; flowers silvery-blue with narrow, spiny silver bracts.
Leaves narrow, grayish green; florets purplish, up to 2 cm wide, in racemes.
origin: Garden origin (an old hybrid of unknown parentage - possibly E. x linifolium)

keyFeatures: Leaves oblong to 8 cm long; flowers with single set of petals, arranged in racemes (corymb-like in some cvs).

E. 'Chameleon' is mounded; leaves/stems burgundy/purple, leaves oblong, white midrib; flowers yellow-green cymes. 'Excalibur' evergreen, upright mound; leaves blue-green/purple margins/white midrib; flowers chartreuse, mid summer.
Leaves pinnately compound, finely-divided, leaflets to 2 cm long; florets small, white (pink in bud), fragrant, and in astilbe-like panicles.
Leaves to 8cm long, undulating, serrate, and point downward; fruit appears like a 4-sided spiky capsule. Winter ID: Typical 1.5 cm spear-like beech buds.
Leaves oval with rippled margin; raceme of white to pink-tinged bottlebrush flowers in May; axillary buds protected by off-white stipule. Winter ID: buds stalked, fuzzy.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves with 11 serrated, lanceolate to elliptical, sessile, acuminate leaflets; golden yellow fall colour. Winter ID: buds, blue-black, opposite, 5 mm rounded/ flattened on stem side.

Leaves with 5-9 finely serrated leaflets that are 5–10 cm long x 2-4 cm wide. pinnate, 20-30 cm long; flowers in dense panicles 10-20 cm long after leaves, each floret has four slender creamy white petals 5-6 mm long. Winter ID: bark smooth, dark grey; buds pale pinkish-brown to grey-brown, with a dense covering of short grey hairs.

Low, creeping, evergreen groundcover; leaves thick, ovate, with very faint serrate margins and a wintergreen scent when crushed, dark green but may have a reddish tint in winter. Winter ID: fleshy red fruit that persist in winter with wintergreen taste.
Leaves opposite, lobed to deeply incised, venation palmate.
Leaves 6-8 cm wide; flowers 3-4 cm wide, petals pinks with shallow notch.
Leaves basal, cordate, lobed, toothed, 15-20 cm wide, stem leaves smaller; flowers petals purplish-pink with black veins and spot, 3 cm wide, June to August.
Leaves with five lobes with each split into three large teeth; flowers of species purple 2.5-4 cm.
Leaves mostly compound with largest leaflet at tip; flowers petals large and usually orange (semi-doubled in some cvs.), many pistils forming achenes.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Internodes short; leaves opposite and each pair rotated by 90 degrees at each node, about 1 cm x 4 mm wide; raceme of tightly packed white florets.
Leaves soft, flexible; flowers white/yellow in June. Winter ID: fruit 4 section , spear tip, persistent over winter, tan when ripe; terminal bud absent; superposed, slightly stalked, scaled.

An evergreen trailing plant; flowers saucer-shaped in loose terminal clusters, bright yellow, stamens bright orange and in tight cluster that is sensitive to touch (spread outwards to reveal the tall stigma in the middle).

Plants with features similar to canna, bird of paradise, and banana; leaves of most locally grown indoor species are 15-100 cm long, elliptic to ovate; inflorescence erect or drooping, spike-like with florets mostly enclosed in brightly coloured bracts and 6 tepals.
Short-lived perennial similar to sunflower; leaves ovate, toothed, to 15 cm long; flowers daisy-like to 7 cm wide, rays yellow-orange, disk florets brownish-yellow.
Leaves basal, rounded, lobed, palmate venation, cordate bases.
origin: Garden origin (H. sanguinea x H. americana x H. micrantha)

keyFeatures: Compact form for bed edges; leaves not variegated.
Leaves basal, ovate, glaucous.
origin: Garden origin (Hosta sieboldiana x Hosta nakaian)
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves basal, linear; florets fragrant, narrowly tubular to campanulate, six violet-blue tepals, or occasionally white, in spring on arching racemes.
Leaves large, opposite, serrated, ovate; florets in large white corymb-like cymes. Winter ID: bark peels off in several successive thin layers with different colors.
Leaves thick, leathery, deeply lobed akin to an oak leaf, autumn colour from brilliant red to purple; raceme of white florets, 4 petals; bark slightly exfoliating, smooth; new growth is hairy.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: (the sterile flowers become pink-tinged with age)

keyFeatures: Flowers with long spindly white tepals, stamens connected with a thin funnel shaped white membrane.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves very spiny, simple with yellow to white margins and covered in pink-tinged white spines; new branch growth vibrant purple; old growth whitish-gray, woody.
Stem purplish; leaves glossy, ovate, dark green, most with entire margins; fruit persistent red "berries".
Stiffly upright sword-shaped leaves, 60-90 cm long with a sheathing base; flowers are a large single spike with "beard" or fuzz at the interface of the three upright and three dropping petals.
origin: Garden origin (Iris spp. x I. germanica)

keyFeatures: Leaves long, narrow; flowers, with 3 (or 4) large flat, spreading or pendent fall petals, alternating with 3 erect, often smaller, standard petals, in late winter, spring or early summer.
Leaves trifoliate, leaflets sessile; flowers yellow, wisteria-like, in pendulous racemes, spring.
origin: Garden origin ( L. alpinum x L. anagyroides)

keyFeatures: Leaves toothed, lobed almost to midrib with largest lobes towards the apex, up to 25 cm long; flower heads < 1 cm wide comprised of 5 golden-yellow ray florets; achenes with silver-gray hairs.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Stems fluted with reddish lines; leaves narrow with sparsely serrate margins; heads with white ray florets have slight lobes in the ends of the petals, disc florets bright yellow.
Leaves thick, shiny, dark green, turn purplish-bronze in winter; flowers clustered, urn-shaped, white.
Leaves dull green, lance-shaped; flowers small, white, unpleasantly scented, formed in summer in cymose panicles (thryse), fruit small, dark purple to black, berry (poisonous).
origin: Europe (also from N. Africa and W. Asia)

keyFeatures: Flowers with four large white petals followed with large, flatened oval-shaped fruit.
Leaves opposite, ovate, rugose, toothed; floret petals fused with lower ones pouch-like, very showy.
Large upright colourful racemes and palmately compound leaves with 9-17 leaflets.
Flowers mostly with 9 thick tepals with a citrus-lemon fragrance, early to late spring,

Leaves to 15 cm long with pointed tip and ciliate margins; flowers with 6 tepals, white with pink tinge appearing before leaves in April. Winter ID: graceful habit, usually multi-stemmed, broken twigs with strong odour; persistent or dropped irregular shaped fruit.

Leaves ovate, dark green, grayish beneath, flowers nodding, 6-9(-12) tepals, white with pink to crimson stamens, cup-shaped, fragrant, most 7-10 cm wide, fruit aggregate pink-red before turning brown as the follicles open to reveal their single orange-red seed. s. Winter ID: habit spreading, vase shaped, buds opposite, boat shaped, felty; lenticels whitish.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
fruitColour: (eventually releasing some orange seed before dropping)

keyFeatures: Vigorous hybrid; flowers star-shaped, up to 8 cm wide with (9-) 11-13 (-18) long, narrow, pink to white, fragrant tepals appearing before the leaves; fruit small, orange-red. Winter ID: buds large, hairy; branch bark ridge very prominent.
origin: Garden origin (M. kobus x M. stellata)

keyFeatures: Leaves are ovate, slightly serrated, and have green fading to reddish-purple foliage in spring.
fruitColour: (Usually the common apples are green or red
however ther are some that are slightly yellow.)

keyFeatures: Leaves compound, each with three oval leaflets, center leaflet usually has a longer petiole, toothed toward the tip,and end in a short point; flowers small, yellow, grouped in compact racemes, 2-4(-8) mm wide.
Up to 2 m tall; leaves with white midrib.
Small for maiden grass - only up to 60 cm tall in flower; leaves mid-green with white midrib.
Tall grass (1.2 m); leaves narrow (0.5 cm), linear, lighter grayish-green, variegated with a white midrib.
Leaves only about 6 mm wide.
Leaves 9-13 mm wide; flowers red turning creamy-white.
Leaves about 2 cm wide, dark green with thin white midrib; flowers large, feathery, silvery-pink, well above leaves.
Stems wiry, chocolate brown; leaves alternate, nearly round, mid-green, about 1.5 cm long with red petioles.
Leaves large, leathery, lanceolate, with a very wavy margin and the entire leaf curls inward.
Leaves lance-shape to ovate, acute, leathery, dark green; flowers white, tubular, in dense auxillary clusters; fruit ellipsoid, blue-black.
Medium sized evergreen shrub with graceful arching branches; leaves are small, thick, curved, dark green, finely toothed, and opposite; flowers small, white, fragrant, early spring.

Leaves dark green, elliptic, up to 12 cm long; florets white but partially covered by and protrude from showy, overlapping golden yellow bracts that somewhat resemble the overlapping scales on a 4-sided inflorescence (resembles a shrimp).

Leaves light green, undersides glaucous pale green, compound, leaflet deeply divided or incised; flowers three to four on each shoot, the axil of the leaves,10-12 cm wide, pedicels 5-9 cm long, May - early June; 4 or 5 lance-shaped bracts associated with each flower.

Leaves large (petioles up to 1 m, blades to 0.5 m), mostly arrow-head shaped, arising from submerged rhizome; floret tiny in spadix with whitish to greenish to yellow spathe; fruit a brown berry containing a few seeds within a clear gelatinous pulp.
Dense ground cover with 6 cm, spatulate; leaves mid-green with a strong, creamy midrib; florets in a 5 cm long pink raceme in summer.

Stems compressed; leaves alternate, broadly elliptic to obovate, margin entire, glossy, dark green; florets with 5 tepals plus lip (modified lower petal), in raceme on long sturdy green peduncle, very long lasting (some species resemble months).
Exfoliating bark on upright stems; leaves opposite, ovate, 4-6 course serrations on each margins, about 7-11 cm long; flowers aromatic, lasting 2-3 weeks.

Upright, weeping branches; needles 12-20(-25) mm long, 4 sided, greyish-blue green above with several thin lines of stomata, and blue-white below with two broad bands of stomata; female cones pendulous, slender, ovoid-cylindric, 3-6(-11) cm long x 1.5 cm wide when closed and 2.5 cm when open, scales thin and flexible, to 15 mm long, with a smoothly rounded margin; seeds black, 2-3 mm long, with a slender, pale brown wing 5-8 mm long.
Weeping form; needles 8-12 cm long, 2 per fascicle.
Leaves odd-pinnately compound, resembling ladders; flowers usually deep blue in terminal cymes.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Medium sided tree; flowers bright white, 5-petaled, spring; fruit red (or yellow or black) plums, July.

Exfoliating bark; leaves elliptic, serrated margin; flowers solitary, petals white and about 1 cm long; drupes oval shaped, cherries 1 cm long. Winter ID: buds clusters; leaf scars half-round to elliptical.
