Leaves dark red; flowers pink in early spring; fruit dark red, cherry like but almost plums in summer. Winter ID: Small tree with open,, rounded crown to 10 m tall; buds alternate, red, oblong, pointed; twigs dark red.
Branches weeping; leaves serrated with an acute tip that tilts sideways; flowers pink, showy, solitary. Winter ID: buds appressed, about 2 mm long; terminal buds 2-3 per cluster.

Leaves basal, long-stalked, elliptical, bristly-pubescent, mottled with white spots or blotches, up to 30 cm long; florets nodding with 5 bluish petals that emerge pinkish, in branched terminal cymes, about 1.5 cm wide.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, clustered, apex 3-lobed, pubescent, most 1-2 cm long; flowers with about 25 stamens, petals 5-9 mm long, creamy-yellow; achenes about 15 mm long with a persistent style. Winter ID: woolly young twigs.
Leaves elliptic, ovate, serrated; bark is grey-brown/flat ridges at the top, red-brown branches. Winter ID: buds scaly, slightly tomentose, acute.
petalColour: (Various cream colours in white and pink.)

keyFeatures: Round-form oak tree; leaves toothed, lanceolate, about 20 cm long. Winter ID: buds black-brown, small, with overlapping small scales.
Loose, open oak tree; leaves about 15 cm long, dull, margins variable, base taper toward the petiole; Winter ID; Buds have one or more thick hairs that resemble the hook on a bur.
Buttercup 50-90 cm tall; leaves compound with three lobed leaflets, terminal leaflet sessile; flowers glossy, 2.5 cm wide.
Flowers pure white in May.

Small evergreen; leaves narrowly elliptic, to 6 cm long, dark green; flowers vivid reddish-purple with darker blotch should be hose in hose (specimen shown and on campus has the outer hose is partially formed).
origin: Garden origin (R. yedoense var. poukhanense x R. 'Hexe')

keyFeatures: Dwarf; flowers purple, in large trusses.
Medium sized typical rhododendron; leaves large, flowers large and red in May.

Leaves glossy, 15-45 cm long, long-stalked, alternate and palmate with 5-12 deep lobes with coarsely toothed segments; panicle-like inflorescence up to 15 cm long with lower male and upper female flowers, reddish stigmas and or bracts; fruit a spiny capsule about 2 cm wide.
Compact with dense foliage; leaves glossy, dark green; flowers pink, double.
origin: Garden origin (R. sempervirons x R. Marthe Caron) x R. Picasso)

keyFeatures: Dense clusters of pale pink 5-petaled flowers to 4 cm across; reddish-brown prickles to 5 mm long that tend to curve downwards.
origin: Garden origin (hybrid by J.A. Bentall in1937

keyFeatures: Shrub rose; flowers clustered to 8 cm wide, milk-white, with stamens that turn pink to yellow.

Low to medium shrub, 0.5-2 m tall, spreading by rhizomes and sometimes thicket-forming; stems spindly to stout, erect to spreading, usually with a pair of straight or slightly curved prickles near the base of the leaves, often with weak internodal prickles or bristles especially on young shoots; mature stems reddish- to greyish-brown; leaflets 1.5-5 cm long, short- or glandular-hairy to smooth beneath, coarsely single-toothed, the teeth not gland-tipped; inflorescence of 1 to 5 stalked flowers in a small, short cluster at the end of a lateral branchlet; corollas pink, saucer-shaped, rather small (3-5 cm across), the petals 5, 12-25 mm long; calyces 5-lobed, the lobes lanceolate, long-tapering and narrowing then flaring below the tip, 10-20 mm long; fruits are achenes, numerous, stiffly long-hairy on one side, enclosed by fleshy accessory tissue, which ripens into a dark red, globe-shaped to ellipsoid hip 6-12 mm long. (Source: E-Flora BC)
Thicket forming, spindly; leaves with three leaflets, margins lobed, toothed, and serrated.

Leaves either basal or alternating up stem, up to 15 cm long, sessile with rounded bases; flower head disk florets tubular forming an elongated cone, ray florets absent, leaf-like bracts somewhat showy.
Leaves mostly with 5 coarsely serrated leaflets; flowers white to pinkish in corymbs; fruit a oval black drupe up to 6 mm wide
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves linear, 20-60 cm long x 1–4 cm wide; florets about 1.5 cm wide, 6 blue tepals (also purple and white cvs.), on a dense raceme.
Leaves arsing from soil, linear, about 15 cm x 1 cm; raceme of blue florets on reddish scape.
Leaves tube shaped, spirally arranged and arising from the stem in six directions when viewed from the tip.
Leaves are spoon-shaped, toothed, glossy deep green; flowers yellow; fruit orange-red.
Thicket-forming shrub; leaves compound, 13-21 leaflets, lanceolate, serrated, sessile, dark green; florets about 1 cm wide, 5 white petals, hundreds per panicle.

Shrub or tree up to 10 m tall; leaves pinnately compound up to 25 cm long. leaflets 11-15 (-17) oblong-lanceolate, serrate, pointed, grey-green undersides with some pubescence; florets white, in corymbs up to 14 cm wide; fruit red, clustered; pomes scarlet-red, 5-8 mm wide. Winter ID: buds valvate, swollen, and sticky; leaf scars crescent shaped.
Branches woolly, reddish-brown; leaves narrowly oblong, dark green/densely tomentose underneath, toothed at tips; flowers dense panicles, purple-pink, early summer, bowl-shaped.
Leaves dark bluish-green, ovate to almost sound, coarsely toothed (three distinct lobes not so obvious); flowers white, small (8 mm wide), numerous, in corymb-like cymes in May.

Mounds 5-8 cm high, semi-shrubby; stems slender, hairy; leaves small, softly hairy, fleshy, elliptic to ovate leaves that occur in whorls of three. The single or paired tubular flowers occur on slender stalks, arising from the upper leaf axils. They are very attractive with a white tube contrasting with lilac-mauve, violet-like lobes. The three lower petal lobes are larger than the upper two. The flowers are small in size, but are produced continuously throughout the spring and summer months, even into winter when growing conditions are favourable.

Deciduous tree; bark red-brown, fibrous, exfoliating; leaves single or multiple compound pinnate in varied sizes with soft, needle-like leaflets; female cones green, spherical; buds are invisible to the naked eye; roots poke out above water surface like knees.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Dwarf; scale leaves bright golden green.

A dense, conical shrub usually <2 m tall; leaves scale-like, yellowish-green, in flattened sprays; seed cones oval, up to 2 cm long; bark reddish-brow. branchlets being two-ranked in a vertical plane.

Leaves in whorls of 5-9 (at top of a usually green stem 5-20 cm tall), most elliptic to oblanceolate, entire margins glabrous, 3-8 cm long x 1-2 cm wide; flowers about 1 cm wide, with (5-)6(-7) long white petals and 5 shorter green sepals.
Leaves in a whorl of 3 on top of a smooth green stem, mostly ovate, 5-18 cm long, unstalked or with short petioles, margins entire, die back in summer.
Leaves are blue-green, about 3 cm long, turning bright red in the fall; flowers are urn shaped, white.
Leaves three-lobed, maple-like; fruit round, single seeded drupe, bright red.
Leaves ovate, margins toothed, up to 5 cm wide x 11 cm long; florets white, about 12 mm wide, in dense, rounded cymes, 6-10 cm wide, highly fragrant.
origin: Garden origin (V. carlesii x V. macrocephalum var. keteleeri)

keyFeatures: Leaves ovoid, simple, opposite; inflorescence is off-white terminal corymb; bark has prominent lenticels. Winter ID: flower buds occur in large terminal clusters; buds soft, elliptical, yellowy and upright.
origin: Garden origin (V. utlile x V. carlesii)

keyFeatures: Leaves basal, fleshy, ribbed, velvety, and arranged in a floating rosette.
Leaves palmately compound with 5 doubly serrated ovate leaflets; flowers white to blushed pink; fruit and plant very similar to Himalayan blackberry but lacks prickles and spines.
Small, mounding perennial found in full sun in rocky, poor soils; leaves spatulate, gray-green glaucus; flowers butter yellow with four petals and formed in a panicle.
Narrow columnar form; leaves bright green new growth and winter foliage.
Leaves 2 or 3 pinnate, leaflets obovate to spatulate, margins entire or 3-lobed; florets bright yellow, about 2 cm long, tubular, spurred.
Leaves arching, serrulate, long and narrow (some over 2 m and < 1 cm wide); spikelets in feathery, silvery panicles (also pinkish cvs.) up to 20 cm long, high above foliage.

Leaves ovate to elliptic to lanceolate, up to 25 cm x 8 cm, 2 or 3 per plant. florets nodding, bell-shaped, sweetly fragrant, white, in a one-sided raceme up to 20 cm long, April-May; fruit an orange-red poisonous berry with up to 6 seeds.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, glossy, with 3 or 5 deep lobes with teeth.

Leaves elliptic, pinnately compound, up to 12 cm long with 4 or 5 (-7) pairs of elliptic leaflets up to 3 cm long (may be linear in some cvs.); flowers yellow, pea-like in May. Winter ID: spiny stipules.

Leaves on mature trees are nearly round, 4-8 x 3-7 cm long, petiole flattened (larger and more triangular on young trees and suckers); catkins 4-6 cm long, early spring before leaves appear; fruit 10 cm long pendulous string of 6 mm wide capsules, each containing about 10 minute seeds embedded in cottony fluff for wind dispersal in early summer.
origin: North America (cooler areas or higher elevations)

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, ovate, margins scalloped, leathery, mostly hairless, blades 7-10 cm long petioles mostly 5-10 cm long; florets about 2 cm wide, in white in corymbs about 8 cm wide, late April to early May.
Leaves about 10 cm wide, 3-5 palmate lobes, coarsely toothed, pale underneath.
origin: North America (A. rubrum x A. saccharinum)

keyFeatures: Foliage is oval to lanceolate, alternate, and has a smooth margin; flowers bilaterally symmetrical with 5 petals.
Berries smaller and more elongated (most species) than for the sweet pepper.
Strong compact conical habit; needles to 15 mm long, sharp pointed, ridged; no comes.
Leaves oval to obovate, margins way to toothed, up to 15 cm long; flowers in the fall on woody twigs, four ribbon-like petals.
A dwarf evergreen azalea with attractive tiered branches; flowers funnel-shaped, hose-in-hose (two sets of petals, one inside the other), coral-pink to peach-pink to purplish; fruit absent (hybrid).
origin: S.E. Asia / Japan / China (Japan: R. sataense x R. kiusianum x ?)

keyFeatures: Usually grown as a winter fruiting decorative indoor plant; leaves glossy, dark green, elliptic with wavy margins, 5-8 cm long; fruit mildly poisonous if mistaken for cherry tomatoes.
Leaves ovate, usually with serrated leaf margins; flowers white, very fragrant; fruit a green-yellow lemon. Some images may be of another hybrid which has winged petioles.
origin: South Asia / India (most likely a hybrid - possibly of C. medica x C. aurantiifolia)

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, with (3-)5(-9) lobes, up to 10 cm long; flowers also up to 10 cm wide, with 10 white sepals, many blue or violet corona filaments; berries oval, dark orange, up to 6 cm long.
Leaves alternate, narrow, mostly elliptic, bluish green, up to 7(-10) cm long; catkins from April to May. Winter ID: twigs dark red to purplish.

Leaves alternate, simple, ovate to oblong, margin coarsely and sharply doubly serrated, bases conspicuously uneven, lower surface downy. Winter ID: buds ovate, over 6 mm long, reddish brown with darker edged scales.
Leaves opposite, usually with three forward pointing lobes; samaras green to red over summer before ripening in the fall.

Leaves palmately compound, 5 elliptic to slightly oblong leaflets with serrated margins, up to 20 cm long; flowers in erect panicles to 15 cm long; fruit a round capsule with 1 or 2 "buckeyes" surrounded by a leathery light brown husk. Winter ID: large terminal flower buds (not sticky and lighter colour compared to horse chestnut).
Flowers with 4 bright yellow petals, corymb-like raceme.

Bark non-exfoliating dark with wide, cherry-like lenticels (horizontal and wide), smooth and dark reddish-brown when young, becoming dark gray and scaly with age; leaves elliptical to ovate, 5-10 x 4-8 cm, margins finely single toothed or irregularly double toothed. Winter ID: bark; twigs smooth, reddish with strong wintergreen smell; buds also smooth (not hairy) and diverging from twigs.
Needles mostly 2 per fascicle, 8-15 cm long, stiff and brittle, snapping when sharply bent; buds ± reddish brown.
Deciduous; needles in bunches of 10-20, 2.5 cm long; female cones about 2cm long. Seedlings: 4-6 cotyledons; deciduous, 2.5 cm needles in bunches of 10-20.
Needles short (<2.5 cm), flat, tips rounded; leaf scars rounded; female cones with protruding, rounded bracts.

Needles 0.6-1.5(2) cm, 4-angled in cross section, rigid, pale blue-green, glaucous, bearing stomates on all surfaces, apex mostly blunt-tipped; female cones 1.5-2.5(-4) cm, scales fan-shaped, broadest near apex, 8-12 × 8-12 mm, dark purple ripening purple-brown (Conifers.org). Seedlings with 3-5 cotyledons.
Small thorny shrub of spreading habit; leaves glossy, obovate, 5 cm long; flowers 3.5 cm wide, deep crimson with prominent golden anthers.
Flat-topped; needles dark green, dense; male cones catkin-like, yellow-brown; female cones purple, barrel-shape.
Clump-forming rhizomatous perennial to 2 m tall; leaves bipinnate; flowers tiny, creamy-white in large terminal panicles.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: (male flowers white or creamy-white; female flowers greenish-white)

keyFeatures: Leaves large, basal (similar to Rodgersia); florets tiny, white, and in spikes (similar to astilbe).
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Rounded shrub; leaves are heart shaped (10 cm) long. Winter ID: half round leaf scar with small pointy chubby buds.
Leaves to 1 m, sword-shaped, tough and leathery with a sharp margin; racemes bottle brush-like, florets tubular with 6 red-orange and yellow tepals (like a 'rocket' popsicle).
petalColour: (red in bud then orange then fading to yellow)

keyFeatures: Stems about 90 cm tall; leaves alternate, lanceolate, reddish-purple; racemes bright, crimson red raceme with 4 cm long bilabiate florets.
petalColour: pink salomon/ cream and dark red cvs. also exist).)

keyFeatures: Leaves basal and then opposite on flowering stem, ovate, up to 25 cm long; florets, two shades of yellow, numerous, in compact whorled clusters.
Flowers are bright pink, spikes; 2 kinds of leaf: basal leaf is cordate with a very irregular, lobed, or incised margin; floral stalk leaf is linear.

Seedlings with 7-10 cotyledons; needles 5 per fascicle, 4-10 cm x 0.7-1 mm, blue-green, margins finely serrulate; female cones narrow, 10-25 cm long; seeds 5-7 mm long, wing 2-2.5 cm long. (Conifers.org)
Leaves ovate to obovate, hairy, <3 cm long; flower heads <2 cm wide with light blue ray florets and yellow centers, from June to frost.
Leaves alternately arranged, simple, 6-11 cm x 5-8 cm, most broadly elliptic, margin entire, densely pubescent; flowers, with five white or pink petals, 5 cm wide.
Leaves narrow, 3-4 cm long, sticky; flowers funnel shaped with white throat, opens with five petals (2 up, 2 down and out, 1 down the middle like a tongue).
Flower is bi-lateral with two nectar tubes protruding out the back (hence the name 'twinspur').

Leaves opposite, exstipulate, mostly reniform to orbicular, crenate, blades to 3 cm long, petioles often much longer; florets mostly 3 per node, lavender-blue with purple spots, Mar-July amongst leaf-like bracts.
Leaves in clusters at nodes; flower bilabiate (3 petals hanging like tongues, 2 more upright like open arms).
Creeping plant great for hanging baskets; leaves alternate, lanceolate, about 15 mm long, pointed tip; flowers blue to purple, bilaterally symmetrical with three upper petals and two lower petals.
Leaves opposite, lanceolate, sparsely toothed; flowers bilaterally symmetrical, white, pink, yellow, purple, back spur, throat with yellow palate, about 1 cm wide.
origin: Garden origin (most involve N. fruticans or N. strumosa)

keyFeatures: Small, +/- triangular shaped to linear, succulent leaves (initially tightly clustered) on upright stems.

Leaves alternate on flowering stems, obovate to spoon-shaped, 6-12 mm wide x 20-30 mm long; florets in terminal, umbrella-shaped clusters, petals 5, narrowly lanceolate and long-pointed, yellow then turning pinkish, (8) 10-13 mm long; follicles erect with bases slightly fused (modified from E-Flora BC).
Stems grass-like, three sided, green, with whorl of leaf-like bracts at tips that resemble umbrella spokes; flowers in greenish-brown clusters on or amongst the bracts.
Loose, tufted evergreen; leaves linear, deep green, 30 cm long, hairy margins; flowers are white, in clusters.
Leaves basal and then spiraled up flowering stock, s-shaped, margin whitish serrated; florets numerous, white, on panicle up to 60 cm tall, petals 6-10 mm long with reddish spots.
Leaves palmate, crenate, green on the outside and has purple palmate colouring in the middle (along the veins); florets in an upright white bottlebrush.
Leaves lobed, usually pubescent, green to reddish-green or purple-green in color and may have very long, gland-dotted petioles; florets pink, white, or greenish in an erect panicle to 1 m tall.

Leaves basal rosette in first year, stalked. lanceolate to elliptical, 12–15 cm long with serrated margins, upper leaves formed in second year smaller, lanceolate and sessile, almost embracing the stem; florets in a racemose inflorescence of extremely long lasting blooms, bell-shaped flowers with short pedicels, corolla has five fused petals with lightly bent lobes, violet-blue or rarely white.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Mounding herbaceous perennial; basal leaves are trifolate, deeply lobed, soft, and dentate; flowers small, 5-petaled light pink.
Often found emerging from concrete cracks and growing horizontally (prostrate); leaves opposite, mostly elliptical and less than 4 mm wide x 9 mm long.

Branches tiered; needles flat, dark green, 2 white lines underneath, spreading forward and upward, spirally arranged, most 1-2.5(-4.5) cm x 1-3 mm; female cones erect, ovoid-cylindrical, resinous, purple-grey before turning brown, most 8-10 cm x 4-5 cm with deciduous scales about 2x2 cm, finely pubescent, bracts shorty and usually hidden between the scales. Winter ID: buds small, spherical, brown, with violet wax.

Leaves palmate with 5 lobes deeply incised, dark red, looks like Canadian flag leaf; petiole is long, broken leaf veins or petiole ooze milky sap. Winter ID: buds opposite, large, plump green/burgundy; samaras held at wide angle.
Flowers golden yellow with enlarged corona and reduced perianth.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves tulip-like, basal leaves, usually <15 cm long, often mottled with gray or brown to purple, margins entire; flowers lily-like with 6 tepals, recurved upward, and close at night; capsules 12-15 mm long.
Needles in brush-like clusters, each with two stomatal bands, < 2 cm long; seed cones brown when mature, < 3 cm long. Winter ID: bark gray to rusty-brown, persistent cones, rounded buds.

Needles 12-20(-25) mm long, 4 sided, blue-green above with several thin lines of stomata, and blue-white below with two broad bands of stomata; female cones pendulous, slender, ovoid-cylindric, 3-6(-11) cm long x 1.5 cm wide when closed and 2.5 cm when open, scales thin and flexible, to 15 mm long, with a smoothly rounded margin; seeds black, 2-3 mm long, with a slender, pale brown wing 5-8 mm long.

Needles 5 per fascicle, 6-13 cm long x 1 mm wide, triangular in cross section (dark green on outer face and two inner faces with whitish green stomatal lines; female cones crowded near the ends of new shoots in groups of 1 to 5, green, ovoid, 9-11 cm x 5-6 cm wide, seeds wingless, about 15 mm long x 10 mm wide x 7 mm thick. (Conifersociety.org)
Needles 5 per fascicle, 4-6 cm long, stiff and twisted, appear in brush-like tuft on branches, glossy bluish-green color.

Shrub multi-stemmed, about 4 m tall; leaves dark green, aromatic, oblanceolate, alternate up the stem to terminal clusters, about 6 cm long; flowers in short spikes or catkins, April to July; fruit 1 cm wide, slightly waxy purple berry clusters, at nodes, Sept-October.
Dwarf rose <1 m tall; flowers cymose, abundant, pink, about 2.5 cm wide.
origin: Garden origin (hybrid tea rose crossed with a polyantha rose
the latter being derived from R. chinensis x R. multiflora)

keyFeatures: Leaves in first year basal, lance-shaped, shallow-toothed; about 5 cm wide x 10-20 cm long; leaves in the second year spirally arranged on stem arising from the rosette; florets with four yellow petals, in terminal panicles, and open at dusk; capsules pod-like and contain over 100 seeds.
Leaves glossy, rounded, margins serrated and most with 2 or 3 lobes, up to to 20 cm long; florets small, yellowish-green, in drooping catkins; multiple fruit on female trees are fused drupes.
fruitColour: (variety of colours may be on one plant as they usually ripen dark red to almost black)

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, 3-5 lobed, bright green; fruit a dark red berry but male plants are more commonly planted for their rust resistance.
Leaves 3 to 5-lobed, dark green to 5 cm long; flowers white in mid spring; fruits red pomes to 1.2 cm long.
petalColour: (cv. Paul's Scarlet has double bright crimson flowers)

keyFeatures: Stems are reddish-brown; leaves are waxy and slightly serrated; flowers white, urn-shaped; fruit - typical blue berries.
Leaves basal, 5-lobed, toothed; flowers yellow to orange, globe to bowl shaped 2.5-6 cm wide.
origin: Garden origin (Parentage may include T. europaeus
petalColour: (Trollius x cultorum 'Alabaster' has semi-double creamy yellow flowers)
fruitType: Follicle, Aggregate fruit, Aborted (hybrids) or absent

keyFeatures: Arching, pendulous branches; leaves deltoid to ovate, serrated; catkins narrow, bright green turning yellow, swollen flaky brown when mature. Winter ID: catkins persist; branches weeping; bark smooth then exfoliating with age, grayish-white with dark gray to black horizontal lenticels becoming larger spots; branch bark ridge long, almost black.
Compact, deciduous with very cold hardy buds; leaves elliptic to obovate, 2-3 cm wide x 7-9 cm long; flowers clustered, very bright colours in early spring; fruit usually do not form.
Multi-stemmed shrub to 3 m tall with peeling bark found in disturbed sites; flowers small, white and aromaic, but soon turn brown.

Leaves lance-shaped with parallel venation; umbel with bilaterally symmetrical florets, almost lily-like in a range of colours (pink and yellow common) with black flecks on 3 petals, sepals wider and with few or no spots.

Over 500 species but most locally sold are small epiphytes with firm or leathery leaves (other species with soft leaves may appear similar to Vriesea or a Guzmania); flowers tubular, violet, blue, red, or pink.
Often a shrubby tree with reddish young twigs; leaves 3-5 lobed, coarsely double-toothed; samara wings V-shaped to nearly parallel.
fruitColour: (often rose color before maturing to brown: hairless)

keyFeatures: Leaves narrow, woolly, silver-gray; flower heads tiny, white, globular with yellow disk florets centre and arranged in flattish corymbs in late-summer bloom.
Leaves shiny reniform, bases overlapping near petiole.
Spreading short-lived perennial to 30 cm tall; leaves small, finely divided bright green; flowers golden yellow "daisies" to 3 cm wide.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves linear, 1-2 cm long; flowers with 4-5 sepals and 4-5 small white petals (sometimes violet or absent).
Florets very small, densely packed, and bloom profusely throughout summer to fall in a feathery or in a brain coral-like inflorescence.
Leaves bipinnate, deeply cut into threadlike segments; flower heads separated, saucer-shaped, daisy-like, 5-10 cm wide.
Leaves alternate, ovate to lanceolate or elliptical, margins scalloped; florets on long racemes all summer long; capsules may form near peduncle while new flower buds open at tip.

Leaves basal, spoon-shaped to oblanceolate, blades more than 3 times as long as wide, gradually tapering to the short, broadly-winged petiole, up to 20 cm long; umbels with up to 20 nodding florets 1-2 cm long, with curved-back petals that are usually pink.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite, simple, ovate to obovate, petioles short, margins toothed towards apex, most 1-2 cm long; flowers in nodding pairs on Y-shaped stalks, corollas pink to purple, 1-1.5 cm long, flaring to 5 white-fringed lobes.
Grows from rhizomes; leaves basal; largest of any native plant in region, 0.3-1.4 m long and 30-80 cm wide; spadix (7-12 cm long) contained within a large, bright yellow or yellowish green spathe.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite, petioles short, blades ovate to oblong, serrate, up to 8 cm long, with fruiting smell and taste; florets in terminal spike, pink to white.
Small shrub; leaves opposite, oval, margins finely toothed, 3-7 cm long; flowers inconspicuous, greenish-white, 5 mm wide; fruit very show, pink with orange seeds.
Basal leaves spatulate, up to 30 cm long; stem leaves ovate, up to 20 cm long, sessile.

Leaves basal in its first year, deeply lobed to pinnified, once or twice on both sides of the center vein, with lobes oblong and wider toward the tip, up to 20 cm long x 5 cm wide; flower heads purple to pink, rarely white, with 25 to 35 florets per head, bracts have black margins or "spots", inflorescence 20 cm to over 1 m tall, branching with leaf-like bracts.
Leaves arrow shaped; florets white in racemes with triangular peduncles in summer.
Leaves alternate, 3(-5) lobed; flowers up to 10 cm wide, with 10 coloured sepals, many corona filaments, 5 large stamens, and pistil with 3 stigma branches.
Stems with vertical ribbing; leaves softly textured, alternate, compound with highly dissected tri-pinnate leaflets formed from a sheathing base and a distinctive scent.
Flowers blue with white eyes in spring, to 5 mm wide (similar to forget-me-knot).
Leaves are elliptic, 2-7 cm long, silvery on both sides due to dense small white scales; flowers yellow, with a four-lobed corolla 6-14 mm long; drupes oval, 9-12 mm long, silver.
Weak thorns on older stems to 2 cm long; variegated cultivars mostly with green margins (unlike E. x ebbingei 'Gilt Edge').

Broadly conical, often multi-stemmed, branching open irregular and angular; leaves small, triangular, crinkly, margins irregularly and minutely toothed, medium green. Winter ID: buds tiny, dark, have a white wax-like coating; branches alternate, zigzag; young shoots downy.
Leaves elliptic, lustrous dark green, crenulate; stems are pubescent (compared to C. japonica which is glabrous).
Leaves lanceolate, mostly less than 25 cm long; flowers pink, with a hooded shape, 3-4 cm tall x 2 cm wide.

Stems up to 4 m in length, becoming very woody; leaves compound with 5(-7) lance-shaped, leaflets, 5-6 cm long (may be lobed); flowers lemon-yellow, nodding, with four petal-like sepals (bell-shaped at first and then split as the petals spread); achenes oval to 5 mm long with tails to about 5 cm long.

Leaves mostly opposite (or less commonly in whorls of three), sessile, lance-shaped, downy, up to 2.5 cm wide x 13 cm long; florets up to 2 cm wide, pink-magenta, in dense terminal spikes up to 45 cm long.

Leaves covered with fuzzy white hairs, spatulate when basal to linear when alternating on stem; female plant heads about 12 mm wide and darker pink then male plant flower heads which are about 6 mm wide.
Leaves long, narrow, and toothed; florets small and tightly clustered in racemes.
Leaves elliptic-ovate to linear, 0.5-2 cm long, green or silvery-grey, acrid or pungant taste (sharp biting), visible pores on the upper leaf surface that look like pin-pricks.
Leaves pinnate up to 1.2 m long, spiraling from a fibrous stem base, leaflets 25 cm long x 1 cm wide.
Leaves alternate with long petioles, reniform to elliptic with cordate base and rounded apex, about 10 cm wide x 15 cm long (may also form tripinnately compound leaves with similar leaflets).
Semi-aquatic; stems hollow; leaves kidney-shaped, toothed; flowers are buttercup-like.

Stems square; leaves opposite (rarely whorled or alternate), clasping stem, lanceolate, mid-green; flowers bright blue/reddish throat/short yellow anthers, 5 petals, <1.5 cm spread, four flowers on long petiole based in leaf axil.
Leaves bright green, deeply divided, <8 cm long, filiform, oblanceolate, acute; flowers mauve, pink or white ray florets, disk florets yellow, <2 cm across, long peduncle.
Leaves hairy, dark green, ovate-laneolate, pointed; flowers tubular to 3 cm long, calyx rose-red to pink-violet; petals paired, red, ear-like (bat face like).
origin: Garden origin (C. llavea x C. procumbens)

keyFeatures: Upright stiff bush; Leaves are 3-lobed and dark red-purple.

Leaves pubescent with petioles up to 6.5 cm long that wrap around structures to climb, blades triangular to heart-shaped, most 5-10(-15) cm long by about 6 cm wide, margins toothed (each one may have a few smaller sharply pointed teeth); flowers with five petals, forming a tube about 5-6 cm long; fruit a round capsule.
Leaves opposite, glossy, about 2 cm long; flower tubular, yellow and red (resemble corn candy).
Leaves are 1cm by 1mm golden, succulent and arranged spirally.
Clump forming; leaves long, strap-shaped (hollow but flattened in c.s.) and from a single tuft (basal).
Leaves compound, feathery; florets small white (- pinkish), in compound umbels; achenes crescent-shaped, with 5 ridges, about 2 mm long.
Leaves are very fine, less than 3 cm wide; flowers sparse, white with yellow disk florets.
Leaves and floral stalks rise from a 1 cm yellow bulb.
Leaves opposite, ovate, up to 7 cm long, and smell of lemons when crushed; flowers axial, small, pale yellow to white, two-lipped, about 1 cm long.
Prostrate; leaves oval, evergreen, 3-8 mm long; flowers strongly scented, 4-6 mm long.
Forms a very dense, silver mound; flowers about 2 cm wide, bright pink (petals appear torn on the tips) and are raised above foliage
Fan-like arrangement of leaves (tight at the base), light grayish-green with one-sided creamy variegation.
Rigid, upright, 80 cm high; stems narrow, round, dark-green linear; leaves small, narrow, often reduced to basal sheaths.
Multi-stemmed deciduous tree; Leaves are medium-green elliptical, 15cm and have stipules; Winter ID: 2mm buds are adpressed and look like yellow duckbills.
Aquatic floating plant; leaves hear-shaped, about 30x20 cm; flowers yellow, cup-shaped.
Leaves pinnately divided with 3 to 7 oval leaflets, entire to wavy-edged; flowers to 6 mm wide in terminal clusters, white; fruit a silique with tips curved upwards.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Stems wiry stiff, 4-angled; florets mauve-purple in cymose clusters at tips of a long, branching peduncle.
Leaves ovate to elliptic, most about 7 x 3 cm; flower heads with 8-10 yellow tubular ray florets that open up flat with maturity.
Moderately dense ground cover; leaves basal, mid-green, spatulate, purple-white at the base; heads with yellow disk florets and commonly pinkish to lavender ray florets.
petalColour: (mauve ray flowers and yellow (turning brown) disc flowers)

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite, ovate, grey-green, fuzzy texture, blades about 15 cm long; inflorescence corymb-like cyme with florets at center blue to purple (fertile), surrounded by sterile white (or sometimes pink to mauve) florets in late summer to autumn.
Leaves heart shaped, most with with 3, 5, or 7 lobes, up to 20 cm long; florets on a rigid raceme with leaf-like bracts up to 2 m tall.

Leaves alternate, leaflets 3, egg- to heart-shaped, 5-15 mm long, shallowly toothed on the upper half, glabrous; inflorescence a dense, globe-shaped, short-stalked, axillary head of 3 to 20 drooping, pea-like flowers, the heads 6-8 mm wide and lacking an involucre; corollas yellow turning brown, 3-3.5 mm long, the banner hood-like, folded over the pod, longer than the wings and keel; calyces 1/2 as long as the corollas, glabrous, 5-veined, the teeth lanceolate, the upper pair wider but less than 1/2 as long as the lower three; legumes egg-shaped, enclosed by the persistent corolla; seeds 1. (E-flora BC)
Leaves dark green, ovate 12-25 cm x 10-18 cm wide, with 3 or 5 lobes; florets enclosed in hollow stem; fruit obovate, mostly 4-7 cm long, green, ripening to purplish-brown (syconium).
petalColour: (must cut open immature 'fruit' to see the flowers.)

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite, broadly elliptic to above, matings entire, thick, glossy, and dark green; flowers waxy white, highly fragrant, narrow-tubular with five flaring lobes.
Flower heads cone-shaped, composed of dense-packed yellowish-green corollas, and lacking ray-florets, have a chamomile/pineapple aroma when crushed.
origin: North America (and N.E. Asia but now cosmopolitan)

keyFeatures: Leaves sessile with two rounded lobes at the base of the stem (auriculate) and sub-clasping above; flower heads ray-less with 8 to 10 small cylinder shaped disc florets (6 to 13 mm) above a conspicuous ring of black tipped bracts forming the base of the inflorescence.
inflorescence: Small heads arranged in a cyme

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, narrowly elliptical, grayish, rolled under with rusty hairs on the underside.
Rounded pimpinellifolia shrub with upright canes; flowers fragrant, pale yellow; fruit hips orange.
Leaves long and linear; florets lily-like with 6 tepals, produced daily.
Low growing compact shrub rose with a creeping habit that is often grown as a ground cover; flowers red, pink, or white.
origin: Garden origin (R. 'Sea Foam' x (R. 'Picasso' x R. 'Maceye'))
petalColour: (Cultivars of these three flower colours were planted in th parking islands in the BCE area. It appears some were transplanted to the LCA and HPZ area.)

keyFeatures: Leaves linear-lanceolate, up to 20 cm long, margins wavy; flowers clustered at stem tips, drooping, 6 tepals, bell-shaped, usually orange (yellow or red cvs.).
origin: Central / west Asia (South Turkey to Kashmir)

keyFeatures: Needles 5 per fascicle, 7-15 cm long, finely serrated (unlike P. flexilis), bluish-green; cones up to 35 cm long.

Needles spreading radially, ascending on upper side of branchlets, spreading and curved upward on lower side, quadrangular, slightly curved, 13-30×2 mm, stomatal lines on all surfaces; female cones green, maturing brown-yellow, oblong-cylindric, 6-9×2.5-3.5 cm, seed scales obovate, 1.6×1.2 cm, striate on exposed part, apex rounded or triangular, seeds 3.5 mm with a 10 mm wing. (Conifers.org)
Leaves opposite, obovate; flowers paired, tubular, yellow, in spring, bracts turning dark red; berries purplish-black.
Leaves in a rosette with flower stalks that rise up over the foliage.
Leaves large and increasing in size towards top of plant, bright green, opposite, ovate with miniature leaves between sets of large leaves; stem thick and fleshy.

Leaves alternate, pinnately compound, most with 11 leaflets that are ovate, toothed; florets with yellow and red petals in long panicles; capsules gradually turn from green to reddish to brown, papery, about 3 cm long. Winter ID: irregular branching pattern, globular buds on fuzzy brown twigs, persistent brown papery capsules.
origin: S.E. Asia / Japan / China ((China and Korea))

keyFeatures: Variable species but most with yellowish exfoliating bark (peals off horizontally), becoming grayish with age; leaves 6-12 (-16) x 4-9 cm, ovate and double-serrate; twigs orange-brown. Winter ID: bark; lateral buds conical and adpressed to twigs.
Fronds form a symmetrical rosette, up to 90 cm long, eventually produced on a scaly, black trunk with separate spore bearing fronds.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Needles flat, rounded tips, two white bands on underside. Winter ID: three or more buds present at terminal ends.
Stems flattened, green, and toothed with remnants of leaves; flowers terminal, solitary and in a wide variety of bright colours.

Leaves evergreen glossy, pungent when crushed, petioles upright, thick and succulent; flowers drooping, cup-shaped, yellowish-green often with a purple edge to the five petal-like sepals in spring; fruit is an aggregate of 3 (-5) wrinkled follicles.
Clump forming; leaves large, cordate, with heavy parallel venation towards the apex; florets with 6 tepals in racemes to 80 cm tall.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves needle-like, lemon scented, 1(-2.5) cm long; flowers arise from leaf axils, 5 rounded petals, 10 stamens, 1(-2.5) cm wide.

Leaves basal, palmately compound with 7-9 leaflets that are serrated, leathery, and glossy; flowers large, cup-shaped, rose-like, usually nodding 7-10 cm wide, usually in clusters of 1-4 on thick peduncles rising above the foliage.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves basal from thick rhizome, round with lobes and teeth, to 20 (-40) cm wide; florets pink, on purple panicle arising prior and well above foliage in spring.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Pinnae lower surface with chain-like rows of sori.
Grass 60 cm high; leaves are green with creamy yellow variegation; flower narrow, discreet spike.
Most infloresences with 5 branches.
Leaves lance-shaped; florets with 6 tepals, clustered in long, dense racemes.
Compact deciduous shrub with elliptic leaves to 3 cm long with underside pubescence along veins. Winter ID: few scales on opposite buds; prominant lenticels; young shoots 4-sided.
Leaves oblanceolate, margins round-toothed to entire, up to 45 cm long, in basal rosette; florets yellow, up to 3 cm wide, in spike-like inflorescence up to 50 cm long. .

Leaves glossy, rich green linear needles with 2 stomata lines underneath, <3.5 cm long, point forward/overlap above on each shoot, flat tip; female cones greenish-brown, ovoid-cylindrical, protruding bracts, held upright on upper branches; buds light brown, terminal or clusters of 5-7.
Leaves oblanceolate to obovate-oblanceolate, smooth, dark green and glossy, up to 13 cm long and 3 cm wide; flowers yellow, clustered in leaf axils, about 7 mm wide.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves basal, petioles long and dark, blades very large and heart-shaped.
Leaves opposite, ovate to oblong, downy, each with 3-7 prominent longitudinal veins, 5-10 cm long; flowers pink to purple with purple stamens, 7-10 cm wide, 5-7 fused petals; capsules 5-valved.
Deciduous barberry with bright yellow-green simple ovate, entire leaves to 2 cm long. Winter ID: unbranched spiny stipules.
Medium sized (larger than C. 'Snowline'), spreading (baby plants around the base in contrast to the pure clumping of other Carex); leaves variegated pale yellow on both margins.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves basal, ivy-shaped, usually gray-green with silver-white marbling from fall to spring; flower stalks arise before leaves in late summer, pink-purple or white that may be tinged with pink, up to 5 cm long.
Low ground cover; leaves succulent; flowers large, daisy-like in June.

Leaves basal, with long petioles, palmate blades up to 15 cm wide, deeply divided into 3-5 ovate toothed lobes (also leaves on stem, sessile, with 3 ovate lobes); flowers globe-shaped with 15-20 inward curving tepals, late spring to early summer, to 5 cm wide.
Leaves small, needle-like, apex sharp-pointed, rounded in cross-section.
Leaves with fine toothed margins, up to 20 cm long, in a basal rosette; florets form a ball on ends of upright peduncle in March - April.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist
petalColour: (Flowers with yellow centers. Many different flowered cultivars available.)

keyFeatures: Compared to Asiatic lilies, Oriental lilies tend to have larger, wider (more elliptical) leaves and larger but fewer flowers (in whites pinks, reds, or rarely yellow) that are strongly scented; 6 tepals.
Leaves opposite (lower) or alternate (upper), oblong to lance-shaped, clasping stem, up to 8 cm long.
petalColour: (petal colour often of two different shades or colours; many cvs.)

keyFeatures: Leaves simple, opposite, elliptic to oblong, <2 cm long; inflorescences with long-lasting, showy white petal-like floral bracts.
Leaves long-stalked with 7-17 ovate leaflets with few spines; flowers pinkish - beige and yellow in mid to late spring.
Leaves palmately compound with 7-16 elliptic to ovate leaflets up to 30 cm long.
fruitType: Drupe, Aggregate fruit, Aborted (hybrids) or absent

keyFeatures: A good lawn substitute; leaves opposite, ovate, entire, <5 mm long, mostly on runners with very short internodes.
Leaves thick, smooth, blue- then blue/green, glaucous underside; flower lavender, August.
Low growing, leaves evergreen with spiny margin.

Leaves linear-spatulate, prominent midrib, dull green/2 gray bands beneath, <1.5 cm; male cones catkin-like, red maturing to yellow; female cone of just two scales, green becoming bright red and drupe-like.
Low spreading ground cover with blue or white star shaped flowers in late spring to early fall.
Groundcover 5 cm high, dense; leaves 2 mm, opposite, oblanceolate, red tinge on new growth; flower verticillaster, mid-pink, June.
Leaves obovate, most about 3 cm long x 1.5 cm wide, margins with 11-15 spines.
Leaves ovate, small, about 2-3 cm long; raceme with two florets per node; flowers showy white, pink, purple, red with "two lips".
Leaves oblanceolate to elliptic, blade tissue extended almost to stem down the petiole; raceme with white to pink florets, 2.5 cm wide, late spring to fall.
Leaves glossy, wavy-margined; florets fan-shaped with 3 to 5 asymmetrical petals on four-sided stalked spikes.
Leaves narrowly lanceolate, serrate; florets about 2 cm wide, on racemes <20 cm long, May-Oct.
Leaves and flowers with distinct and uniquely variegation that changes with the seasons.
Flowers head-like with many tepals and no corona.
Spreading groundcover; leaves are tiny, elliptic, variegated (cream margins, mid-dark green centers), opposite, brown stems.
Slow-growing shrub, broadly arching; leaves opposite, finely toothed, deeply lobed or palmately compound, deep purple, turning bright red or orange in fall.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Bark scaly; needles stiff, 4-angled, bluish gray-green, arranged radially, round with flat top; female cones lacking.
fruitColour: (may be red or puple when immature)

keyFeatures: Leaves greenish-yellow, broad and serrated.
Leaves opposite, lance shaped, spearmint smell; florets forming globular clusters at peduncle nodes.
Leaves mostly whorled at nodes; flowers also whorled, bright yellow.
Leaves opposite linear to narrowly elliptic, glossy dark green leaves, prominent midribs, up to 12 cm long; florets in terminal cymes, petals (5 or cvs. with 10) fused at base, purple, pink or white.
Fruit with long husk extending 2-4 cm beyond the nut forming the 'beak' (unlike C. avellana)
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Stems squarish in c.s., common lawn weed that can be kept short by mowing; florets blue, in spike-like verticillasters.

Leaves aromatic, sticky, palmate with 5-7 elliptic leaflets, spiny stipules; florets spider-like with protruding stamens, in dense elongated terminal racemes of pink, purple or white, from summer to frost; fruits long and thin, pod-like capsules, green ripening to reddish-brown.
Florets arranged in a shrimp-like spike with reddish or rarely yellow bracts.
petalColour: (depends on cultivar - red and pink is more common)

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite or whorled (most other willow species have alternate leaves); florets in reddish-brown catkins, 1-2.5 cm long, early spring.
Leaves all green and very shiny.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Habit bushy; leaves simple, ovate; flowers small, fluffy blue, pink or white in summer and autumn.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Upright and usually not branched, to 40 cm tall; leaves ovate with serrated margins; florets bright yellow in flattened corymbs.

Leaves are stoutly spined, grey-green, deeply lobed basal leaves up to 15–25 cm long, with smaller leaves on the upper part of the flower stem; the leaf lobes are spear-shaped; heads 2.5–5 cm wide, florets appear all the same.
Leaves usually deeply incised leaves, soft to the touch, velvety, and strongly rose scented; flowers pale pink to almost white, mid summer to fall.

Leaves ovate, acute, solid dark-green, margins hairy, crenulate; flowers < 8 cm wide, spur, red, crimson, pink, purple,or white. New Guinea hybrids: leaves tricolor with red midrib, yellow arrow-shaped center and dark-green towards the margins.
Leaves alternate, simple, toothed with winged bases; flowers pink, dark red or purple, tubular, up to 3 cm long.
Leaves ovate to lancolate, shiny, blades about 5 cm long; flowers fragrant, blue and/ or white with yellow anthers, 2 cm wide.

Leaves ovate to elliptic, leathery when mature, flowers white, sepals 2 or 3, petals 5-12 and 1-1.5 cm long; fruit orange berry when mature, oval to round, 3-3.5 cm, glabrous. Winter ID: branchlets glabrous; pith white, solid.
Sub-shrub (becomes woody at base); leaves bluish-green, powdery, and deeply dissected into spoon shaped segments, 7-13 cm long; florets yellow, four-petaled.
Leaves opposite, ovate to lanceolate, dark green, spearmint fragrance and taste, up to 8 cm long; florets small, white to pink to lilac, in spike-like verticillasters.

Stems/branches covered in fine hairs; leaves pubescent both sides, broadly ovate, doubly serrate. Winter ID: male flowers pendulous catkins, in 3's, along branch, winter-spring; buds green-pale brown, chubby.
Leaves willow-like arrow, margins sparsely serrated, up to 5 cm long x 5 mm wide; florets about 1 cm wide, 5 oval petals, white.

Leaves basal, oblanceolate, dark green with white undersides; flower heads very showy, ray floret corollas brightly coloured, most tend to be darker at the base forming a rind and/ or the centre of each corolla may be darker.
Leaves basal, ovate to oblong, margins scalloped, velvety; flowers trumpet-shaped, up to 10 cm wide.
Rounded habit; leaves scale-like, variegated.
Rhizomes only; leaves basal, large, arrowhead-shaped, forming clumps to 60-90 cm tall, flowers minute and in a yellow finger-like spadix surrounded by a bright white bract (the spathe).
Similar to Ilex aquifolium; stems purple tinged-green; leaves glossy bright green, spiny, elliptic to ovate; flowers pinkish-white. Winter ID: fruit glossy red berries on nearby female plants.
origin: Garden origin (Ilex rugosa x I. aquilfolium)

keyFeatures: Thicket-forming shrub; leaves ovate to lance-shape (6-18 cm), sessile, finely serrated.
Bushy shrub; leaves grey-green, opposite, oblong, 6cm, fuzzy; flowers tubular, creamy white. Winter ID: black stems with 'chicken feet' buds, opposite.
Leaves heavily veined, major veins off midrib +/- parallel and curved towards apex, creamy variegation.
Leaves ovate, margins with rounded teeth; flowers violet to amethyst blue, arising from upper leaf axils, in dense cymes, Aug - Oct.
Evergreen perennial tufted, thick; leaves basal, linear, dark green (25-45 cm); flowers are bright violet.

Leaf vernation folded, blade rough, glossy, bright green with glassy lower surface, V-shaped to flat, 1-4 mm wide, tapering to a boat-shaped tip…auricles absent…ligules mostly 2-4 mm, yellow-green, acute to truncate…rhizomes absent… stolons thin, rooting at nodes…culm and sheath flattened and rough…tufted habit. Field ID terms: boat tip, summer stress vs. winter vibrant, puffy/ elevated crowns, reddish sheath.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaf vernation folded, blade light green in spring and fall, V-shaped to flat, mostly >2 mm wide, two parallel pale lines on either side of midrib, margins parallel (not tapering), short with boat-shaped tip…auricles absent…ligule 2-3 mm, whitish, slightly pointed, medium length…low, frequent flowering… rhizomes present…stolons present (perennial)… prostrate growth habit with low, frequent flowering. Field ID terms: boat tip, seed heads, brighter, apple-green, dull under, creeping.

Leaf vernation folded, 2-3 mm wide, tip boat-shaped, tip rounded …auricles absent…ligule 0.6-1.5 mm…sheath thin, smooth, 1.5 to 5 x longer than blade…culm 0.5-0.7 mm wide … rhizomes present…+/- stolons…thatchy habit with tufted or isolated culms.

Leaf vernation folded, blade soft, smooth on both sides, V-shaped to flat, 1-4 mm wide, two parallel pale lines on either side of midrib, edges parallel but then tapering to a boat-shaped and rounded tip…sheath green and smooth…auricles absent…ligule 0.2-0.6 mm truncate, small trichomes on back…sheath slightly compressed… rhizomes strong, multi-branched…stolons absent…thatchy habit. Field ID terms: boat tip, darker (?), duller, smooth top.

Leaf vernation rolled, blade underside glossy, 3-7 mm wide, margins smooth, tapering to a sharp and long pointed tip…auricles clasping, claw-like…ligule 0.1-2 mm, entire… sheath usually reddish at base…+/- very short rhizomes... bunching (tufted) habit, fast growing. Field ID terms: clasping auricles, rolled, pointy.

Leaf vernation folded, blade v-shaped in cs, keeled, 2-5 mm wide, heavily veined and dull above, underside smooth and very glossy, tapering to a sharp and long pointed tip, margin smooth…auricles small, rounded…ligule 0.5-1.5 mm, toothed near tip…sheath smooth, glossy, and usually reddish at base…stem flattened…no rhizomes or stolons…bunching (tufted) habit. Field ID terms: shiny, glossy, folded, pointy-boat, ridged top, darker(?).

Leaf vernation rolled, blade flat and stiff, sharply pointed blade 3-12 mm wide, strongly veined upper surface, strong midrib, lower surface keeled and slightly glossy, rough edges, sharp tip… auricles very small (or absent), rounded, pubescent …few trichomes on collar…ligule mostly 0.4-1.2 mm, smooth edged, with few trichomes…sheath round but keeled near top, glabrous, often reddish at base…+/- short rhizomes… bunching (tufted) habit. Field ID terms: wide, stiff, ridges, rolled.

Leaf vernation folded but hard to see (bristle-like leaves), blade slightly folded, <2 mm wide, deeply ridged on upper surface (heavily veined), tips rounded and not boat-shaped… auricles absent…ligule <0.3 mm, truncate…sheath base reddish, round to very slightly compressed, wider than blade…rhizomes present…stolons absent… bunching, thatchy, aggressive, dense sod habit with bent culms.

Leaf vernation folded, blades bluish-green, bristle-like, 0.5-1.5 mm wide, sharply pointed, top prominently ridged…sheath densely pubescent…auricles absent…ligules <0.3 mm… sheath split, margins overlap, sometimes hairy reddish base…rhizomes absent…stolons absent…erect habit.

Leaf vernation folded, blades about 1 m wide sharply pointed, bristle-like, top prominently ridged …auricles absent…ligule <0.6 mm or absent…+/-rhizomes…stolons short…sheath split, margins overlap, sometimes hairy reddish base…bunch-type growth habit. Field ID terms: needle-like, wiry, narrow, bristly, round.

Leaf vernation rolled, blade about 1 mm wide, flat, tapering to a pointed, canoe-shaped tip, prominent veins on the upper side, finely toothed margins… auricles absent …ligule about 1 mm, jagged tip…rhizomes present…stolons well developed… culms round in section, sheath closed…non-tuft habit.

Leaf vernation rolled, blades 1.5-2.5 mm, soft, flat, tapering, stiff, adpressed, pointed, canoe-shaped tips, prominent veins on the upper sides of leaf blades finely toothed margins… auricles absent…ligule white, 1-3 mm…rhizomes present…stolons thin, long, near ground surface… culms round in section with closed sheath…thatchy, dense, non-tuft habit in lawns.

Leaf vernation rolled, blades narrow 1-3.5 mm wide, soft, flat, tapering leaf blades, pointed, canoe-shaped tips…prominent veins on the upper sides of leaf blades finely toothed margins… auricles absent…ligule 0.3-1.2 mm, finely toothed… culms c.s. round with closed sheath, sheath longer than internodes…short, thin rhizomes…+/- stolons…thatchy, dense, somewhat tufted growth habit. Field ID terms: Pastel-soft, blue-grey-silver, pointy tip, rolled, soft feel, puffy/ elevated crowns.

scientificName: Elymus repens ssp. repens ( syn. Agropyron repens )
keyFeatures: Stems (culms) 40-150 cm tall; rhizomes long, aggressive, sharp-pointed with yellowish tips; leaves linear, 15-40 cm long and 3-10 mm broad at the base of the plant, with leaves higher on the stems 2-8 mm broad, vernation rolled, blade rough on the upper surface, not glossy, auricles 1 mm long, slender and overlapping to clasp the culm, ligule 0.5-1 mm long, sheath not compressed, base with trichomes; flower spike 10-30 cm long, spikelets 1–2 cm long, 5-7 mm broad and 3 mm thick with three to eight florets, glumes 7-12 mm long, usually without an awn or with only a short one. (Wikipedia)

Strongly tufted grass from fibrous roots; stems hollow, erect, up to 150 cm tall; leaf sheaths closed, venation folded, blades 2-10 mm wide, strongly V-shaped in section, light green to bluish green…auricles absent…ligules whitish 2-8 mm long, margins finely jagged, fringed with small hairs, and sometimes with jagged top or splitting lengthwise…sheaths keeled, strongly compressed, especially at crown…stolons absent...clump forming habit in mowed turf.
Lawn weed with alternating rounded but lobed leaves with heavy palmate venation; flowers about 1.5-2 cm across with 5 slightly notched petals.

Leaf vernation rolled, blades dull green to purplish, 2-6 mm wide, lacking hairs (trichomes) except sometimes in collar area, rough textured, tips sharp-pointed…sheaths mostly closed, compressed, smooth…auricles absent…collar with long trichomes…ligule 2-3 mm tall, frayed or wavy edged…rhizomes absent (annual)…prostrate or ascending habit.
Leaves basal, ovate to elliptic, up to 3 cm long; flowers 2-6 cm wide, flattened, face-like, available in many colours and most petals have more than one colour or shading.

Leaf blades 1-1.5 cm wide, flat, and sharply pointed and with dense short hairs… auricles absent…ligule medium height with jagged flattened top, hairy on leaf blade side only... sheaths hairy, compressed with pink veins…clump forming habit.
Stems green with obvious purple blotches from which stiff white hairs arise; leaves deeply lobed, sharply toothed, and serrated.
Leaves opposite, ovate, margins with long pointed teeth.
Small tree with dark green odd-pinnate leaves with 11-23 toothed leaflets; fruit berry-like, red then scarlet in fall with large black seed.
Large vine; leaves alternate, <20 cm long, rounded, lobed with palmate venation; tendrils; berry clusters.
origin: Garden origin (Mediterranean; most cvs. are hybrids of V. vinifera)

keyFeatures: Fast growing annual vine; stipules large and leaf-like surround the stem; leaves compound with broadly ovate to elliptical leaflets, entire or less commonly toothed, some leaflets develop into tendrils instead; flowers with large butterfly-like petals; legume containing mostly 6-11 seeds in a row, flattened when young but becoming roundish later.
petalColour: (depends on cultivar; pale yellow to cream-tan also common)

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate with three oval, leaflets with entire margins, 6-15 cm long; flowers white, pink, or purple, about 1 cm long; legumes green, yellow, black, or purple, 8-20 cm long x 1-1.5 cm wide, each containing 4-6 kidney-shaped beans up to 1.5 cm long.
Ground cover vine; leaves alternate, large, cordate on long upright petioles (lily-pad appearance), long hairs; flower similar to C. maxima but smaller.
Flower buds green, large and in tight, terminal clusters at the ends of thick edible stems, bloom bright yellow if not harvested.
Stems long and thin, climbing (or used as a groundcover potted annual plant); leaves alternate, oblong-spathulate, most 3-5 cm long; flowers about 2 cm wide, petals 5, pale blue.

Leaves ovate, with entire, undulating margins, to 8 cm long; flowers nodding, creamy-yellow, 2.5 cm wide; fruit lantern-like, deep orange accessory tissue from calyx, 5 cm long, each enclosing a red berry.
fruitColour: (red berry inside orange 'lantern' formed by calyx)

keyFeatures: Large low creeping vine; leaves very large, palmate with a maple leaf shape, small sharp serrations along margin; flowers trumpet-like, extremely large, bright yellow with ruffled edge; fruit is a large orange pepo (pumpkin).
Winter: multiple straight basal stems with small prickles, Summer:same with compound leaves
Leaves linear, up to 45 cm long x 1.4 cm wide; florets fragrant with 6 white tepals, usually white (pink or yellow cvs.) in terminal raceme well above leaves (60-120 cm tall).
Leaves simple, heavily dissected and elongated.
Narrowly columnar tree; leaves broadly elliptic, dark purple turning red in fall. Winter ID: habit, form, and 'elephant skin' bark; buds narrow, pointy, alternating on reddish-brown twigs.
Leaves are variegated green with golden margin. Winter ID: Buds large, 2 scales not overlapping, looks-like 'praying hands'.
Small size; leaves are dark green with white margins; base of leaves are triangular in cross-section.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Very dense ground cover; leaves basal and then opposite on runners, ovate, bronze-green, irregular margins; florets crowded in verticillasters, blue to purple, May-June.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Similar to Ilex aquifolium, structure pyramidal; stems purple tinged-green; leaves satiny dark green, serrated, spiny, elliptic to ovate; flowers pinkish-white. Winter ID: fruit glossy red berries (female plants).
origin: Garden origin (Ilex rugosa x I. aquilfolium)

keyFeatures: Stems jointed with sheathing stipules; leaves broadly ovate to 30 cm long, marbled and splashed with creamy white, yellow and a touch of pink, with each leaf having a large central reddish-brown chevron; flowers small, pinkish-red, on long, slender stalks mid to late summer.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Shrub vase-shape/ascending branches; leaves fall colour gold to deep purple-red. Winter ID: buds fuzzy; flowers clusters of buds, or spider-like flowers, yellow, orange, or dark red in Jan-Feb on bare fuzzy stems.
origin: Garden origin (H. japonica x H. mollis)

keyFeatures: Shrub multi-stemmed; stems red to orange-brown/turn to light gray; leaves opposite, elliptic to lance-shaped with acuminate tip, dull gray-green fall colour reddish-purple; flowers creamy-white, tiny, early June; berries small, white.
Leaves ovate - lanced shaped, about 25 cm long; flowers bell shaped, pink, white, or purple, inflorescence rises above, narrow spike, about 10 cm long.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves succulent, toothed, and with margins yellowish.
Low-growing, hairless perennial; leaves fleshy dark green, heart-shaped; flowers with numerous bright yellow, glossy petals.
Leaves very bright pale yellow to greenish-yellow; flowers pale lavender.
origin: Garden origin (x H. ‘Sea Fire’ by O. Petryszyn (ONIR)

keyFeatures: Leaves thick, variegated with gold centers and irregular blue-green margins, in a thick mound.
Flowers appear pale orange - amber deep yellow petals speckled with red, sepals red tinted on back.
origin: Garden origin (E. flavum x E. wushanense 'Caramel')

keyFeatures: Clump forming; leaves 5-7 lobed, toothed, and up to 25 cm wide.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves underside whitish compared to F. pennsylvanica, leaflets 7-9 per leaf, margins entire, wavy, scalloped, or with small teeth. Winter ID: buds rusty to dark chocolate brown with suede-like scalloped scales; leaf scar crescent shaped with the lateral bud sitting within the scar; densely branches.
Needles 4-9 cm long, blue-green, 5 per fascicle, persistent; male cones red; female cones long, ovoid, yellow-ochre, seeds wingless.
Leaves deep purple, entire or lobed; flowers bright pinkish red in April-May; pomes dark red, about 1 cm round.
origin: Garden origin (an open-pollinated seedling of M. transitoria 'Schmidtcutleaf')

keyFeatures: Leaves <18 cm; flowers scented, white/pink flush, large cup-n-saucer shape, most with 12 broad tepals, about 15 cm wide, late March to early April; ornamental fruit.
origin: Garden origin (M. sargentiana var. robusta × M. sprengeri ‘Diva’)

keyFeatures: Upright habit; leaves elliptic, lobes more shallow but similar to Gary oak, dark green on top and whitish on the underside.
origin: Garden origin (Quercus robur 'Fastigiata' X Q. bicolor)

keyFeatures: Narrowly pyramidal small tree; leaves broadly elliptic, dark purple turning copper colour in fall. Winter ID: habit, form, and 'elephant skin' bark; buds large, narrow pointy, alternating.
Fronds feathery, usually variegated; spores may form along a downward rolled margin.
Leaves silver-gray with dark green herring bone pattern along veins, blades broadly ovate to 7 cm long, petioles dark red to 12 cm long.
Leaves mature with bright, metallic-purple stripes radiating outward from the central leaf vein, to 8-12 (-20) cm long.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves grass-like and widely-spaced on the stems; flowers nodding, 6 tepals, checkered reddish-brown, purple, white, or grey.
petalColour: (checkered or all white as with F. 'Alba')

keyFeatures: Climbing deciduous vine; leaves are compound with 3-5 leaflets; flowers with 4 or 8 petal-like violet sepals in spring.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves alternate, oval-obovate, toothed; autumn leaves red-orange-yellow, <6 cm long; flowers white, fragrant, terminal 'bottlebrush' filaments.
Bushy, evergreen shrub; stems woolly; leaves aromatic, silver-grey to yellowish green, about 3 cm long.
Leaves divided into 3-5 slender pubescent leaflets (1-2 cm long x 1 mm wide); flowers orange-red to red, pea flower-shaped, but slender, 2-4 cm long and 5-8 mm broad like lobster claws.

Spreading or trailing habit (or tied to trellis); leaves pinnately compound with 7 ovate, doubly serrated leaflets in distinctive pattern, small prickles and stipules on petiole; fruit large, dark maroon coloured 'blackberry'.
origin: Garden origin (R. ideaus X R. fruticosis X R. x loganobaccus)

keyFeatures: Creeping ground cover <4 cm high, leaves oval (almost round), tiny with tiny notched; flowers white to blue, 4 petals, late May-June.
Leaves elliptic with wavy-crenate margins and red veins.
Leaves alternate, lanceolate, serrated, reddish-purple in fall; flowers dark red fading to rosy pink with age.
fruitType: Follicle, Aggregate fruit, Aborted (hybrids) or absent

keyFeatures: Leaves dull, dark green, up to 15 cm long, mostly with three pointy lobes, aromatic when crushed, stipules small and leafy if still present; berries glossy black with persistent calyx.
petalColour: (petals may be reddish-green to brownish depending on cv.)

keyFeatures: Habit spreading; Leaves are irregular, rounded with (3-)5 lobes, spines sporadic (0 to 2 per node), stipules to 2 cm long, prickles on some stems.
Flowering stem solid and triangular in cross-section; leaves grass-like; inflorescence umbel-like panicle forming brown clusters of achenes.
Leaves the lower half of the stem, strongly flattened (iris-like); florets in dark globular clusters.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Stems square in c.s., 60-120 cm tall; leaves opposite, ovate, serrated, lower surface downy, fragrant, up to 10 cm long; florets 2-lipped, tubular, < 1 cm long, tightly clustered in whorls to form spike-like verticillasters.
Compact aster; leaves lanceolate to spatulate, margins crenate to serrate, up to 10 cm x 2 cm; head inflorescences up to 2 cm wide, floret rays of most cultivars blue, disk florets yellow.
Leaves basal, triangular or v-shaped at ground level; fruit clustered, brown achenes.
Leaves to 6-10 cm wide on hairy petioles to 15-30 cm long; rhizomes smell like ginger.
Compacr blanket flower to 30 cm tall; heads to 8 cm wide; disc florets red; ray florets half red and half golden.
petalColour: ray floret corolla half golden yellow towards outer perimeter of head)

keyFeatures: Leaves covered with soft hairs (villosa).

Shrub upright, vase-shaped; stems gray; leaves ovate, 3 major lobes towards apex, light green, long stipule ; flowers large, trumpet-shaped, solitary or paired from leaf axils. Winter ID: branches whitish, upright; buds alternate with small hairs.
petalColour: (depends on cv.; often with darker centers; yellow anthers on white filaments)

keyFeatures: Leaves elliptical with rounded ends, about 12 mm long; flowers white or pink in late spring; berries sour-tasting, red or pink, 9-14 mm wide, harvested in October, persistant.
Leaves astilbe-like, deeply cut, ternately compound, bronze-purple; flowers creamy-white, Aug-Sept, scented, terminal racemes, bottlebrush-look.

Needles 2 per fascicle, 8-12 cm long, margins rough, stomatal lines on all surfaces; female cones conical to ovate, 4-7 cm long, in whorls of 2-5 at branch nodes, remaining closed and attached for several years, seed and attached wing 10-17 mm long. (Conifersociety.org)
Leaves alternate up flowering stem, partially folded lengthwise along major veins; flower petals much smaller than the similar colored sepals, throat spotted pink, up to 12 cm wide.
Leaves dark green (appears a metallic blue/purple under full sun); lance-shaped to 30 cm long and 2 cm wide with prominent veins on the underside.
Leaves alternate, simple, ovate, serrated, up to 14 cm long.

"Leaves" are flexible needle-like cladodes (modified stems) in the axils of tan coloured scale leaves; flowers greenish-white to yellowish, bell shaped, arising at nodes in spring, about 5 mm long; berries on female plants in late summer.

Habit compact and shrubby, slow-growing; leaves to 15 cm long, medium green then turning yellow-bronze in fall; flowers fragrant, about 15 cm wide, most with 6 tepals fuchsia fading to pink, May and again in August.
origin: Garden origin (M. liliiflora ‘Nigra’ x M. stellata ‘Rosea’)
fruitType: Aborted (hybrids) or absent, Follicle, Aggregate fruit

keyFeatures: Clump forming bulbous perennial to 10 cm tall; leaves basal with 9-22 heart-shaped leaflets; flowers pinkish-purple, to 2.5 cm wide, with 5 petals and dark veined.

Leaves toothed, mostly ovate, 2.5 cm to 7.5 cm long; flowers of most cvs. rosy-pink and at the tips of the branches. Winter ID: Branches fine, upright with many dry terminal fruit clusters; bark is reddish-brown, smooth.

Low shrub or creeper (quick to form adventitious roots); leaves opposite, elliptic to oval, finely toothed, dark green, 2-6 cm long x 1-3 cm wide; fruit spherical, < 6 mm, white capsules with orange arils (seeds; fruit absent in some cvs.).
origin: dark green; flowers clusters of cymes; fruit white/orange arils

keyFeatures: Leaves long, narrow, linear, and tightly packed, most 1-2 mm wide x 10-15 cm long; florets commonly pink, in rounded compact clusters on erect scapes (peduncles) about 15 cm long.
origin: Garden origin (A. alliacea x A. maritima ... or x pseudarmeria?)

keyFeatures: Flowers heart shaped; leaves fern-like, blue gray foliage; slightly fragrant.

Habit tall, sturdy, dandelion-like with milky sap; leaves lobed with margin spiny; flower heads 1.5 - 2.5 cm wide; short taproot (compared to perennial sow thistle head that are 3-5 cm wide and form deep, rhizome-like roots).
Leaf blades >45 cm, ruffled, puckered, red-orange-yellow-green, thick midribs and petioles.

Hollow, four-sided, stems to 2 m long; leaves are stipulate, alternate and compound, 3 - 8 pairs of linear, lance-shaped, leaflets up to 3.5 centimeters long, each ending in a branched tendril; flowers pea-like, occur in the leaf axils, solitary or in pairs, flower corolla is 1-3 mm long, usually bright pink to purple; legume to 7 cm long.
Garlic bulb; leaves linear, flattened, about 2 cm wide x 30 cm long; florets pinkish-white, in umbel to 45 cm tall in summer.
fruitColour: (tan with dark grey to black seeds)

keyFeatures: Swollen taproot that is commonly red; leaves basal with long petioles in the first year, ovate with wavy margins (second year leaves alternate on flowering stem).
Leaves clustered around a short stem to form a dense globular head.
Leaves colorful, mostly green reddish or rarely variegated, yellow, gold or bluish.
Creeping; flowers relatively large with four violet petals and yellow center.
Leaves basal, oblong, margins wavy and scalloped, up to 60 cm long; florets small, whitish, in terminal panicles.
Leaves large with irregular margin; swollen tap root.

Stems square in c.s., 60-120 cm tall; leaves opposite, ovate, serrated, lower surface downy, lemon fragrance, up to 4 cm long; florets 2-lipped, tubular, < 2 cm long, clustered in whorls to form verticillasters up to 30 cm long.
Leaves blades large and heart-shaped, with stalks like celery but red that arise from short, thick rhizomes.
Leaves pinnately compound with dissected leaflets, basal, arsing from top of a carrot.
Kale-like but with large leaf buds (or "Brussel sprouts") forming (seedlings with rounded leaf blades).
Leaves large, prickly, deeply-lobed, silver-gray; flowers large, thistle-like.
Needles 5 per fascicle, drooping, gray-green,13-19 cm long, arching, bluish-green; seed cones narrow, greenish, slowly turning brown before dropping, up to 30 cm long.

Bulbs mostly clustered with papery covering, white to brownish or reddish; leaves cylindrical, linear; umbels spherical, densely flowered on peduncle up to 1 m tall; florets stellate, pedicels 3-4 times as long as the tepals which are 4-5 mm long and greenish-white.

Stems winged and end in tendrils; leaves pinnately compared with two leaflets and a terminal tendril, which twines around supporting plants and structures; flowers highly fragrant and now come in many colours, 2–3.5 cm wide.
Onion-like biennials but varieties grown for stems may lack distinct bulbs; leaves sheathing long, linear and gradually narrowing down to the fine tip.
Flower buds usually creamy-white and very tightly clustered and harvested as a rounded mass 10-20 cm wide.
Long spreading or tailing shoots; leaves dissected, margins spinose.
Leaves coarsely toothed; flowers white, petal fused, fuzzy, about 3 cm wide; fruit a berry surrounded by a persistent green paper-like calyx.
Leaves long and hollow, up to 4 cm in diameter in fall; bulbs absent.
Leaves alternate, ovate, entire when immature then becoming lobed to dentate.

Leaves basal, arising from a swollen part of the rhizome (pseudobulb), linear, most over 30 cm long x less than 3 cm wide; florets with a waxy texture, 5 tepals plus lip (modified lower petal), 5-10 cm wide, raceme as high as 90 cm with the peduncle arising from the base of the most recent pseudobulb in winter.
Leaflet lanceolate; flowers fragrant, white (pink in bud).
Stems thick but fragile; leaves pointed, narrow-oblong, elliptical, bases sheathing the stem, to 15 cm long; flowers with 3 pink petals, about 2 cm wide, in small clusters.
Male plants with catkins 15-30 cm long; fruit a chain of dry purplish berries on separate female plants.

Needles flattened, glossy dark green above, and with two broad, vividly white bands of stomata below 1-2 cm x 2-2.5 mm x 0.5 mm, slightly notched at the tip; cones dark purple-blue before maturity, 4-7 cm x 1.5-2 cm; scale bracts long, green or yellow, and emerge between the scales in the closed cone.
Single-stemmed small tree with ascending branches; flowers mostly with 12 dark red-purple tepals that are more pinkish on the inside.
origin: Garden origin (M. liliiflora ‘Nigra’ x M. sprengeri ‘Diva’)
fruitType: Follicle, Aggregate fruit, Aborted (hybrids) or absent

keyFeatures: Leaves silvery green, oblong; flowers small, white, feathery; fruit a small green then purple drupe. Winter ID: buds opposite on four angled stem; immature olives may be present.
Leaves on the lower stem are broad ovoid-acute, up to 30 cm long, rough texture and hairy; flowers heads yellow, 5–10 m wide, with 10–20 ray florets.

Leaves usually ovate, sometimes ovate-oblong, 6-12 x 5-10 cm, margin sharply serrate, apex abruptly acuminate; florets greenish yellow or white, 1.2-2 cm wide when fully open, 4-6 petals 7-9 mm long; anthers black or dark purple. Winter ID: branchlets lenticels absent when young, small and inconspicuous when old; pith white to brown.
Flowers large, commonly purple to blue with toothed ligules on the ray florets.

Leaves lance-shaped, blade bases gradually tapering to petioles; umbels of 8 to 20 nodding florets with curved-back petals and yellow stamens that converge to a point, capsules drop seed and then the whole plant goes dormant until next spring. basal rosette of lance-shaped leaves come 1-4 sturdy, leafless, center flower scapes rising to 20" tall. Atop each flower scape is an umbel containing 8-20, nodding, 1" long flowers. Each flower has five swept-back (reflexed) petals and a cluster of yellow stamens converging to a point, thus giving the flower the appearance of a shooting star plummeting to earth.

Stems square in c.s.; leaves narrow-lanceolate, sharply-toothed, up to 12 cm long; flowers snapdragon-like (tubular, two-lipped), pink to pale lilac in upright terminal spikes up to 40 cm long from July until late fall.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Evergreen, mat-forming, perennial ground cover; leaves rounded, basal or alternate on runners; flowers larger, white to pinkish-violet.
A flat carpet of lead-grey foliage that creeps along between and over small rocks.
Up to 25 cm tall; leaves obovate up to 2.5 x 4 cm, greyish blue-green with reddish veins and tips; flowers rosy-red.
origin: Garden origin (S. cauticola x S. telephium)
petalColour: (petals dark pink at tip and paleer at base; carpels bright pink)
fruitType: Aborted (hybrids) or absent, Follicle, Aggregate fruit

keyFeatures: Similar to hens and chicks; leaves in rosettes, chalky-gray, succulent; flowers small, in conical spikes.
Up to 12 cm tall; stems dark red; leaves grey, oblong to ovate, toothed toward apex, up to 2.5 x 1.5 cm; flowers purple or pink-purple.
Rapidly expanding on still water surfaces; fronds forming moss-like mats of foliage about 1 cm tall.
Leaves round, deeply divided into 7-9 lobes and 3-6 inch wide; flowers pale blue (pink cvs.).
Long arching rope-like branchlets of tightly overlapping scales.
Twigs with thorns; leaves are glossy dark green, up to 15 cm long, winged petioles; flowers about 5 cm, four white petals.
origin: Garden origin (C. sinensis x C. maxima)

keyFeatures: A thallose lichen commonly epiphytic on tree bark; upper surface pale or bright orange, bearing fruiting bodies (apothecia).
Leaves glabrous, about 4 cm long, most margins with 13-19 spines.

Leaves basal, usually pinnately lobed with the terminal lobe much larger than the lateral lobes; roots swollen, commonly pink or red but may be white, tan, brown or black, globular or elongated (many varieties exist).
Leaves fussy and almost round; florets pink to purple in masses of hop-like greenish flower bracts.
Leaves long-stalked with 3-7 ovate leaflets, margins usually spinose.
Leaves basal, trifoliate, leaflets obovate with toothed margins; flowers 5-petaled, pink with yellow centres, formed primarily in spring and followed by a few small fragrant strawberries.
origin: Garden origin (F. x ananassa x Comarum palustre)

keyFeatures: Leaves opposite, dark green, lance-shaped to elliptic-oval (like stinging nettle), sharp-toothed, taper-pointed, petioles long; flowers small fluffy, bright white, (composites with rays absent) arranged in loose corymbs to 7-10 cm across.

Leaves oblanceolate to ovate-elliptic, leathery, glossy, sharply toothed, light green with yellow/pinkish tinge when new, dark green mature leaves/yellow variegation; flowers white, fragrant, clusters, tubular, in fall, about 5 mm wide.
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Leaves bright green, pointy, round in cross-section; flowers yellow.
Leaves and stems strongly scented, pubescent to hairy.
Leaves linear to oblanceolate, most about 2 cm long x 5 mm wide, pungent; flowers commonly white to light violet, about 10 mm long x 6 mm wide across the three larger lower petals.
Very sweet taste (up to 30 times sweeter than sugar); leaves opposite, sessile, elliptic to oblong with serrate margins

Highly-scented, tufted, herbaceous perennial, strongly scented; leaves bright yellow-green, pubescent, ovate, to 1-2(-3) cm long, most having a wrinkled appearance and margins curved upwards; flowers densely arranged in verticillasters, white to pink, to 3 mm wide.
Basal, clumping, taproot; leaves dark green, oblong-ovate, leathery, dentate; flowers blue/blue-green bracts, Aug-Oct, tight clustered spikes, umbels (three or more may arise from common node).

A clump-forming hybrid to 60 cm tall; leaves alternate, lance shaped to narrowly elliptic, margins sparingly toothed, up to 9 cm long; florets bright yellow, just 3-4 mm wide, densely arranged in plume-like panicles.
Leaves basal and strap-shaped with fuzzy-edged grayish cross-banding.

Small tree 2-15 m tall, often shrubby or irregular; branches spreading to drooping in flat sprays; similar to the English yew but more irregular and has slightly shorter and narrower, yellow-green leaves (most 12-18 mm long x 1-2 mm wide); aril round to less commonly oval, 5-6 mm long; male cones rounded on separate trees, 3 mm long. (Eflora BC)
Plants and leaves resemble pepper; flowers small and white; berries ripening from green to deep black.
Branches pale green at first becoming striped chalk-white; leaves 3-5 lobed. Winter ID: vase shaped; buds opposite, dark red, pointy; bark green striped.

Tiered branching; leaves alternate (most other dogwood tree have opposite leaves); inflorescence to 18 cm wide with 4 large bracts in early summer. [The variegated giant dogwood tree located at BCE is dedicated to Jack Copeland, an outstanding student who passed way just before his final exams in 2014. Jack was a one of a kind student that gave so much to the program and his fellow students, and this was his favorite tree.]
Habit with tiered horizontal branching; new growth reddish; floral bracts on this cultivar are well spaced (not overlapping); fruit absent.
origin: Garden origin (Cornus florida x C. kousa)
exposure: Full sun only if soil kept moist

keyFeatures: Needles 2 per fascicle, 7-9 cm long; female cones 5-8 cm long, nearly black when immature.
fruitColour: (cobalt blue in mid summer; brown when mature)

keyFeatures: Leaves emerge red and then red again in fall. Winter ID: persistent fruit (drooping woody capsules).

Stems with four-angled branches; leaves roughly 1-3 centimeters long, thick, leathery, toothed, and pointed or round-tipped; flowers flattened, petals dark red, oval, 1 mm long; fruit an oblong capsule to 1 cm long with usually one seed in each of its two valves; seed dark, shiny, and partly covered in a white aril.
Leaves alternate, 2-5 cm long, wider and toothed towards the apex; stipules absent.
Branchlets glossy brown; needles sharply pointed, 8-15 mm long.
Fronds leathery, evergreen, glossy, dark green (resembles mahonia), to 70 cm long, once-pinnate; sori randomly scattered on lower surface.
Leaves large, velvety; bark exfoliating, tan coloured.
Leaves compound and in whorls of three; flowers bright white white in late spring.
